MCQ Test

Q1: What is the rumen?

Source: RRB Group-D 29-09-2022 (Shift-II)
Correct! The rumen is a chamber of the stomach to store food. The rumen is also known as a paunch, is the largest stomach compartment in ruminant and act as a storage or holding vat for feed.
Incorrect. The rumen is a chamber of the stomach to store food. The rumen is also known as a paunch, is the largest stomach compartment in ruminant and act as a storage or holding vat for feed.

Q2: Which of the following organisms has a longer small intestine?

Source: RRB Group-D 23-08-2022 (Shift-II)
Correct! Among the following cow has the longest small intestine. It is a fact that cow has intestines that are 20 times as long as its body.
Incorrect. Among the following cow has the longest small intestine. It is a fact that cow has intestines that are 20 times as long as its body.

Q3: ........... reduce (s) the size of large fat globules, allowing enzymes to work more effectively.

Source: RRB Group-D 25-08-2022 (Shift-I)
Correct! Bile salts reduce(s) the size of large fat globules, allowing enzymes to work more effectively. Bile salts are one of the primary components of bile. They help with the digestion of fats. They also help the body absorb fat soluble vitamins. The bile juice secreted by the liver.
Incorrect. Bile salts reduce(s) the size of large fat globules, allowing enzymes to work more effectively. Bile salts are one of the primary components of bile. They help with the digestion of fats. They also help the body absorb fat soluble vitamins. The bile juice secreted by the liver.

Q4: What is the effect of bile salts in the digestion of food?

Source: RRB Group-D– 13/09/2022 (Shift-II)
Correct! See the explanation of above question.
Incorrect. See the explanation of above question.

Q5: In which part of the human body are villi present?

Source: RRB Group-D 28-09-2022 (Shift-III)
Correct! Villi are present in the small intestine to increase the surface area of absorption.
Incorrect. Villi are present in the small intestine to increase the surface area of absorption.

Q6: Which figure shows the correct location of the liver (shown as the pink shape) in the human body (given that the person is facing you, the reader)?

Source: RRB Group-D– 06/10/2022 (Shift-I)
Correct! Figure 3 shows the correct location of the liver (shown as the pink shape) in the human body (given that the person is facing you the reader)?
Incorrect. Figure 3 shows the correct location of the liver (shown as the pink shape) in the human body (given that the person is facing you the reader)?

Q7: An adult human being has only ______ incisors in his/her mouth.

Source: RRB Group-D– 06/10/2022 (Shift-I)
Correct! An adult human being has only eight incisors in his/her mouth, with four along the top row and four along the bottom row. Incisors cut food up into smaller pieces, which the teeth and tongue then move to the back of the mouth.
Incorrect. An adult human being has only eight incisors in his/her mouth, with four along the top row and four along the bottom row. Incisors cut food up into smaller pieces, which the teeth and tongue then move to the back of the mouth.

Q8: The diagram below shows a part of the human alimentary canal. Which process is taking place and how?

Source: RRB Group-D– 30/09/2022 (Shift-III)
Correct! The process that is taking place in the diagram is peristalsis, due to rhythmic contraction and relaxation of muscular walls. Peristalsis is a series of wave-like muscle contractions that move food through the digestive tract. It starts in the esophagus where strong wave-like motions of the smooth muscle move balls of swallowed food to the stomach.
Incorrect. The process that is taking place in the diagram is peristalsis, due to rhythmic contraction and relaxation of muscular walls. Peristalsis is a series of wave-like muscle contractions that move food through the digestive tract. It starts in the esophagus where strong wave-like motions of the smooth muscle move balls of swallowed food to the stomach.

Q9: Match the columns. Group-I Group-II I. Mouth A. Chewing of food II. Teeth B. Rolling of food III. Tongue C. Intake of whole food IV. Saliva D. Swallowing of food

Source: RRB Group-D– 26/09/2022 (Shift-II)
Correct! The mouth consists of oral cavity, through which whole food is taken in it contains gums, teeth, a tongue, and openings of salivary glands. Teeth involve in chewing of food. The tongue allow the rolling of food and to shape it into a bolus. Salivary glands secrete saliva which helps in swallowing of food. RRB Science Planner Biology YCT 535
Incorrect. The mouth consists of oral cavity, through which whole food is taken in it contains gums, teeth, a tongue, and openings of salivary glands. Teeth involve in chewing of food. The tongue allow the rolling of food and to shape it into a bolus. Salivary glands secrete saliva which helps in swallowing of food. RRB Science Planner Biology YCT 535

Q10: To get rid of pain in the stomach during indigestion, people use:

Source: RRB Group-D– 26/09/2022 (Shift-II)
Correct! Milk of magnesia, also known as magnesium hydroxide is used to get rid of pain in the stomach during indigestion. It acts as an antacid or as saline laxative.
Incorrect. Milk of magnesia, also known as magnesium hydroxide is used to get rid of pain in the stomach during indigestion. It acts as an antacid or as saline laxative.

Q11: The enzymes responsible for final conversion of Proteins into amino acids, complex carbohydrates into glucose and fats into fatty acids and glycerol is present in the:

Source: RRB Group-D– 26/08/2022 (Shift-I)
Correct! The enzymes responsible for final conversion of proteins into amino acids, carbohydrates into glucose and fats into fatty acids and glycerol is present in the intestinal juice.
Incorrect. The enzymes responsible for final conversion of proteins into amino acids, carbohydrates into glucose and fats into fatty acids and glycerol is present in the intestinal juice.

Q12: Some features of villi of the small intestine in humans are given below: (i) They are finger-like with very thin walls (ii) Provide a large surface area (iii) Have small pores for food to pass (iv) Richly supplied by blood capillaries Which option/options shows/show the features that enable the villi to absorb food?

Source: RRB Group-D– 26/08/2022 (Shift-III)
Correct! Villi are tiny, finger-like projections from the wall of the small intestine. They line the inner surface of the small intestine. Their role is to increase the surface area within the small intestine. This will lead to the increase of the surface area of absorption as it is the main function of the small intestine.
Incorrect. Villi are tiny, finger-like projections from the wall of the small intestine. They line the inner surface of the small intestine. Their role is to increase the surface area within the small intestine. This will lead to the increase of the surface area of absorption as it is the main function of the small intestine.

Q13: What are the finger like projections that increase the area of absorption of the small intestine called?

Source: RRB Group-D– 13/09/2022 (Shift-II)
Correct! Villi are small finger-like projections found in the inner linings of small intestine. These micro structures play a major role in increasing the surface area for absorption of nutrients during the process of digestion.
Incorrect. Villi are small finger-like projections found in the inner linings of small intestine. These micro structures play a major role in increasing the surface area for absorption of nutrients during the process of digestion.

Q14: In which of the following places is the cellulose of food digested by the action of certain bacteria in animals like horses, rabbit, etc.?

Source: RRB Group-D– 22/09/2022 (Shift-III)
Correct! Caecum is the place where the cellulose of food digested by the action of certain bacteria in animals like horses, rabbit etc. Caecum is the part of large intestine.
Incorrect. Caecum is the place where the cellulose of food digested by the action of certain bacteria in animals like horses, rabbit etc. Caecum is the part of large intestine.

Q15: Which enzyme required the presence of hydrochloric acid for its action in the process of digestion?

Source: RRB Group-D– 01/09/2022 (Shift-I)
Correct! Pepsin is a gastric enzyme that serves to digest proteins found in ingested food. Gastric chief cells secrete pepsin as an inactive zymogen called pepsinogen.
Incorrect. Pepsin is a gastric enzyme that serves to digest proteins found in ingested food. Gastric chief cells secrete pepsin as an inactive zymogen called pepsinogen.

Correct! The pancreas is the second major gland of the human body. It produces pancreatic juice, which is responsible for digestion. There are three types of enzymes found in pancreatic juice –
Incorrect. The pancreas is the second major gland of the human body. It produces pancreatic juice, which is responsible for digestion. There are three types of enzymes found in pancreatic juice –

Q17: Which of the following organs secretes bile juice?

Source: RRB NTPC 21.03.2021 (Shift-II) Stage Ist
Correct! Bile juice is a yellowish fluid that is secreted by the liver. This juice is then stored in the gallbladder. Bile juice helps in digestion of food.
Incorrect. Bile juice is a yellowish fluid that is secreted by the liver. This juice is then stored in the gallbladder. Bile juice helps in digestion of food.

Q18: After digestion, protein is converted into:

Source: RRB NTPC 29.01.2021 (Shift-II) Stage Ist
Correct! In the stomach, protein digestion occurs with the aid of protease enzymes and pepsin enzymes, that break down proteins into amino acids. Amino acids are responsible for the breaking down of food and they are known as the building blocks of life. There are 20 amino acids obtained after digestion of proteins.
Incorrect. In the stomach, protein digestion occurs with the aid of protease enzymes and pepsin enzymes, that break down proteins into amino acids. Amino acids are responsible for the breaking down of food and they are known as the building blocks of life. There are 20 amino acids obtained after digestion of proteins.

Q19: What can humans NOT digest?

Source: RRB NTPC 29.01.2021 (Shift-II) Stage Ist
Correct! . The digestive system of human has many enzyme, and acids to break down and digest all kinds of different foods (carbohydrates, proteins and fats), but do not have the enzymes needed to break down cellulose. Cellulose is a complex carbohydrate, or polysaccharide, consisting of 3000 or more glucose units. It forms the cell walls of all plants and trees and is used in making plastics, paper, etc. Animals like cows, goats, sheep and other animals that graze, have the enzymes needed to digest cellulose. So, human are unable to digest cellulose due to the absence of appropriate enzymes.
Incorrect. . The digestive system of human has many enzyme, and acids to break down and digest all kinds of different foods (carbohydrates, proteins and fats), but do not have the enzymes needed to break down cellulose. Cellulose is a complex carbohydrate, or polysaccharide, consisting of 3000 or more glucose units. It forms the cell walls of all plants and trees and is used in making plastics, paper, etc. Animals like cows, goats, sheep and other animals that graze, have the enzymes needed to digest cellulose. So, human are unable to digest cellulose due to the absence of appropriate enzymes.

Q20: Lactose intolerance is :

Source: RRB Science Planner Biology
Correct! Lactose intolerance is the inability to break down a type of natural sugar called lactose. Lactose is commonly found in dairy products, such as milk and yogurt.Too little of an enzyme produced in small intestine (lactase) is usually responsible for lactose intolerance.
Incorrect. Lactose intolerance is the inability to break down a type of natural sugar called lactose. Lactose is commonly found in dairy products, such as milk and yogurt.Too little of an enzyme produced in small intestine (lactase) is usually responsible for lactose intolerance.

Q21: Which of the following has largest size in the human body?

Source: RRB J.E. (14.12.2014, Yellow paper)
Correct! The liver is the largest gland in the human body. It weighs between 1.5 to 2.0 kg. It is situated in the abdominal cavity, just below the diaphragm and has four lobes. The bile juice secreted by the liver is stored in the gall bladder. This bile catalyzes the action of enzymes present in the intestine and protects body by neutralizing toxins produced in the body.
Incorrect. The liver is the largest gland in the human body. It weighs between 1.5 to 2.0 kg. It is situated in the abdominal cavity, just below the diaphragm and has four lobes. The bile juice secreted by the liver is stored in the gall bladder. This bile catalyzes the action of enzymes present in the intestine and protects body by neutralizing toxins produced in the body.

Q23: Which is the largest internal organ of human body?

Source: RRB JE 23.05.2019 (Shift-III)
Correct! See the explanation of the above question.

Q24: Sight of delicious food usually makes mouth watery, it is a -

Source: RRB J.E. (14.12.2014, Green paper)
Correct! Sight of delicious food usually makes mouth watery, it is a neurological reaction. Mouth watering at the sight of tasty food is called salivation. Salivation is a nerve-mediated reflex. On the sight of food, how much saliva produced in mouth is depends upon the intensity and type of taste and also on tactile stimulation. Moreover , a reflex action is defined as an involuntary response shown by body in response to a sudden stimuli.
Incorrect. Sight of delicious food usually makes mouth watery, it is a neurological reaction. Mouth watering at the sight of tasty food is called salivation. Salivation is a nerve-mediated reflex. On the sight of food, how much saliva produced in mouth is depends upon the intensity and type of taste and also on tactile stimulation. Moreover , a reflex action is defined as an involuntary response shown by body in response to a sudden stimuli.

Q25: A protruding part of the throat that is responsible for growing voice box in boys is called:

Source: RRB NTPC 11.04.2016 (Shift-I) Stage Ist
Correct! A protruding part of the throat that is responsible for growing voice box in boys is called Adam's apple. At puberty, the voice box or the larynx begins to grow. Boys develop larger voice boxes. The growing voice box in boys can be seen as a protruding part of the throat called Adam's apple. The larynx, commonly called the voice box or glottis, is the passageway for air between the pharynx above and the trachea below. The larynx plays an essential role in human speech. The thyroid cartilage is the Adam's apple. The epiglottis acts like a trap door to keep food and other particles from entering the larynx.
Incorrect. A protruding part of the throat that is responsible for growing voice box in boys is called Adam's apple. At puberty, the voice box or the larynx begins to grow. Boys develop larger voice boxes. The growing voice box in boys can be seen as a protruding part of the throat called Adam's apple. The larynx, commonly called the voice box or glottis, is the passageway for air between the pharynx above and the trachea below. The larynx plays an essential role in human speech. The thyroid cartilage is the Adam's apple. The epiglottis acts like a trap door to keep food and other particles from entering the larynx.

Q26: The secretion of bile in human occurs in -

Source: RRB J.E. (14.12.2014, Green paper)
Correct! Bile secreted by the hepatic cells of liver, passes through the hepatic ducts and is stored and concentrated in a thin muscular sac called gall bladder. Bile is made up of essential acids for digestion, absorption and the breaking down of fats. Bile secretion in stomach is caused due to reflex actions.
Incorrect. Bile secreted by the hepatic cells of liver, passes through the hepatic ducts and is stored and concentrated in a thin muscular sac called gall bladder. Bile is made up of essential acids for digestion, absorption and the breaking down of fats. Bile secretion in stomach is caused due to reflex actions.

Q27: Which of the following acids does our stomach produce that helps in digestion?

Source: RRB NTPC 23.07.2021 (Shift-I) Stage Ist
Correct! Hydrochloric acid is produced in the stomach which help in he digestion of food. The hydrochloric acid in the gastric juice breaks down the food and the digestive enzymes split up the proteins. Hydrochloric acid contributes to protein digestion by supplying HCl which activates pepsinogen, the precursor to pepsin. HCl activates the enzyme pepsin which aids in the digestion of proteins by breaking amio acid bonds and it breaks up connective tissues and plant cell walls.
Incorrect. Hydrochloric acid is produced in the stomach which help in he digestion of food. The hydrochloric acid in the gastric juice breaks down the food and the digestive enzymes split up the proteins. Hydrochloric acid contributes to protein digestion by supplying HCl which activates pepsinogen, the precursor to pepsin. HCl activates the enzyme pepsin which aids in the digestion of proteins by breaking amio acid bonds and it breaks up connective tissues and plant cell walls.

Q28: Bile is secreted from:

Source: RRB SSE (21.12.2014, Set-08, Green paper)
Correct! Bile releases through the liver. Bile kills harmful germs present in food. The organic salts present in the bile alkaline the food coming from the stomach, so that the pancreatic juice can function.
Incorrect. Bile releases through the liver. Bile kills harmful germs present in food. The organic salts present in the bile alkaline the food coming from the stomach, so that the pancreatic juice can function.

Q29: Which of the following animals has a comparatively long intestine?

Source: RRB ALP & Tec. (14-08-18 Shift-II)
Correct! The rabbit has a comparatively long intestine among given animals. Herbivores animals have small intestine larger than that of carnivorous animals because herbivores digest cellulose completely and cellulose digestion takes longer time.
Incorrect. The rabbit has a comparatively long intestine among given animals. Herbivores animals have small intestine larger than that of carnivorous animals because herbivores digest cellulose completely and cellulose digestion takes longer time.

Q30: Tooth decay starts when pH of the mouth is lower than ………. .

Source: RRB ALP & Tec. (09-08-18 Shift-III)
Correct! When the pH of the mouth falls below 5.5, tooth decay starts. Bacteria present in the mouth produce acid by degradation of sugar and food particles which remain in the mouth after eating. The acid produced in the mouth attack the enamel thereby, creating tooth decay. RRB Science Planner Biology YCT 537
Incorrect. When the pH of the mouth falls below 5.5, tooth decay starts. Bacteria present in the mouth produce acid by degradation of sugar and food particles which remain in the mouth after eating. The acid produced in the mouth attack the enamel thereby, creating tooth decay. RRB Science Planner Biology YCT 537

Q31: What are the receptors for detecting taste called?

Source: RRB ALP & Tec. (09-08-18 Shift-III)
Correct! The receptors for detecting taste are called Gustatory receptors. Taste buds contain the taste receptor cells, which are also known as gustatory cells.
Incorrect. The receptors for detecting taste are called Gustatory receptors. Taste buds contain the taste receptor cells, which are also known as gustatory cells.

Q32: Among the following, ............. generate maximum amount of energy on oxidation.

Source: RRB J.E. (14.12.2014, Green paper)
Correct! Fat is the main food that provides energy to the body. Fats are the slowest source of energy but the most energy-efficient form of food. Fats are complex molecules composed of fatty acids and glycerol. Each gram of fat supplies the body with about 9.3 grams of energy after complete oxidation. An adult should attain 20 - 30% energy from fat.
Incorrect. Fat is the main food that provides energy to the body. Fats are the slowest source of energy but the most energy-efficient form of food. Fats are complex molecules composed of fatty acids and glycerol. Each gram of fat supplies the body with about 9.3 grams of energy after complete oxidation. An adult should attain 20 - 30% energy from fat.

Q33: Complete digestion of carbohydrates, proteins and fats takes place in :

Source: RRB ALP & Tec. (29-08-18 Shift-I)
Correct! Small intestinal wall have digestive glands which secrete intestinal juice. There are some digestive enzymes present in intestinal juices, such as erepsin, enterokinase, lipase, sucrose, maltase, lactase etc. Carbohydrates, fats, proteins and other nutrients are digested completely in small intestine through these digestive enzymes. The intestinal epithelial cells also have finger-like projections, which are known as microvilli that absorb digested food.
Incorrect. Small intestinal wall have digestive glands which secrete intestinal juice. There are some digestive enzymes present in intestinal juices, such as erepsin, enterokinase, lipase, sucrose, maltase, lactase etc. Carbohydrates, fats, proteins and other nutrients are digested completely in small intestine through these digestive enzymes. The intestinal epithelial cells also have finger-like projections, which are known as microvilli that absorb digested food.

Q34: Which of the following is NOT a correct statement?

Source: RRB NTPC 06.04.2021 (Shift-I) Stage Ist
Correct! Cells of liver secretes bile juice which is collected in gall bladder. Islets of Langerhans of pancreas help in the secretion of insulin from beta cells. It controls and regulates the metabolism of carbohydrates.
Incorrect. Cells of liver secretes bile juice which is collected in gall bladder. Islets of Langerhans of pancreas help in the secretion of insulin from beta cells. It controls and regulates the metabolism of carbohydrates.

Q35: Which organ in the human body produces bile juice?

Source: RRB NTPC 04.01.2021 (Shift-I) Stage Ist
Correct! Liver produces a digestive juice called bile. The gallbladder stores bile. When a person eat meals, the gallbladder squeezes bile through the bile ducts, which connect the gallbladder and liver to the small intestine
Incorrect. Liver produces a digestive juice called bile. The gallbladder stores bile. When a person eat meals, the gallbladder squeezes bile through the bile ducts, which connect the gallbladder and liver to the small intestine

Q36: The presence of Coliform in drinking water supply is a symptom of ……….

Source: RRB NTPC Stage Ist 30.04.2016 (Shift-III)
Correct! The presence of Coliform in the drinking water supply is a symptom of contamination from human waste (faeces-urine), which is specifically determined by the presence of E. coli. When polluted water is used for drinking or cooking, it can cause waterborne diseases such as cholera, diarrhea, typhoid, amoebiasis and jaundice.
Incorrect. The presence of Coliform in the drinking water supply is a symptom of contamination from human waste (faeces-urine), which is specifically determined by the presence of E. coli. When polluted water is used for drinking or cooking, it can cause waterborne diseases such as cholera, diarrhea, typhoid, amoebiasis and jaundice.

Q37: Metabolism is related to - (I) All chemical reactions involved in the body (II) Synthesis of complex molecules from simple molecules (III) Anabolism and catabolism

Source: RRB NTPC Stage Ist 29.04.2016 (Shift-III)
Correct! Metabolism is the set of chemical reactions that occur in living organisms. These processes help organisms to grow and reproduce, maintain their homeostasis and respond to their environment changes. It involves the synthesis of complex molecules from simple molecules. Metabolism is the sum of all of the chemical reactions that are involved in catabolism and anabolism. The reactions governing the breakdown of food to obtain energy are called catabolic reactions, while anabolic reactions involve the joining of smaller molecules into larger ones in contrast of catabolic reactions.
Incorrect. Metabolism is the set of chemical reactions that occur in living organisms. These processes help organisms to grow and reproduce, maintain their homeostasis and respond to their environment changes. It involves the synthesis of complex molecules from simple molecules. Metabolism is the sum of all of the chemical reactions that are involved in catabolism and anabolism. The reactions governing the breakdown of food to obtain energy are called catabolic reactions, while anabolic reactions involve the joining of smaller molecules into larger ones in contrast of catabolic reactions.

Q38: In which part of the body is bile juice produced?

Source: RRB NTPC 18.04.2016 (Shift-III) Stage Ist
Correct! Bile juice is produced from the liver and it is stored in the gall bladder.
Incorrect. Bile juice is produced from the liver and it is stored in the gall bladder.

Q40: The instrument used to examine human digestive system is called -

Source: RRB NTPC Stage Ist 27.04.2016 (Shift-II)
Correct! The endoscope instrument is used to examine the internal organs of the body. An oscilloscope is an electronic device that displays a voltage in the form of a graph relative to time or voltage.In fact, an oscilloscope is a sophisticated diagnostic instrument that draws a graph of an electrical signal. A microscope is an instrument used to see micro objects that are too small to be seen by the naked eye. Radiography is an imaging technique using X-rays, gamma rays, or similar ionizing radiation and non-ionizing radiation to view the internal form of an object. RRB Science Planner Biology YCT 538
Incorrect. The endoscope instrument is used to examine the internal organs of the body. An oscilloscope is an electronic device that displays a voltage in the form of a graph relative to time or voltage.In fact, an oscilloscope is a sophisticated diagnostic instrument that draws a graph of an electrical signal. A microscope is an instrument used to see micro objects that are too small to be seen by the naked eye. Radiography is an imaging technique using X-rays, gamma rays, or similar ionizing radiation and non-ionizing radiation to view the internal form of an object. RRB Science Planner Biology YCT 538

Q41: Which of the following is NOT a part of the alimentary canal of the human body?

Source: RRB NTPC 27.02.2021 (Shift-I) Stage Ist
Correct! The alimentary canal is mainly referred to as the pathway by which food enters our body and moves out through the anus after digestion. The alimentary tract of the digestive system is composed of the mouth, pharynx, oesophagus, stomach, small and large intestines, rectum and anus. The trachea, commonly known as the windpipe, is a part of the airway system that connects the larynx to the bronchi of the lungs.
Incorrect. The alimentary canal is mainly referred to as the pathway by which food enters our body and moves out through the anus after digestion. The alimentary tract of the digestive system is composed of the mouth, pharynx, oesophagus, stomach, small and large intestines, rectum and anus. The trachea, commonly known as the windpipe, is a part of the airway system that connects the larynx to the bronchi of the lungs.

Q42: Which of the following is not a part of the digestive system?

Source: RRB JE 31.05.2019 (Shift-IV)
Correct! The heart is not a part of the digestive system.
Incorrect. The heart is not a part of the digestive system.

Q43: Which of the following has homodont teeth?

Source: RRB NTPC Stage Ist 29.04.2016 (Shift-I)
Correct! In mammals, teeth are diphyodont, thecodont and heterodont while fishes have acrodont and homodont teeth.
Incorrect. In mammals, teeth are diphyodont, thecodont and heterodont while fishes have acrodont and homodont teeth.

Q44: Duodenum is part of……… .

Source: RRB NTPC Stage Ist 26.04.2016 (Shift-I)
Correct! The duodenum is a U-shaped or horseshoe- shaped structure that lies in the upper abdomen near the midline. The small intestine is made up of the duodenum, jejunum, and ileum. Duodenum is about 25 cm (10 inches) long; the jejunum is about 2.5 m (8 feet) long and the ileum is about 3.6 m (12 feet) long. The small intestine is the largest part of the alimentary canal. Complete digestion takes place in this section of alimentary canal. It is about 6.5 metres long and 2.5 meters wide in an adult man.
Incorrect. The duodenum is a U-shaped or horseshoe- shaped structure that lies in the upper abdomen near the midline. The small intestine is made up of the duodenum, jejunum, and ileum. Duodenum is about 25 cm (10 inches) long; the jejunum is about 2.5 m (8 feet) long and the ileum is about 3.6 m (12 feet) long. The small intestine is the largest part of the alimentary canal. Complete digestion takes place in this section of alimentary canal. It is about 6.5 metres long and 2.5 meters wide in an adult man.

Q45: Which of the following organs of the digestive system has the similar shape to the English alphabet "J"?

Source: RRB NTPC 13.03.2021 (Shift-II) Stage Ist
Correct! The stomach is a J-shaped organ in the upper belly (abdomen). It's part of the digestive system. It is between the end of the food pipe (esophagus) and the start of the first part of the small intestine of bowel (duodenum).
Incorrect. The stomach is a J-shaped organ in the upper belly (abdomen). It's part of the digestive system. It is between the end of the food pipe (esophagus) and the start of the first part of the small intestine of bowel (duodenum).

Q46: The inner walls of the small intestine have thousands of finger-like out growth. These are called:

Source: RRB NTPC 07.03.2021 (Shift-I) Stage Ist
Correct! Villi are the tiny projections on the inner surface of the small intestine which help in absorbing the digested food. These villi help to increase the surface area of intestinal walls. Many blood vessels are present within these villi, that help in the absorption of digested food and carry it to the bloodstream. Later, from the bloodstream, the absorbed food is delivered to each and every cell of the body.
Incorrect. Villi are the tiny projections on the inner surface of the small intestine which help in absorbing the digested food. These villi help to increase the surface area of intestinal walls. Many blood vessels are present within these villi, that help in the absorption of digested food and carry it to the bloodstream. Later, from the bloodstream, the absorbed food is delivered to each and every cell of the body.

Q47: Where in the body is villi found?

Source: RRB NTPC 09.02.2021 (Shift-I) Stage Ist
Correct! See the explanation of the above question.
Incorrect. See the explanation of the above question.

Q48: The gastric juice present in digestive system, includes ……… .

Source: RRB NTPC Stage Ist 26.04.2016 (Shift-I)
Correct! Gastric glands are located in the mucosa of the stomach.There are mainly three types of cells in gastric glands: (a) Mucous neck cells secrete mucous. (b) Chief cells are responsible for secretion of proenzyme Pepsinogen and prore nin (c) Parietal or oxyntic cells are responsible for the production of hydrochloric acid, which is necessary to activate the other enzymes.
Incorrect. Gastric glands are located in the mucosa of the stomach.There are mainly three types of cells in gastric glands: (a) Mucous neck cells secrete mucous. (b) Chief cells are responsible for secretion of proenzyme Pepsinogen and prore nin (c) Parietal or oxyntic cells are responsible for the production of hydrochloric acid, which is necessary to activate the other enzymes.

Q49: Which acid is produced by human's stomach?

Source: RRB NTPC 17.01.2021 (Shift-II) Stage Ist
Correct! Hydrochloric Acid (HCl) is produced by the parietal cells of the stomach. To begin with, water (H2O) and carbon dioxide (CO2) combine within the parietal cell cytoplasm to produce carbonic acid (H2CO3). The stomach is a gastrointestinal organ that is responsible for preliminary digestion.
Incorrect. Hydrochloric Acid (HCl) is produced by the parietal cells of the stomach. To begin with, water (H2O) and carbon dioxide (CO2) combine within the parietal cell cytoplasm to produce carbonic acid (H2CO3). The stomach is a gastrointestinal organ that is responsible for preliminary digestion.

Q50: What is the tooth enamel made of?

Source: RRB NTPC Stage Ist 22.04.2016 (Shift-III)
Correct! The tooth enamel is made of calcium phosphate. All teeth have three layers: enamel, dentine, and pulp. The enamel is the outermost layer and is primarily made of calcium phosphate minerals. Enamel is the hardest substance in the human body, but it does not grow back once it’s lost.
Incorrect. The tooth enamel is made of calcium phosphate. All teeth have three layers: enamel, dentine, and pulp. The enamel is the outermost layer and is primarily made of calcium phosphate minerals. Enamel is the hardest substance in the human body, but it does not grow back once it’s lost.

Q51: What is a tooth enamel made of?

Source: RRB Group-D 24-10-2018 (Shift-I)
Correct! See the explanation of the above question.
Incorrect. See the explanation of the above question.

Q52: Our enamel is made of .............. .

Correct! See the explanation of the above question.
Incorrect. See the explanation of the above question.

Q53: Which acid is used to aid digestion in the body?

Source: RRB NTPC 10.04.2016 (Shift-III) Stage Ist
Correct! Hydrochloric acid is used to aid digestion in the body. Hydrochloric acid combines with other gastric juices in the stomach to aid digestion as well as protect us from disease by killing germs found in foods.
Incorrect. Hydrochloric acid is used to aid digestion in the body. Hydrochloric acid combines with other gastric juices in the stomach to aid digestion as well as protect us from disease by killing germs found in foods.

Q54: Which one of the following is the largest compartment of stomach in hoofed animals?

Source: RRB NTPC 13.03.2021 (Shift-II) Stage Ist
Correct! Rumen (on the left side of the animal) is the largest stomach compartment and consists of several sacs in hoofed animals.
Incorrect. Rumen (on the left side of the animal) is the largest stomach compartment and consists of several sacs in hoofed animals.

Q55: Name an enzyme used for the conversion of proteins into a peptide.

Source: RRB NTPC 15.02.2021 (Shift-I) Stage Ist
Correct! When digestive system of body fails to produce enough of enzymes for digestion process, then in this case "pepsin" enzyme helps in the process of digestion. It is a type of enzyme released by the main cells in the stomach. Its main function is to convert protein into peptide.
Incorrect. When digestive system of body fails to produce enough of enzymes for digestion process, then in this case "pepsin" enzyme helps in the process of digestion. It is a type of enzyme released by the main cells in the stomach. Its main function is to convert protein into peptide.

Q56: What protects the inner lining of the stomach from the action of acid, under normal conditions?

Source: RRB NTPC 05.01.2021 (Shift-I) Stage Ist
Correct! Mucus protects the inner lining of the stomach from the action of the acid under normal conditions. The digestion in stomach is taken care of by the gastric glands present in the wall of the stomach. They release hydrochloric acid, a protein digesting enzyme called pepsin, and mucus.
Incorrect. Mucus protects the inner lining of the stomach from the action of the acid under normal conditions. The digestion in stomach is taken care of by the gastric glands present in the wall of the stomach. They release hydrochloric acid, a protein digesting enzyme called pepsin, and mucus.

Q57: How is energy measured obtained by food?

Source: RRB NTPC 18.04.2016 (Shift-I) Stage Ist
Correct! Energy obtained from food is measured in terms of calories. First of all, Professor Nicholas Clement defined calorie as a unit of energy in 1824 AD. To increase the temperature of 1 gram of water by 1 degree Celsius, 1 calorie of heat is required.
Incorrect. Energy obtained from food is measured in terms of calories. First of all, Professor Nicholas Clement defined calorie as a unit of energy in 1824 AD. To increase the temperature of 1 gram of water by 1 degree Celsius, 1 calorie of heat is required.

Q58: The only part of the human body that can be re-developed / regenerated?

Source: RRB NTPC 29.03.2016 (Shift-I) Stage Ist
Correct! The only part of the human body that can be re-developed and regenerated, is liver . The liver is the largest gland in the body, weighing from 1.5–2.0 kg. Bile is secreted by the liver.
Incorrect. The only part of the human body that can be re-developed and regenerated, is liver . The liver is the largest gland in the body, weighing from 1.5–2.0 kg. Bile is secreted by the liver.

Q59: In the human body, what is called a throat?

Source: RRB NTPC 31.03.2016 (Shift-I) Stage Ist
Correct! The throat is known as voice box in human body.The throat is a ring-like muscular tube that acts as the passageway for air, food and liquid. It is located behind the nose and mouth and connects the mouth (oral cavity) and nose to the breathing passages (trachea and lungs) and the esophagus.
Incorrect. The throat is known as voice box in human body.The throat is a ring-like muscular tube that acts as the passageway for air, food and liquid. It is located behind the nose and mouth and connects the mouth (oral cavity) and nose to the breathing passages (trachea and lungs) and the esophagus.

Q60: On average, how many taste buds are present in an human tongue?

Source: RRB NTPC 02.04.2016 (Shift-II) Stage Ist
Correct! Tounge is an essential part of the body of most animals. The taste buds are embedded in the epithelium of the tongue and make contact with the outside environment through a taste pore. On average, the human tongue has 2,000–8,000 taste buds, implying that there are hundreds of thousands of receptor cells.
Incorrect. Tounge is an essential part of the body of most animals. The taste buds are embedded in the epithelium of the tongue and make contact with the outside environment through a taste pore. On average, the human tongue has 2,000–8,000 taste buds, implying that there are hundreds of thousands of receptor cells.

Q61: The entire digestive system of an adult human is ………….. meter long from mouth to anus.

Source: RRB NTPC 05.04.2016 (Shift-III) Stage Ist
Correct! The complete digestive system of an adult human is 9 meters long from mouth to anus.
Incorrect. The complete digestive system of an adult human is 9 meters long from mouth to anus.

Q62: Which receptors are located on our tongue?

Source: RRB NTPC 10.01.2021 (Shift-I) Stage Ist
Correct! Gustatory receptors are preseent on the tongue which spread evenly across the taste buds. Their main function is to provide a sense of taste. It is significant that, olfactory receptors are present on the surface of the olfactory neurons. Their main function is to sense smell.
Incorrect. Gustatory receptors are preseent on the tongue which spread evenly across the taste buds. Their main function is to provide a sense of taste. It is significant that, olfactory receptors are present on the surface of the olfactory neurons. Their main function is to sense smell.

Incorrect. Ingestion is the process by which food enters in the esophagus. The process of food digestion involves five stages-

Q65: The process of digestion of food in the humans begins in ______ and is completed in ______.

Source: RRB NTPC 13.03.2021 (Shift-II) Stage Ist
Correct! Digestion begins in the mouth with chewing and ends in the small intestine. As food passes through the gastrointestinal tract, it mixes with digestive juices, causing large molecules of food to break down into smaller molecules. RRB Science Planner Biology YCT 540
Incorrect. Digestion begins in the mouth with chewing and ends in the small intestine. As food passes through the gastrointestinal tract, it mixes with digestive juices, causing large molecules of food to break down into smaller molecules. RRB Science Planner Biology YCT 540

Q66: In reference of food, which among the following statement is false?

Source: RRB NTPC 17.01.2017 (Shift-III) Stage IIst
Correct! Food is an abiotic substance, this statement is false. Food performs chemical reactions, it is a biological substance and provides us energy. Food is a beneficial substance for almost all organisms.
Incorrect. Food is an abiotic substance, this statement is false. Food performs chemical reactions, it is a biological substance and provides us energy. Food is a beneficial substance for almost all organisms.

Q67: The contraction and expansion movements of the walls of the food pipe is called ……… motion.

Source: RRB NTPC Stage Ist 19.01.2017 (Shift-II)
Correct! The contraction and expansion movements of the walls of the food pipe is called peristalsis motion. The teeth cut and crush food, and the pieces are mixed with saliva to form a ball of food called a bolus. This is then swallowed and is carried down the esophagus by peristalsis, as muscles work together to produce wave- like contractions.
Incorrect. The contraction and expansion movements of the walls of the food pipe is called peristalsis motion. The teeth cut and crush food, and the pieces are mixed with saliva to form a ball of food called a bolus. This is then swallowed and is carried down the esophagus by peristalsis, as muscles work together to produce wave- like contractions.

Q68: In the human body, the digestion of fats mainly occurs in :

Source: RRB NTPC 03.04.2021 (Shift-II) Stage Ist
Correct! The majority of fat digestion happens once it reaches the small intestine. This is also where the majority of nutrients are absorbed. Pancreas produces enzymes that break down fats, carbohydrates, and proteins. Liver produces bile that helps digest fats and certain vitamins.
Incorrect. The majority of fat digestion happens once it reaches the small intestine. This is also where the majority of nutrients are absorbed. Pancreas produces enzymes that break down fats, carbohydrates, and proteins. Liver produces bile that helps digest fats and certain vitamins.

Q69: Which of the following is not a part of human alimentary canal?

Source: RRB Group-D 23-10-2018 (Shift-III)
Correct! The oral cavity, gall bladder, large intestine, liver, pancreas are part of the human alimentary canal, while alveoli are found in the lungs and part of the respiratory system.
Incorrect. The oral cavity, gall bladder, large intestine, liver, pancreas are part of the human alimentary canal, while alveoli are found in the lungs and part of the respiratory system.

Q70: Saliva contains ……………. enzyme.

Source: RRB Group-D 25-10-2018 (Shift-II)
Correct! Human saliva contains about 99% water and the remaining 1% enzymes, mainly of two types :Ptyolin and Lysozyme. Ptyalin is also known as amylase that decomposes starch (present in the food) into maltose sugars. An enzyme called lysozyme works by destroying harmful bacteria present in food.
Incorrect. Human saliva contains about 99% water and the remaining 1% enzymes, mainly of two types :Ptyolin and Lysozyme. Ptyalin is also known as amylase that decomposes starch (present in the food) into maltose sugars. An enzyme called lysozyme works by destroying harmful bacteria present in food.

Q71: Enzyme Ptyalin is found in ………… .

Source: RRB JE 28.05.2019 (Shift-I)
Correct! See the explanation of the above question.
Incorrect. See the explanation of the above question.

Q72: After digestion, carbohydrate is converted into -

Source: RRB Group-D 04-12-2018 (Shift-III)
Correct! Digestion of food in humans starts from the mouth. Mouth cavity, alimentary canal, esophagus, stomach etc. take part in digestion. Intestinal juice contains a variety of enzymes that convert complex carbohydrates into glucose, proteins into amino acids, and fats into fatty acids.
Incorrect. Digestion of food in humans starts from the mouth. Mouth cavity, alimentary canal, esophagus, stomach etc. take part in digestion. Intestinal juice contains a variety of enzymes that convert complex carbohydrates into glucose, proteins into amino acids, and fats into fatty acids.

Q73: The function of bile. . . . . . can be called:

Source: RRB Group-D 05-12-2018 (Shift-III)
Correct! The liver is a supportive digestive gland that produces bile. Bile is an alkaline compound, which helps in the breakdown of fats. During emulsification of lipids, bile attaches to lipids indigestion.
Incorrect. The liver is a supportive digestive gland that produces bile. Bile is an alkaline compound, which helps in the breakdown of fats. During emulsification of lipids, bile attaches to lipids indigestion.

Q74: The ……….. enzyme present in pancreatic juice, converts proteins into amino acids.

Source: RRB Group-D 22-09-2018 (Shift-III)
Correct! All enzymes present in pancreatic juice are in inactive state. Trypsinogen, chymotrypsinogen, procarboxy peptidase, amylase, lipase, and nuclease. Trypsinogen enzyme are activated by enterokinase which is secreted by intestinal mucosa and converts trypsinogen to active trypsin. Trypsin activates all enzymes present in pancreatic juice. Proteins, peptones, proteases, Trypsin → dipeptides
Incorrect. All enzymes present in pancreatic juice are in inactive state. Trypsinogen, chymotrypsinogen, procarboxy peptidase, amylase, lipase, and nuclease. Trypsinogen enzyme are activated by enterokinase which is secreted by intestinal mucosa and converts trypsinogen to active trypsin. Trypsin activates all enzymes present in pancreatic juice. Proteins, peptones, proteases, Trypsin → dipeptides

Q75: During digestion, the role of bile is…….. .

Source: RRB Group-D 24-09-2018 (Shift-III)
Correct! During digestion, the role of bile is emulsification of fat.
Incorrect. During digestion, the role of bile is emulsification of fat.

Q76: Which acid is excreted in the digestive system of humans?

Source: RRB Group-D 24-10-2018 (Shift-II)
Correct! Hydrochloric acid (HCl) is excreted in the digestive system of human. Oxyntic cells of the stomach secrete HCl which inhibits the action of ptyalin and makes food acidic. It kills the harmful bacteria of food and stimulates enzymes to act on food.
Incorrect. Hydrochloric acid (HCl) is excreted in the digestive system of human. Oxyntic cells of the stomach secrete HCl which inhibits the action of ptyalin and makes food acidic. It kills the harmful bacteria of food and stimulates enzymes to act on food.

Q77: .................rings are present in throat.

Source: RRB Group-D 25-09-2018 (Shift-II)
Correct! Cartilage is a flexible connective tissue found in the human body and other animals. It is made up of chondrocytes cells present in our marrow. Ear bone, nose bone, throat bone, joints of bones etc. are made of cartilages. Cartilages strengthen the tissues of the body. It also makes our body joints flexible. Due to its presence, many parts of our body work smoothly.
Incorrect. Cartilage is a flexible connective tissue found in the human body and other animals. It is made up of chondrocytes cells present in our marrow. Ear bone, nose bone, throat bone, joints of bones etc. are made of cartilages. Cartilages strengthen the tissues of the body. It also makes our body joints flexible. Due to its presence, many parts of our body work smoothly.

Q78: ........ enzyme is secreted from the salivary gland.

Source: RRB Group-D 25-09-2018 (Shift-I)
Correct! Saliva secretes from salivary glands of the mouth. Saliva contains amylase enzyme that breaks down starch into sugars. Thus, the digestion of food starts from the mouth.
Incorrect. Saliva secretes from salivary glands of the mouth. Saliva contains amylase enzyme that breaks down starch into sugars. Thus, the digestion of food starts from the mouth.

Q79: The bile juice is secreted from ……… in human digestive system. -

Source: RRB Group-D 24-09-2018 (Shift-I)
Correct! The liver is the largest gland in the human body. The liver secretes bile juice. It is alkaline in nature. It contains water, bile salts, cholesterol, pigment cells. Its pH is 7.7.
Incorrect. The liver is the largest gland in the human body. The liver secretes bile juice. It is alkaline in nature. It contains water, bile salts, cholesterol, pigment cells. Its pH is 7.7.

Q80: Describe the type of energy conversion that occurs during the process of digestion of food.

Source: RRB Group-D 28-11-2018 (Shift-I)
Correct! The energy conversion that occurs during the process of food digestion, is from chemical energy to heat energy.
Incorrect. The energy conversion that occurs during the process of food digestion, is from chemical energy to heat energy.

Q81: Herbivore requires longer small intestine to digest .......

Source: RRB Group-D 28-11-2018 (Shift-I)
Correct! Herbivore needs longer small intestine called cecum to digest cellulose. Cellulose is an organic compound in which monomers combine to form a polymer of thousand molecules. The cell walls of many green plants are made up of cellulose. 90 percent portion of the cotton fibre is cellulose.
Incorrect. Herbivore needs longer small intestine called cecum to digest cellulose. Cellulose is an organic compound in which monomers combine to form a polymer of thousand molecules. The cell walls of many green plants are made up of cellulose. 90 percent portion of the cotton fibre is cellulose.

Q82: The common track for food and air in humans:

Source: RRB Group-D 05-11-2018 (Shift-III)
Correct! The pharynx is the common track for both food and air. The pharynx opens into the trachea by the throat. The throat is a cartilaginous box that helps in voice production. Hence, it is also called voice box.
Incorrect. The pharynx is the common track for both food and air. The pharynx opens into the trachea by the throat. The throat is a cartilaginous box that helps in voice production. Hence, it is also called voice box.

Q83: Tooth enamel, made of ………., is degraded by acid, causing tooth decay.

Source: RRB Group-D 03-12-2018 (Shift-III)
Correct! Tooth enamel, made of calcium phosphate, is degraded by acid, causing tooth decay. Low pH levels can cause tooth decay. Teeth begin to decay, when the pH value of enamel is less than 5.5.
Incorrect. Tooth enamel, made of calcium phosphate, is degraded by acid, causing tooth decay. Low pH levels can cause tooth decay. Teeth begin to decay, when the pH value of enamel is less than 5.5.

Q84: The liver performs……… functions.

Source: RRB Group-D 15-11-2018 (Shift-III)
Correct! The liver is the largest gland in the human body, which produces bile. Bile enters into duodenum and gallbladder by the hepatic duct system and the bile duct. This is the main place of metabolism of the intestinal juice absorbed in the digestive system. The liver performs digestive functions. The liver performs more than 300 different functions of the human body; storing glycogen (fuel for the body) made from glucose, helping to translocate fats and proteins from digested food. The liver also functions to make blood in the fetus, converts carbohydrates and proteins into fat.
Incorrect. The liver is the largest gland in the human body, which produces bile. Bile enters into duodenum and gallbladder by the hepatic duct system and the bile duct. This is the main place of metabolism of the intestinal juice absorbed in the digestive system. The liver performs digestive functions. The liver performs more than 300 different functions of the human body; storing glycogen (fuel for the body) made from glucose, helping to translocate fats and proteins from digested food. The liver also functions to make blood in the fetus, converts carbohydrates and proteins into fat.

Q85: Herbivore requires longer small intestine to digest .............. .

Source: RRB Group-D 20-09-2018 (Shift-II)
Correct! The small intestine is an important part of human digestive system that starts from stomach and completes at large intestine. Digestion and absorption of food takes place in the small intestine . Cellulose is a component of plants that is non- digestable compoenent for human body. Cellulose is an insoluble fibre that needs longer small intestine for digestion in herbivores
Incorrect. The small intestine is an important part of human digestive system that starts from stomach and completes at large intestine. Digestion and absorption of food takes place in the small intestine . Cellulose is a component of plants that is non- digestable compoenent for human body. Cellulose is an insoluble fibre that needs longer small intestine for digestion in herbivores

Q86: What is the unit of measurement used for measuring the energy requirements of the human body?

Source: RRB NTPC 09.03.2021 (Shift-II) Stage Ist
Correct! A calorie is a unit of measurement of energy. Very specifically, it is the amount of energy that is required to raise the temperature of one ml, (which is also one gram), of water by one degree celsius. The word calorie was actually coined by the great French Chemist Nicolas Clement who used it to refer to the body’s internal heat. A food calorie is actually a “kilocalorie”. In other words it is the amount of energy needed to raise the temperature of one litre of water by one degree. Originally, the calorie content of a food was measured in a calorimeter.
Incorrect. A calorie is a unit of measurement of energy. Very specifically, it is the amount of energy that is required to raise the temperature of one ml, (which is also one gram), of water by one degree celsius. The word calorie was actually coined by the great French Chemist Nicolas Clement who used it to refer to the body’s internal heat. A food calorie is actually a “kilocalorie”. In other words it is the amount of energy needed to raise the temperature of one litre of water by one degree. Originally, the calorie content of a food was measured in a calorimeter.

Q87: Which is the only muscle found in human body that is not connected at both ends?

Source: RRB JE 24.05.2019 (Shift-IV)
Correct! Tongue is the only muscle found in the human body that is not connected at both ends.
Incorrect. Tongue is the only muscle found in the human body that is not connected at both ends.

Q88: Some functions of lymph are given below. Select the option with the correct functions.

Source: RRB Group-D 30-08-2022 (Shift-I)
Correct! Lymph performs many important functions. It keeps the body cells moist. It transports oxygen, hormones and nutrients to different parts of the body and removes metabolic waste from the cells. It transports antibodies and lymphocytes to the blood. Maintaining the composition of tissue fluid and the volume of blood. Absorption of fats from the small intestine occurs through lymphatic vessels. Prevents invasion of microbes and foreign substances inside the lymph nodes.
Incorrect. Lymph performs many important functions. It keeps the body cells moist. It transports oxygen, hormones and nutrients to different parts of the body and removes metabolic waste from the cells. It transports antibodies and lymphocytes to the blood. Maintaining the composition of tissue fluid and the volume of blood. Absorption of fats from the small intestine occurs through lymphatic vessels. Prevents invasion of microbes and foreign substances inside the lymph nodes.

Q89: Which of the following events takes place during diastole in the human heart?

Source: RRB Group-D 18-08-2022 (Shift-II)
Correct! Systole and diastole are two phases of the cardiac cycle. Systole occurs when the heart contracts, while diastole takes place when the heart relaxes after contraction. During diastole, when heart muscle is relaxed, the blood flows freely through the atria and owing to the low pressures in the chambers, it enters into the ventricles.
Incorrect. Systole and diastole are two phases of the cardiac cycle. Systole occurs when the heart contracts, while diastole takes place when the heart relaxes after contraction. During diastole, when heart muscle is relaxed, the blood flows freely through the atria and owing to the low pressures in the chambers, it enters into the ventricles.

Q90: Why is deoxygenated blood kept separate from oxygenated blood in the hearts of some animals like human beings?

Source: RRB Group-D 14-09-2022 (Shift-I)
Correct! To help in keeping the body temperature constant deoxygenated blood is kept separate from oxygenated blood in the hearts of some animals like human beings.
Incorrect. To help in keeping the body temperature constant deoxygenated blood is kept separate from oxygenated blood in the hearts of some animals like human beings.

Q91: Which of the following carry/carries digested and absorbed fat from the intestine?

Source: RRB Group-D 14-09-2022 (Shift-I)
Correct! Lymph is a clear to white fluid made of white blood cells especially lymphocytes. It digest and absorb fat from the intestine.
Incorrect. Lymph is a clear to white fluid made of white blood cells especially lymphocytes. It digest and absorb fat from the intestine.

Q92: The respiratory pigment, hemoglobin is present in:

Source: RRB Group-D 11-10-2022 (Shift-II)
Correct! The respiratory pigment, hemoglobin is present in the red blood corpuscles. (RBC) Hemoglobin (Hb) is a protein that carry oxygen in the blood and gives red colour to the blood.
Incorrect. The respiratory pigment, hemoglobin is present in the red blood corpuscles. (RBC) Hemoglobin (Hb) is a protein that carry oxygen in the blood and gives red colour to the blood.

Q93: Which of the following is required for the formation of human blood?

Source: RRB Group-D 11-10-2022 (Shift-I)
Correct! Red blood cells contain a form of globular protein called hemoglobin. Iron is needed for the formation of hemoglobin & is a part of red blood cells that carry oxygen and remove carbon dioxide from the body. Iron deficiency causes anemia.
Incorrect. Red blood cells contain a form of globular protein called hemoglobin. Iron is needed for the formation of hemoglobin & is a part of red blood cells that carry oxygen and remove carbon dioxide from the body. Iron deficiency causes anemia.

Q94: Which blood group is referred to as the 'Universal Donor'?

Source: RRB Group-D 30-08-2022 (Shift-III)
Correct! A universal donor is a person who can donate blood to any recipient of any blood group. Although people with an O blood type are commonly known as universal blood donors, people with O–(negative) blood type are the true universal donors.
Incorrect. A universal donor is a person who can donate blood to any recipient of any blood group. Although people with an O blood type are commonly known as universal blood donors, people with O–(negative) blood type are the true universal donors.

Q95: Which of the following vessels carries blood away from the heart to various organs of the body, except the lungs?

Source: RRB Group-D 11-10-2022 (Shift-III)
Correct! The Aorta is the major blood vessel that carries blood away from the heart to the rest of the body except the lung. The blood leaves the heart through the aortic valve. It travels through the Aorta, making a cane shaped curve that allows other major arteries to deliver oxygen rich blood to the brain, muscles and other cells.
Incorrect. The Aorta is the major blood vessel that carries blood away from the heart to the rest of the body except the lung. The blood leaves the heart through the aortic valve. It travels through the Aorta, making a cane shaped curve that allows other major arteries to deliver oxygen rich blood to the brain, muscles and other cells.

Q96: What aids in preventing the mixing of oxygen- rich and carbon dioxide-rich blood in the heart?

Source: RRB Group-D 24-08-2022 (Shift-III)
Correct! There is a special feature known as the septum present in the human heart which does not allow the mixing of blood and acts as dividing wall that present between the left side and right side of the heart. With the division of the heart into four parts the septum is also known by two names one is inter-atrial and other is an inter-ventricular septum which contains deoxygenated and oxygenated blood respectively. RRB Science Planner Biology YCT 543
Incorrect. There is a special feature known as the septum present in the human heart which does not allow the mixing of blood and acts as dividing wall that present between the left side and right side of the heart. With the division of the heart into four parts the septum is also known by two names one is inter-atrial and other is an inter-ventricular septum which contains deoxygenated and oxygenated blood respectively. RRB Science Planner Biology YCT 543

Q97: Where is the respiratory pigment in human body present?

Source: RRB Group-D 24-08-2022 (Shift-II)
Correct! The respiratory pigment in human body is present in red blood cells. A respiratory pigment is substances that enhance the capacity of blood to carry oxygen Hemoglobin is the respiratory pigment and it is present in RBCs.
Incorrect. The respiratory pigment in human body is present in red blood cells. A respiratory pigment is substances that enhance the capacity of blood to carry oxygen Hemoglobin is the respiratory pigment and it is present in RBCs.

Q98: The diagram below shows the different types of white blood cells. Identify the option with correct labelling.

Source: RRB Group-D 24-08-2022 (Shift-II)
Correct! Different type of White Blood cells as given in diagram are a-Neutrophil, b-Eosinophil, c-Basophil, d-Lymphocyte, e-Monocyte. WBC's plays a significant role in protecting the body from infectious disease. That's why they are known as protecting guards of Immune system.
Incorrect. Different type of White Blood cells as given in diagram are a-Neutrophil, b-Eosinophil, c-Basophil, d-Lymphocyte, e-Monocyte. WBC's plays a significant role in protecting the body from infectious disease. That's why they are known as protecting guards of Immune system.

Q99: The normal systolic and diastolic pressure in humans is .............. respectively.

Source: RRB Group-D 23-08-2022 (Shift-II)
Correct! The normal systolic pressure is 120mm Hg while the normal diastolic pressure is 80mm Hg in humans. Now a days due to owing of different lifestyles and entry of different food products in the food chain the pharma and medical giants are considering to extend the systolic and diastolic limit range.
Incorrect. The normal systolic pressure is 120mm Hg while the normal diastolic pressure is 80mm Hg in humans. Now a days due to owing of different lifestyles and entry of different food products in the food chain the pharma and medical giants are considering to extend the systolic and diastolic limit range.

Q103: In which of the following animal does blood go through the heart twice during each cycle?

Source: RRB Group-D 29-09-2022 (Shift-III)
Correct! In mammals, birds and reptiles, blood goes through the heart twice during each cycle. A mechanism in which blood circulates twice through the heart in one complete cycle is known as double circulation.
Incorrect. In mammals, birds and reptiles, blood goes through the heart twice during each cycle. A mechanism in which blood circulates twice through the heart in one complete cycle is known as double circulation.

Q104: Which of the following statements regarding Blood Pressure is FALSE?

Source: RRB Group-D 28-09-2022 (Shift-III)
Correct! The Blood Pressure is measured using a sphygmomanometer. The normal systolic pressure is about 120 mm of Hg and diastolic pressure is 80 mm of Hg. The pressure during ventricular contraction is called systolic pressure and during ventricular relaxation is called diastolic pressure. Unlike arteries veins don't have to carry highly pressurized blood, but they have to carry large volumes of deoxygenated blood back to your heart. RRB Science Planner Biology YCT 544
Incorrect. The Blood Pressure is measured using a sphygmomanometer. The normal systolic pressure is about 120 mm of Hg and diastolic pressure is 80 mm of Hg. The pressure during ventricular contraction is called systolic pressure and during ventricular relaxation is called diastolic pressure. Unlike arteries veins don't have to carry highly pressurized blood, but they have to carry large volumes of deoxygenated blood back to your heart. RRB Science Planner Biology YCT 544

Q105: Which blood cells help in clotting of blood and stop bleeding?

Source: RRB Group-D 28-09-2022 (Shift-II)
Correct! Platelets, or thrombocytes, are small, colorless cell fragments in our blood that form clots and stop or prevent bleeding. Platelets are made in our bone marrow, the sponge like tissue inside our bones.
Incorrect. Platelets, or thrombocytes, are small, colorless cell fragments in our blood that form clots and stop or prevent bleeding. Platelets are made in our bone marrow, the sponge like tissue inside our bones.

Q106: Ravi injured his knee while playing and it was bleeding. After some time, he noticed that the bleeding had stopped and a dark red clot had plugged the wound. Which type of cells help in blood clotting ?

Source: RRB Group-D 28-09-2022 (Shift-II)
Correct! See the explanation of above question.
Incorrect. See the explanation of above question.

Q107: Blood coagulation occurs with the help of :

Source: RRB Group-D– 26/08/2022 (Shift-II)
Correct! See the explanation of above question.
Incorrect. See the explanation of above question.

Q108: Which of the following is similar to the plasma of blood but is colourless and contains less protein?

Source: RRB Group-D– 16/09/2022 (Shift-I)
Correct! Lymph is similar to the plasma of blood but is colourless and contains less protein. Lymph is a clear to white fluid made of White Blood Cells, especially lymphocytes, the cells that attack bacteria in the blood.
Incorrect. Lymph is similar to the plasma of blood but is colourless and contains less protein. Lymph is a clear to white fluid made of White Blood Cells, especially lymphocytes, the cells that attack bacteria in the blood.

Q109: The following figure shows the human heart. LA = left auricle; LV = left ventricle; RA = right auricle; RV = right ventricle. Where are the valves located ?

Source: RRB Group-D– 06/10/2022 (Shift-I)
Correct! At the positions, 2, 3, 4 & 5 the heart valves are located.
Incorrect. At the positions, 2, 3, 4 & 5 the heart valves are located.

Q110: Throbbing movements called pulse is felt due to:

Source: RRB Group-D– 30/09/2022 (Shift-II)
Correct! Throbbing movements called pulse is felt due to blood flowing in the arteries. When the heart pushes blood into the aorta, the blood's impact on the elastic walls create a pressure wave that continues along the arteries. This impact is the pulse.
Incorrect. Throbbing movements called pulse is felt due to blood flowing in the arteries. When the heart pushes blood into the aorta, the blood's impact on the elastic walls create a pressure wave that continues along the arteries. This impact is the pulse.

Q111: Blood coagulation occurs with the help of:

Source: RRB Group-D– 26/09/2022 (Shift-II)
Correct! Blood coagulation occurs with the help of platelet cells. Platelets are much smaller than RBC. They are formed in red bone marrow and are disposed off in spleen. Their life span is about 3 to 5 days. Blood coagulation or clotting results from physical and chemical changes in the blood. When a blood vessel is cut, the platelets disintegrate and release thromboplastin. This reacts with prothrombin to form thrombin which forms fibrin, which traps blood cells and forms clots.
Incorrect. Blood coagulation occurs with the help of platelet cells. Platelets are much smaller than RBC. They are formed in red bone marrow and are disposed off in spleen. Their life span is about 3 to 5 days. Blood coagulation or clotting results from physical and chemical changes in the blood. When a blood vessel is cut, the platelets disintegrate and release thromboplastin. This reacts with prothrombin to form thrombin which forms fibrin, which traps blood cells and forms clots.

Q112: Which of the following options correctly describes the features of arteries ?

Source: RRB Group-D– 08/09/2022 (Shift-III)
Correct! Features of arteries- (i) Located deep in the muscle. (ii) Carry blood from the heart to organs (iii) carry oxygenated blood (iv) Have no valves (except for the pulmonary artery)
Incorrect. Features of arteries- (i) Located deep in the muscle. (ii) Carry blood from the heart to organs (iii) carry oxygenated blood (iv) Have no valves (except for the pulmonary artery)

Q113: Lymph transports digested and absorbed intestinal ______.

Source: RRB Group-D– 08/09/2022 (Shift-II)
Correct! Lymph transports digested and absorbed intestinal fats.
Incorrect. Lymph transports digested and absorbed intestinal fats.

Q114: Which of the following components of blood promotes immunity and helps the body fight against germs ?

Source: RRB Group-D– 06/10/2022 (Shift-II)
Correct! White blood cells (WBC) components of blood promotes immunity and helps the body fight against germs. White blood cells are made in the bone marrow. The lifespan of WBC is around 12 - 20 days. RRB Science Planner Biology YCT 545
Incorrect. White blood cells (WBC) components of blood promotes immunity and helps the body fight against germs. White blood cells are made in the bone marrow. The lifespan of WBC is around 12 - 20 days. RRB Science Planner Biology YCT 545

Q115: The functions of bile juice are mentioned below. Select the option that is NOT the function of bile juice.

Source: RRB Group-D– 09/09/2022 (Shift-II)
Correct! Except option (b) all the functions are performed by the bile juice. Pepsin is a protein digesting enzyme and helps in the digestion of proteins and food. Pepsin is produced in stomach while bile juice is secreted by liver.
Incorrect. Except option (b) all the functions are performed by the bile juice. Pepsin is a protein digesting enzyme and helps in the digestion of proteins and food. Pepsin is produced in stomach while bile juice is secreted by liver.
