Q117: The following diagram shows which component of the human circulatory system?

Source: RRB Group-D– 18/09/2022 (Shift-II)
Correct! The diagram shows vein of the circulatory system. Veins are blood vessels located throughout the body that collect deoxygenated blood and return it to the heart.
Incorrect. The diagram shows vein of the circulatory system. Veins are blood vessels located throughout the body that collect deoxygenated blood and return it to the heart.

Q118: Which of the following pigments has a high affinity for oxygen?

Source: RRB Group-D– 18/09/2022 (Shift-II)
Correct! Hemoglobin pigments has a high affinity with oxygen and carbon monoxide but not with carbon dioxide. Hemoglobin functions as oxygen carrier and myoglobin serves to store oxygen in muscles.
Incorrect. Hemoglobin pigments has a high affinity with oxygen and carbon monoxide but not with carbon dioxide. Hemoglobin functions as oxygen carrier and myoglobin serves to store oxygen in muscles.

Q119: Which of the following is an example of a human cell that has the ability to modify its shape?

Source: RRB Group-D– 17/08/2022 (Shift-III)
Correct! White blood cells (WBC) have the ability to change the shape because white blood cells can squeeze themselves in between other cells, to reach other areas in blood to catch and kill infected cells and harmful viruses etc entered into the blood stream
Incorrect. White blood cells (WBC) have the ability to change the shape because white blood cells can squeeze themselves in between other cells, to reach other areas in blood to catch and kill infected cells and harmful viruses etc entered into the blood stream

Q120: All the veins in the human system carry blood towards the heart. What is the difference between a pulmonary vein and other veins?

Source: RRB Group-D– 05/09/2022 (Shift-II)
Correct! Pulmonary veins are the only veins in body that carry oxygen-rich blood. All the other veins carry oxygen-poor blood. Similarly, pulmonary arteries are the only arteries that carry oxygen-poor blood. All the rest of the arteries carry oxygen-rich blood.
Incorrect. Pulmonary veins are the only veins in body that carry oxygen-rich blood. All the other veins carry oxygen-poor blood. Similarly, pulmonary arteries are the only arteries that carry oxygen-poor blood. All the rest of the arteries carry oxygen-rich blood.

Q121: Systolic pressure is a measure of ______

Source: RRB Group-D– 13/09/2022 (Shift-III)
Correct! Systolic pressure is a measure of ventricular contraction. Blood pressure is the pressure of blood pushing against the walls of the arteries. Arteries carry blood from the heart to other parts of the body. A normal blood pressure is 120/80 mmHg.
Incorrect. Systolic pressure is a measure of ventricular contraction. Blood pressure is the pressure of blood pushing against the walls of the arteries. Arteries carry blood from the heart to other parts of the body. A normal blood pressure is 120/80 mmHg.

Q122: Which of the following circulates around the body and plugs the leaks by helping to clot the blood at the points of injury?

Source: RRB Group-D– 13/09/2022 (Shift-III)
Correct! Platelets are tiny blood cells that help your body from clots to stop bleeding. If one of your blood vessels gets damaged, it sends out signals to the platelets. The platelets then rush to the site damage and form a plug (clot) to fix the damage.
Incorrect. Platelets are tiny blood cells that help your body from clots to stop bleeding. If one of your blood vessels gets damaged, it sends out signals to the platelets. The platelets then rush to the site damage and form a plug (clot) to fix the damage.

Q123: Which of the following statements is INCORRECT about voluntary muscles?

Source: RRB Group-D– 15/09/2022 (Shift-III)
Correct! Cells are long, cylindrical, unbranched and uninucleate is incorrect statement about voluntary muscles. Rest is statements are correct.
Incorrect. Cells are long, cylindrical, unbranched and uninucleate is incorrect statement about voluntary muscles. Rest is statements are correct.

Q124: Match the columns. Group-I Group-B I. Heart A. Pumping organ II. Arteries B. Carries deoxygenated blood III. Veins C. Carries oxygenated blood

Source: RRB Group-D– 22/09/2022 (Shift-I)
Correct! Group I Group II I. Heart Pumping organ II. Arteries Carries oxygenated blood III. Veins Carries deoxygenated blood
Incorrect. Group I Group II I. Heart Pumping organ II. Arteries Carries oxygenated blood III. Veins Carries deoxygenated blood

Q125: Two questions based on the transverse section of human heart are given below. Find the option that gives the correct answers to both the questions. Q. Why does the part labelled 'A' have thick walls? Q. What is the function of the part labelled 'B'?

Source: RRB Group-D– 22/09/2022 (Shift-I)
Correct! The myocardium in the left ventricle is significantly thicker than that of the right ventricle. Both ventricles pump the same amount of blood, but the left ventricle must generate a much greater pressure to overcome greater resistance in the systemic circuit. The ventricles are shown in both relaxed and contracting states. So, A- Because it pumps blood to different parts of the body B - Prevents back flow of blood.
Incorrect. The myocardium in the left ventricle is significantly thicker than that of the right ventricle. Both ventricles pump the same amount of blood, but the left ventricle must generate a much greater pressure to overcome greater resistance in the systemic circuit. The ventricles are shown in both relaxed and contracting states. So, A- Because it pumps blood to different parts of the body B - Prevents back flow of blood.

Q126: What is the fluid matrix of blood called?

Source: RRB Group-D– 20/09/2022 (Shift-III)
Correct! The fluid matrix of blood is called plasma. The main role of plasma is to take nutrients hormones and proteins to the parts of the body that need it.
Incorrect. The fluid matrix of blood is called plasma. The main role of plasma is to take nutrients hormones and proteins to the parts of the body that need it.

Q127: Which of the following elements is part of heme (haem) of human blood?

Source: RRB NTPC (Stage-II) –14/06/2022 (Shift-II)
Correct! Iron is a part of heme (haem) of human blood. Haemoglobin is a type of globular protein present in Red Blood Cells (RBCs), which transports oxygen in our body through blood. It is a tetrameric protein and contains the haem prosthetic group attached to each subunit. Haem is an iron porphyrin complex.
Incorrect. Iron is a part of heme (haem) of human blood. Haemoglobin is a type of globular protein present in Red Blood Cells (RBCs), which transports oxygen in our body through blood. It is a tetrameric protein and contains the haem prosthetic group attached to each subunit. Haem is an iron porphyrin complex.

Q128: The liquid part of human blood, called _______. is made of water, salts and protein.

Source: RRB NTPC (Stage-II) 14/06/2022 (Shift-I)
Correct! The liquid part of human blood is called plasma. It contains 92% water, 7% blood vital proteins such as albumin, gamma globulin and anti-hemophilic factor and 1% mineral salts, sugars, fats, hormones and vitamins. Blood plasma flows within blood vessels and takes part in nutrition, excretion, respiration.
Incorrect. The liquid part of human blood is called plasma. It contains 92% water, 7% blood vital proteins such as albumin, gamma globulin and anti-hemophilic factor and 1% mineral salts, sugars, fats, hormones and vitamins. Blood plasma flows within blood vessels and takes part in nutrition, excretion, respiration.

Q129: In the human heart, the pulmonary vein is connected to the ______.

Source: RRB Group-D– 06/10/2022 (Shift-II)
Correct! Normally, each pulmonary vein connects directly with your left atrium. In that case, there are four ostia (openings) in your left atrium, one for each of your pulmonary veins. Oxygen-rich blood travels through these openings and into your left atrium.
Incorrect. Normally, each pulmonary vein connects directly with your left atrium. In that case, there are four ostia (openings) in your left atrium, one for each of your pulmonary veins. Oxygen-rich blood travels through these openings and into your left atrium.

Q130: Which of the following plasma protein is involved in blood coagulation?

Source: RRB SSE 21.12.2014
Correct! Prothromboplastin reacts with the calcium ion of blood to form thromboplastin. Thromboplastin, by reacting with an enzyme called calcium ion (Ca ++) and tryptase, converts inactive prothrombin into a substance called active thrombin. This active thrombin acts on the blood protein fibrinogen and converts it into fibrin. Fibrin makes a mesh of fine and soft fibres. This mesh is so fine and microfilamentous that particles of blood (especially RBC) get trapped in it and form a red solid body, called a blood clot.
Incorrect. Prothromboplastin reacts with the calcium ion of blood to form thromboplastin. Thromboplastin, by reacting with an enzyme called calcium ion (Ca ++) and tryptase, converts inactive prothrombin into a substance called active thrombin. This active thrombin acts on the blood protein fibrinogen and converts it into fibrin. Fibrin makes a mesh of fine and soft fibres. This mesh is so fine and microfilamentous that particles of blood (especially RBC) get trapped in it and form a red solid body, called a blood clot.

Q131: A conventional blood pressure measuring device in which the physician observes fluctuations in mercury column, the manually operated air pump is connected to:

Source: RRB SSE (21.12.2014, Set-08, Green paper)
Correct! A conventional blood pressure measuring device is called a sphygmomanometer. It is the most conventional form of blood pressure apparatus . This device consists of a pump that has a rubber tube. This tube subsequently divides into two parts. It consists of manually inflatable cuffs that are attached to the mercury-infused tubes. This instrument was invented by Samuel Siegfried Karl Ritter von Basch in the year
Incorrect. A conventional blood pressure measuring device is called a sphygmomanometer. It is the most conventional form of blood pressure apparatus . This device consists of a pump that has a rubber tube. This tube subsequently divides into two parts. It consists of manually inflatable cuffs that are attached to the mercury-infused tubes. This instrument was invented by Samuel Siegfried Karl Ritter von Basch in the year

Q132: Which among the following blood group is considered as universal donor?

Source: RRB SSE (21.12.2014, Set-07, Yellow paper)
Correct! The blood group was discovered by Landsteiner. Blood is of four types A, B, AB, and O. Blood group AB is an universal receiver i.e it can receive blood of any person. Blood group O is universal donor i.e it can donate blood to person of any blood group but it can receive blood only from person with O group.
Incorrect. The blood group was discovered by Landsteiner. Blood is of four types A, B, AB, and O. Blood group AB is an universal receiver i.e it can receive blood of any person. Blood group O is universal donor i.e it can donate blood to person of any blood group but it can receive blood only from person with O group.

Q133: Which of the following is not a blood group?

Source: RRB JE 26.05.2019 (Shift-IV)
Correct! See the explanation of the above question.
Incorrect. See the explanation of the above question.

Q134: The normal systolic pressure of human blood is:

Source: RRB NTPC 05.04.2021 (Shift-I) Stage Ist
Correct! When the heart beats, it contracts and pumps blood through the arteries to the rest of body. This force creates pressure on the arteries. This is called systolic blood pressure. A normal systolic pressure is 120 mm Hg. The diastolic blood pressure indicates the pressure in the arteries when the heart rests between beats. A normal diastolic blood pressure is 80 mm/Hg.
Incorrect. When the heart beats, it contracts and pumps blood through the arteries to the rest of body. This force creates pressure on the arteries. This is called systolic blood pressure. A normal systolic pressure is 120 mm Hg. The diastolic blood pressure indicates the pressure in the arteries when the heart rests between beats. A normal diastolic blood pressure is 80 mm/Hg.

Q135: Select the option that is not true regarding the circulatory system.

Source: RRB Group-D 03-10-2018 (Shift-III)
Correct! Red blood is an example of fluid connective tissue. The amount of blood in the human body is about 7 to 8% of the body weight. Therefore, an average 5 to 6 liters of blood is present in a human body of 70 kg. RBC surrounds 1 / 13th part of human body. Its lifespan is about 120 days.
Incorrect. Red blood is an example of fluid connective tissue. The amount of blood in the human body is about 7 to 8% of the body weight. Therefore, an average 5 to 6 liters of blood is present in a human body of 70 kg. RBC surrounds 1 / 13th part of human body. Its lifespan is about 120 days.

Q136: Which of the following options is not correct about the circulatory system?

Source: RRB Group-D 03-10-2018 (Shift-II)
Correct! Blood is fluid connective tissue which constitutes 7-8% of the total weight of human body. Three types of blood cells are found in the blood as RBC, WBC and platelets. Red blood cells have lifespan 115-120 days. A healthy human body has about 6.8 liters of blood. Hence option (d) is not correct about the circulatory system.
Incorrect. Blood is fluid connective tissue which constitutes 7-8% of the total weight of human body. Three types of blood cells are found in the blood as RBC, WBC and platelets. Red blood cells have lifespan 115-120 days. A healthy human body has about 6.8 liters of blood. Hence option (d) is not correct about the circulatory system.

Q137: Normal human blood is:

Source: RRB J.E. (14.12.2014, Green paper)
Correct! Human blood is a bodily fluid that flows continuously in various organs inside the blood vessels. This thicks, lightly alkaline and reddish fluid, which is circulated in the blood capillaries, is a living connective tissue. It consists of plasma and blood platelets. There is about five liters of blood in the human body. Its pH value is between 7.35 to 7.45. It has slightly alkaline nature due to a pH greater than 7.
Incorrect. Human blood is a bodily fluid that flows continuously in various organs inside the blood vessels. This thicks, lightly alkaline and reddish fluid, which is circulated in the blood capillaries, is a living connective tissue. It consists of plasma and blood platelets. There is about five liters of blood in the human body. Its pH value is between 7.35 to 7.45. It has slightly alkaline nature due to a pH greater than 7.

Q138: Blood pressure is the force:

Source: RRB NTPC 08.03.2021 (Shift-I) Stage Ist
Correct! Blood pressure is the force of the blood pushing against the artery walls. The force is made with each heartbeat as blood is pumped from the heart into the blood vessels. This is called systolic blood pressure. • The components of blood pressure include systolic pressure, which results from ventricular contraction and diastolic pressure which results from ventricular relaxation.
Incorrect. Blood pressure is the force of the blood pushing against the artery walls. The force is made with each heartbeat as blood is pumped from the heart into the blood vessels. This is called systolic blood pressure. • The components of blood pressure include systolic pressure, which results from ventricular contraction and diastolic pressure which results from ventricular relaxation.

Q139: Blood has a fluid matrix called ____, in which RBCs, WBCs, and platelets are suspended.

Source: RRB NTPC 23.01.2021 (Shift-II) Stage Ist
Correct! The liquid part of the blood, called plasma, is made of water, salts, and protein. Over half of our blood is plasma. The solid part of our blood contains red blood cells, white blood cells, and platelets. Red Blood Cells (RBC) deliver oxygen from our lungs to our tissues and organs. It is basic in nature and its pH value is 7.4 . WBCs are a part of Immune system. They help fight infection and defend the body against other foreign materials.
Incorrect. The liquid part of the blood, called plasma, is made of water, salts, and protein. Over half of our blood is plasma. The solid part of our blood contains red blood cells, white blood cells, and platelets. Red Blood Cells (RBC) deliver oxygen from our lungs to our tissues and organs. It is basic in nature and its pH value is 7.4 . WBCs are a part of Immune system. They help fight infection and defend the body against other foreign materials.

Q140: The blood pressure of a healthy man is:

Source: RRB J.E. 2014 (14.12.2014 Set-2, Red Paper)
Correct! Blood pressure (BP) is the pressure of circulating blood on the walls of blood vessels on contraction of heart. This phenomenon is expressed using two values known as the systolic pressure and the diastolic pressure (in mm Hg).The normal resting blood pressure for adults is 120/80. The systolic pressure is the measurement of pressure when the heart contracts . On the contrary, the diastolic pressure is the measurement of pressure when the heart refills with blood between beats. Blood pressure is measured by sphygmomanometer. 150/90 mm Hg → suffers from high pressure. (Hypertension) 100/50 mm Hg → suffers from low pressure. (Hypotension)
Incorrect. Blood pressure (BP) is the pressure of circulating blood on the walls of blood vessels on contraction of heart. This phenomenon is expressed using two values known as the systolic pressure and the diastolic pressure (in mm Hg).The normal resting blood pressure for adults is 120/80. The systolic pressure is the measurement of pressure when the heart contracts . On the contrary, the diastolic pressure is the measurement of pressure when the heart refills with blood between beats. Blood pressure is measured by sphygmomanometer. 150/90 mm Hg → suffers from high pressure. (Hypertension) 100/50 mm Hg → suffers from low pressure. (Hypotension)

Q141: The technology that uses the reflection of ultrasound waves to produce images of the heart is known as:

Source: RRB NTPC 05.03.2021 (Shift-I) Stage Ist
Correct! Echocardiography is a test that uses soundwaves to produce live images of heart. This test allows doctor to monitor the functioning of heart and its valves. The images can help to get information about blood clots in the heart chambers.
Incorrect. Echocardiography is a test that uses soundwaves to produce live images of heart. This test allows doctor to monitor the functioning of heart and its valves. The images can help to get information about blood clots in the heart chambers.

Q142: Which component of the blood transports food, CO2 and nitrogenous waste?

Source: RRB ALP & Tec. (14-08-18 Shift-I)
Correct! Plasma is the yellowish fluid component of blood, in which blood cells of whole blood are normally suspended. It accounts for about 55% of the total blood volume.It consists water as major portion and proteins, sugars, coagulation factors, mineral ions, hormones and carbon dioxide are soluble in it . Plasma transports food, CO2 and nitrogenous wastes in human body.
Incorrect. Plasma is the yellowish fluid component of blood, in which blood cells of whole blood are normally suspended. It accounts for about 55% of the total blood volume.It consists water as major portion and proteins, sugars, coagulation factors, mineral ions, hormones and carbon dioxide are soluble in it . Plasma transports food, CO2 and nitrogenous wastes in human body.

Q143: The pH level of the human body is:

Source: RRB ALP & Tec. (20-08-18 Shift-I)
Correct! The pH value is the measure of the acidicity and alkalinity of substances. Its value is equal to the inverse logarithm of the concentration of hydrogen ion (H+). The pH value is between 0 to 14. A substance whose pH value is less than 7 is acidic, alkaline when greater than 7, and neutral when it is equal to 7. The human body needs a controlled pH level of 7.0 to 7.8 (alkaline) to survive. The pH value of human urine is 5.5 to 7.5, the pH value of human saliva is 6.5 to 7.5 and the pH value of human blood is from 7.3 to 7.5.
Incorrect. The pH value is the measure of the acidicity and alkalinity of substances. Its value is equal to the inverse logarithm of the concentration of hydrogen ion (H+). The pH value is between 0 to 14. A substance whose pH value is less than 7 is acidic, alkaline when greater than 7, and neutral when it is equal to 7. The human body needs a controlled pH level of 7.0 to 7.8 (alkaline) to survive. The pH value of human urine is 5.5 to 7.5, the pH value of human saliva is 6.5 to 7.5 and the pH value of human blood is from 7.3 to 7.5.

Q144: The pH range of a human body is:

Source: RRB NTPC 04.01.2021 (Shift-I) Stage Ist
Correct! The pH value of the human body lies in a tight range between 7.35-7.45 and the pH of other body fluids are different. pH indicates the level of H+ ions where low pH indicates too many OH– ions.
Incorrect. The pH value of the human body lies in a tight range between 7.35-7.45 and the pH of other body fluids are different. pH indicates the level of H+ ions where low pH indicates too many OH– ions.

Q145: ..............found in blood, is responsible for oxygen transportation.

Source: RRB ALP & Tec. (21-08-18 Shift-II)
Correct! Red blood cells are formed in red bone marrow in adults but it is formed in the spleen and liver in embryonic stage. Each hemoglobin molecule contains four iron-binding haem groups which are the site of oxygen binding. Oxygen-bound hemoglobin is called oxyhemoglobin. Cell carries oxyhemoglobin through blood circulation. This cell does not have a nucleus. Its average life span is 120 days.
Incorrect. Red blood cells are formed in red bone marrow in adults but it is formed in the spleen and liver in embryonic stage. Each hemoglobin molecule contains four iron-binding haem groups which are the site of oxygen binding. Oxygen-bound hemoglobin is called oxyhemoglobin. Cell carries oxyhemoglobin through blood circulation. This cell does not have a nucleus. Its average life span is 120 days.

Correct! See the explanation of the above question.

Q147: Which is the largest artery in the human body?

Source: RRB NTPC 10.01.2021 (Shift-I) Stage Ist
Correct! The aorta is the largest artery in the human body that carries oxygen-rich blood from the left ventricle of the heart to other parts of the body. The aorta breaks into arteries and finally to a very fine structure known as arterioles.
Incorrect. The aorta is the largest artery in the human body that carries oxygen-rich blood from the left ventricle of the heart to other parts of the body. The aorta breaks into arteries and finally to a very fine structure known as arterioles.

Q148: The average weight of an adult human heart is about

Source: RRB NTPC 03.03.2021 (Shift-I) Stage Ist
Correct! The adult human heart weights around 250- 350g. It accounts for approximately 0.45% of the total body weight. According to option, correct answer will be option (b).
Incorrect. The adult human heart weights around 250- 350g. It accounts for approximately 0.45% of the total body weight. According to option, correct answer will be option (b).

Q149: .........tissue changes the diameter of the blood vessel.

Source: RRB ALP & Tec. (30-08-18 Shift-I)
Correct! Muscles are important for making various interfaces of the body to generate power to contract and relax inside the body. The thin, elongated and contractile muscle cells, also called muscle fibres, are called muscle tissue. These muscle tissues are helpful in changing the diameter of blood vessels in the body.
Incorrect. Muscles are important for making various interfaces of the body to generate power to contract and relax inside the body. The thin, elongated and contractile muscle cells, also called muscle fibres, are called muscle tissue. These muscle tissues are helpful in changing the diameter of blood vessels in the body.

Q150: ........ is part of the blood that contains 92% water and the remaining 8% contains protein, minerals, hormones, enzymes and other substances.

Source: RRB ALP & Tec. (31-08-18 Shift-II)
Correct! Plasma is a yellowish, clear , viscous , transparent and basic fluid component of blood . Plasma is the liquid portion of blood. About 55% of blood is plasma, and the remaining 45% are red blood cells, white blood cells and platelets that are suspended in the plasma.Plasma is about 92% water. It also contains 7% vital proteins such as albumin, gamma globulin and anti-hemophilic factor, and 1% mineral salts, sugars, fats, hormones and vitamins.
Incorrect. Plasma is a yellowish, clear , viscous , transparent and basic fluid component of blood . Plasma is the liquid portion of blood. About 55% of blood is plasma, and the remaining 45% are red blood cells, white blood cells and platelets that are suspended in the plasma.Plasma is about 92% water. It also contains 7% vital proteins such as albumin, gamma globulin and anti-hemophilic factor, and 1% mineral salts, sugars, fats, hormones and vitamins.

Q151: What is the function of RBC in the human body?

Source: RRB NTPC 02.03.2021 (Shift-II) Stage Ist
Correct! Red blood cells are responsible for transporting oxygen from lungs to body’s tissues. Our tissues produce energy with the oxygen and release a waste, identified as carbon dioxide. Our red blood cells take the carbon dioxide (CO2) waste to lungs for exhale. RRB Science Planner Biology YCT 549
Incorrect. Red blood cells are responsible for transporting oxygen from lungs to body’s tissues. Our tissues produce energy with the oxygen and release a waste, identified as carbon dioxide. Our red blood cells take the carbon dioxide (CO2) waste to lungs for exhale. RRB Science Planner Biology YCT 549

Q152: Why is pulse rate of the human body examined?

Source: RRB NTPC Stage Ist 30.04.2016 (Shift-I)
Correct! The pulse rate of the human body is used to check the functioning of the heart. Pulse is the rate at which the heart beats. As the blood pumps from the heart, it can feel pulsation in some blood vessels close to the surface of the skin. The normal pulse rate for an adult beats 60 to 100 beats per minutes.
Incorrect. The pulse rate of the human body is used to check the functioning of the heart. Pulse is the rate at which the heart beats. As the blood pumps from the heart, it can feel pulsation in some blood vessels close to the surface of the skin. The normal pulse rate for an adult beats 60 to 100 beats per minutes.

Q154: On which organ of human body is angioplasty performed?

Correct! Angioplasty is performed on heart in human body.
Incorrect. Angioplasty is performed on heart in human body.

Q155: Which of the following is a pigment present in human blood that carries oxygen out from lungs to all parts of the body?

Source: RRB NTPC 16.01.2021 (Shift-II) Stage Ist
Correct! Haemoglobin is the iron-containing pigment that enables red blood cells to carry high concentration of oxygen to the tissues. It carries oxygen out from lungs to all parts of the body.
Incorrect. Haemoglobin is the iron-containing pigment that enables red blood cells to carry high concentration of oxygen to the tissues. It carries oxygen out from lungs to all parts of the body.

Q156: In human beings, which of the following has a high affinity for oxygen?

Source: RRB NTPC 12.01.2021 (Shift-II) Stage Ist
Correct! Respiratory pigments like haemoglobin, myoglobin have high affinity with oxygen. Haemoglobin functions as oxygen carrier in blood from the lung to the rest of the body.
Incorrect. Respiratory pigments like haemoglobin, myoglobin have high affinity with oxygen. Haemoglobin functions as oxygen carrier in blood from the lung to the rest of the body.

Q157: Which of the following metals is present in hemoglobin?

Source: RRB NTPC Stage Ist 29.04.2016 (Shift-I)
Correct! Hemoglobin is made up of a protein called globin and a compound called heme. Heme consists of iron and a pigment called porphyrin, which gives blood its red colour while iron rich globin protein have tremendous capacity to bind with oxygen and carbon dioxide. Normal adult has average amount of hemoglobin is 15 gm/100 ml.
Incorrect. Hemoglobin is made up of a protein called globin and a compound called heme. Heme consists of iron and a pigment called porphyrin, which gives blood its red colour while iron rich globin protein have tremendous capacity to bind with oxygen and carbon dioxide. Normal adult has average amount of hemoglobin is 15 gm/100 ml.

Source: RRB JE 29.05.2019 (Shift-III)
Correct! See the explanation of the above question.
Incorrect. See the explanation of the above question.

Q159: The protein in hemoglobin is .

Source: RRB JE 25.05.2019 (Shift-III)
Correct! See the explanation of the above question.
Incorrect. See the explanation of the above question.

Q160: Human blood platelets release .............. which helps in blood clotting.

Source: RRB NTPC Stage Ist 27.04.2016 (Shift-III)
Correct! Human blood platelets release prothrombin which helps blood clotting. Vitamin K also assists in blood clotting.
Incorrect. Human blood platelets release prothrombin which helps blood clotting. Vitamin K also assists in blood clotting.

Q161: White blood cells in the blood. . . . . .

Source: RRB NTPC Stage Ist 26.04.2016 (Shift-I)
Correct! The shape and size of white blood cells or leukocytes is not fixed, but it changes like amoeba. The number of WBCs in an adult human is 6–11 thousand per cubic mm. The immune function of the body is conducted by white blood cells. Immunity is the balanced state of multicellular organisms having adequate biological defenses to fight infection, disease, or other unwanted biological invasion, while having adequate tolerance to avoid allergy, and autoimmune diseases.
Incorrect. The shape and size of white blood cells or leukocytes is not fixed, but it changes like amoeba. The number of WBCs in an adult human is 6–11 thousand per cubic mm. The immune function of the body is conducted by white blood cells. Immunity is the balanced state of multicellular organisms having adequate biological defenses to fight infection, disease, or other unwanted biological invasion, while having adequate tolerance to avoid allergy, and autoimmune diseases.

Q162: Normal human bleeding time and clotting time are ……… and ………. respectively .

Source: RRB NTPC 07.04.2016 (Shift-II) Stage Ist
Correct! Normal human bleeding time and clotting time are 2-7 and 3-10 minutes respectively. Blood plasma releases prothrombin and fibrinogen with the help of vitamin K in the liver. Vitamin K helps in blood clotting.
Incorrect. Normal human bleeding time and clotting time are 2-7 and 3-10 minutes respectively. Blood plasma releases prothrombin and fibrinogen with the help of vitamin K in the liver. Vitamin K helps in blood clotting.

Q163: In which of the following cells present in human body, mitochondria are not found?

Source: RRB NTPC 02.04.2016 (Shift-I) Stage Ist
Correct! RBCs (red blood cells), present in the human body, do not contain mitochondria. RBCs are formed in the bone marrow. RBCs contain protein named as Hemoglobin. The nucleus is absent in RBCs. Its average life span is 120 days.
Incorrect. RBCs (red blood cells), present in the human body, do not contain mitochondria. RBCs are formed in the bone marrow. RBCs contain protein named as Hemoglobin. The nucleus is absent in RBCs. Its average life span is 120 days.

Q164: Which of the following circulates impure blood?

Source: RRB NTPC 10.04.2016 (Shift-III) Stage Ist
Correct! The pulmonary artery carries deoxygenated blood from the right ventricle into the lungs for oxygenation. It contains impure blood.The left half of the heart collects and pumps pure (oxygenated) blood from the lungs to all parts of the body.The right half of the heart carries impure (CO2 containing) blood.The pH value of blood is 7.4. RRB Science Planner Biology YCT 550
Incorrect. The pulmonary artery carries deoxygenated blood from the right ventricle into the lungs for oxygenation. It contains impure blood.The left half of the heart collects and pumps pure (oxygenated) blood from the lungs to all parts of the body.The right half of the heart carries impure (CO2 containing) blood.The pH value of blood is 7.4. RRB Science Planner Biology YCT 550

Q165: Which of the following does not refer to Cholesterol?

Source: RRB NTPC 11.04.2016 (Shift-II) Stage Ist
Correct! An antigen is obtained from research related to Rhesus monkey.The Rh factor is a protein that can be found on the surface of red blood cells in most human(85%). Anomaly between Rh factors may cause severe disorder for mother and her fetus, while Rhesus factor does not refer to Cholesterol.
Incorrect. An antigen is obtained from research related to Rhesus monkey.The Rh factor is a protein that can be found on the surface of red blood cells in most human(85%). Anomaly between Rh factors may cause severe disorder for mother and her fetus, while Rhesus factor does not refer to Cholesterol.

Q166: Which of the following organs of human body has sinoatrial node?

Source: RRB NTPC 12.04.2016 (Shift-I) Stage Ist
Correct! Sinoatrial node is located in heart of human body. The main function of the sinoatrial node is to act as the normal pacemaker of the heart. It initiates an action potential that results in an electrical impulse travelling through the heart's electrical conduction system to cause myocardial contraction. Internal body temperature is regulated by a part of brain called the hypothalamus, while external body temperature is regulated by ear.
Incorrect. Sinoatrial node is located in heart of human body. The main function of the sinoatrial node is to act as the normal pacemaker of the heart. It initiates an action potential that results in an electrical impulse travelling through the heart's electrical conduction system to cause myocardial contraction. Internal body temperature is regulated by a part of brain called the hypothalamus, while external body temperature is regulated by ear.

Q167: Who invented the A, B and O blood group system?

Source: RRB NTPC 16.04.2016 (Shift-III) Stage Ist
Correct! The blood group was first discovered by Nobel laureate Karl Landsteiner in 1900. He discovered that factors related to blood group are found in RBCs and plasma of blood. Landsteiner discovered only three blood groups A, B and O. Later De Castello and Sturli invented the fourth blood group AB.
Incorrect. The blood group was first discovered by Nobel laureate Karl Landsteiner in 1900. He discovered that factors related to blood group are found in RBCs and plasma of blood. Landsteiner discovered only three blood groups A, B and O. Later De Castello and Sturli invented the fourth blood group AB.

Q168: How many litres of blood does an adult human have?

Source: RRB NTPC 18.04.2016 (Shift-I) Stage Ist
Correct! In a normal adult human , the amount of blood is 1/10 part of its weight, i.e, 4.5–5 litres. The blood is composed of red coloured connective tissue consisting of 55% of the plasma and 45% of the blood cells (RBC, WBC and platelets). The pH value of blood is 7.4 and it is responsible for the circulation of oxygen and nutrients in the body.
Incorrect. In a normal adult human , the amount of blood is 1/10 part of its weight, i.e, 4.5–5 litres. The blood is composed of red coloured connective tissue consisting of 55% of the plasma and 45% of the blood cells (RBC, WBC and platelets). The pH value of blood is 7.4 and it is responsible for the circulation of oxygen and nutrients in the body.

Q169: Which of the following describes heart functioning more appropriately?

Source: RRB NTPC 19.04.2016 (Shift-II) Stage Ist
Correct! An echocardiogram is an ultrasound image of the heart that describes cardiac functioning more appropriately. Echocardiograms are used to diagnose heart problems. An electrocardiogram (ECG) is a test which measures the electrical activity of heart to show whether or not it is working normally.
Incorrect. An echocardiogram is an ultrasound image of the heart that describes cardiac functioning more appropriately. Echocardiograms are used to diagnose heart problems. An electrocardiogram (ECG) is a test which measures the electrical activity of heart to show whether or not it is working normally.

Q170: What is the approximate value of pH of 'human blood'?

Source: RRB NTPC 18.01.2017 (Shift-III) Stage IInd
Correct! The pH of human blood is 7.4. pH value (power of Hydrogen) is the concentration of hydrogen ions in the substances.
Incorrect. The pH of human blood is 7.4. pH value (power of Hydrogen) is the concentration of hydrogen ions in the substances.

Q171: What should be the pH limit in blood for normal health?

Source: RRB NTPC 05.04.2016 (Shift-II) Stage Ist
Correct! See the explanation of above question.
Incorrect. See the explanation of above question.

Q172: A person with AB blood group -

Source: RRB NTPC 31.03.2016 (Shift-II) Stage Ist
Correct! A person with AB blood group can receive blood from any blood group. Blood group 'AB' is called universal recipient, because it has no antibody and blood group 'O' is called universal donar , because it does not contain any antigen.
Incorrect. A person with AB blood group can receive blood from any blood group. Blood group 'AB' is called universal recipient, because it has no antibody and blood group 'O' is called universal donar , because it does not contain any antigen.

Q173: The arteries carry blood, are filled with:

Source: RRB NTPC 28.03.2016 (Shift-I) Stage Ist
Correct! The arteries carry pure blood, which is filled with oxygen (except pulmonary artery). Arteries are the blood vessels of the body that carry blood away from the heart and to the organs and tissues of the body while veins carry deoxygenated blood from the tissues back to the heart; exceptions are the pulmonary and umbilical veins, both of which carry oxygenated blood to the heart.
Incorrect. The arteries carry pure blood, which is filled with oxygen (except pulmonary artery). Arteries are the blood vessels of the body that carry blood away from the heart and to the organs and tissues of the body while veins carry deoxygenated blood from the tissues back to the heart; exceptions are the pulmonary and umbilical veins, both of which carry oxygenated blood to the heart.

Q174: Plasma, a constituent of blood, is a -

Source: RRB NTPC Stage Ist 19.01.2017 (Shift-I)
Correct! Plasma is the fundamental matrix of blood, which is 55-60% of the blood. Plasma contains 90-92% water and 8-10 % proteins, organic and inorganic substances. Generally, it is a type of fluid. There are mainly two substances found in plasma. (1) In Organic substances - sodium chloride and sodium bicarbonate are found in it. Alkalinity of plasma is maintained by organic substance . (2) Organic substances - Plasma proteins, digested nutrients, excretory substances, hormones, antigens etc. The main function of plasma is to circulate digested food and hormones in the body.
Incorrect. Plasma is the fundamental matrix of blood, which is 55-60% of the blood. Plasma contains 90-92% water and 8-10 % proteins, organic and inorganic substances. Generally, it is a type of fluid. There are mainly two substances found in plasma. (1) In Organic substances - sodium chloride and sodium bicarbonate are found in it. Alkalinity of plasma is maintained by organic substance . (2) Organic substances - Plasma proteins, digested nutrients, excretory substances, hormones, antigens etc. The main function of plasma is to circulate digested food and hormones in the body.

Q175: Which of the following options is not true about red blood cells?

Source: RRB Group-D 09-10-2018 (Shift-II)
Correct! Red blood cells are also called erythrocytes. These corpuscles are formed in the bone marrow. The mature human red blood cell is small, round, and biconcave; it appears dumbbell-shaped in profile. RBC contains iron-rich protein called hemoglobin. Hemoglobin participates in the transport of oxygen and carbon dioxide. Their life span is about 120 days. The length of the RBC is 7.0 micrometers.
Incorrect. Red blood cells are also called erythrocytes. These corpuscles are formed in the bone marrow. The mature human red blood cell is small, round, and biconcave; it appears dumbbell-shaped in profile. RBC contains iron-rich protein called hemoglobin. Hemoglobin participates in the transport of oxygen and carbon dioxide. Their life span is about 120 days. The length of the RBC is 7.0 micrometers.

Q176: Which of the following vein collects blood from the anterior parts of the body?

Source: RRB Group-D 12-11-2018 (Shift-II)
Correct! Superior Vena Cava collects blood from the anterior parts of the body. Blood is returned in heart through two paired pulmonary veins, Superior Vena Cava and Inferior Vena Cava.
Incorrect. Superior Vena Cava collects blood from the anterior parts of the body. Blood is returned in heart through two paired pulmonary veins, Superior Vena Cava and Inferior Vena Cava.

Q177: Choose the option that is not true about the ciculatory system.

Source: RRB Group-D 12-10-2018 (Shift-II)
Correct! The circulatory system or vascular system is a set of organs that transports nutrients between the body's cells. It protects the body from diseases and keeps the body temperature and pH constant. This system is usually 7% to 8% of the total body weight.
Incorrect. The circulatory system or vascular system is a set of organs that transports nutrients between the body's cells. It protects the body from diseases and keeps the body temperature and pH constant. This system is usually 7% to 8% of the total body weight.

Q178: Which of the following is NOT found in human blood?

Source: RRB NTPC 14.03.2021 (Shift-I) Stage Ist
Correct! Blood is a specialized body fluid. It has four main components: Plasma, Red blood cells (Erythrocytes), White blood cells (Leucocytes), and Platelets. Types of white blood cells are granulocytes (neutrophils, eosinophils, and basophils), monocytes, and lymphocytes (T-cells and B- cells). Blood performs different functions. The chondrocyte is the resident cell of cartilage that is a prominent tissue in the embryo. It is not found in human blood.
Incorrect. Blood is a specialized body fluid. It has four main components: Plasma, Red blood cells (Erythrocytes), White blood cells (Leucocytes), and Platelets. Types of white blood cells are granulocytes (neutrophils, eosinophils, and basophils), monocytes, and lymphocytes (T-cells and B- cells). Blood performs different functions. The chondrocyte is the resident cell of cartilage that is a prominent tissue in the embryo. It is not found in human blood.

Q179: Which of the following cells, present in the human body, does not have nucleus?

Source: RRB Group-D 23-10-2018 (Shift-III)
Correct! Erythrocytes (Red Blood Corpuscles) do not have a nucleus. RBCs are formed in the bone marrow. Protein, iron, vitamin B12 and folic acid are helpful in the formation of RBCs. RBCs have a life span of 115 to 120 days.
Incorrect. Erythrocytes (Red Blood Corpuscles) do not have a nucleus. RBCs are formed in the bone marrow. Protein, iron, vitamin B12 and folic acid are helpful in the formation of RBCs. RBCs have a life span of 115 to 120 days.

Q180: Choose the option that is not true about the vascular system -

Source: RRB Group-D 04-10-2018 (Shift-II)
Correct! The human heart originates from the mesoderm, which is the size of a closed fist. The circulatory system is about 7-8% of body weight. Blood is commonly called ‘river of life’. Blood flows at high pressures, jerks, and faster in arteries while blood flows slowly, at low pressure in veins.
Incorrect. The human heart originates from the mesoderm, which is the size of a closed fist. The circulatory system is about 7-8% of body weight. Blood is commonly called ‘river of life’. Blood flows at high pressures, jerks, and faster in arteries while blood flows slowly, at low pressure in veins.

Q181: Choose the option that is not true about the circulatory system:

Source: RRB Group-D 05-10-2018 (Shift-I)
Correct! Blood is thick, opaque and alkaline fluid. The amount of blood in human body is about 7-8% of body weight. The amount of blood in an adult human is 5-6 litres. Red blood cells (RBCs) located in the blood are the most important cells of the blood. RBC has an average lifespan of 120 days. Blood is a fluid connective tissue that helps the cells of the body to transport essential substances , nutrients and oxygen. Hence, it is called the 'River of Life'.
Incorrect. Blood is thick, opaque and alkaline fluid. The amount of blood in human body is about 7-8% of body weight. The amount of blood in an adult human is 5-6 litres. Red blood cells (RBCs) located in the blood are the most important cells of the blood. RBC has an average lifespan of 120 days. Blood is a fluid connective tissue that helps the cells of the body to transport essential substances , nutrients and oxygen. Hence, it is called the 'River of Life'.

Q182: Blood is . . .. ... . tissue.

Source: RRB Group-D 05-10-2018 (Shift-I)
Correct! Blood is a fluid connective tissue in which blood cells, plasma, hemoglobin, protein etc. are present. The colour of blood is red due to the presence of a pigment called heme in hemoglobin.
Incorrect. Blood is a fluid connective tissue in which blood cells, plasma, hemoglobin, protein etc. are present. The colour of blood is red due to the presence of a pigment called heme in hemoglobin.

Q183: The largest corpuscles in human blood is …… .

Source: RRB Group-D 27-09-2018 (Shift-III)
Correct! The largest corpuscles in human blood are white blood corpuscles. Their diameter is about 12 to 15 micrometers. It is larger than the red blood corpuscles (about 8.0 micrometers) in size but is tiny, colourless, nucleated and less in number. The shape of a WBC is irregular like Amoeba.
Incorrect. The largest corpuscles in human blood are white blood corpuscles. Their diameter is about 12 to 15 micrometers. It is larger than the red blood corpuscles (about 8.0 micrometers) in size but is tiny, colourless, nucleated and less in number. The shape of a WBC is irregular like Amoeba.

Q184: ........ does not have collagen.

Source: RRB Group-D 16-10-2018 (Shift-III)
Correct! Connective tissue ranges from soft tissue to special types of tissue such as cartilage, bone, fatty tissue, and blood. In all connective tissues except blood, the cells secrete fibres of structural proteins called collagen or elastin. They provide strength, elasticity and flexibility to the tissue. Collagen is found in liver, kidney and heart. It is slightly sticky, red coloured and a living tissue. It consists of plasma and blood particles. There are three types of blood corpuscles – (1) Red blood corpuscles (2) White blood corpuscles (3) Platelets RRB Science Planner Biology YCT 552
Incorrect. Connective tissue ranges from soft tissue to special types of tissue such as cartilage, bone, fatty tissue, and blood. In all connective tissues except blood, the cells secrete fibres of structural proteins called collagen or elastin. They provide strength, elasticity and flexibility to the tissue. Collagen is found in liver, kidney and heart. It is slightly sticky, red coloured and a living tissue. It consists of plasma and blood particles. There are three types of blood corpuscles – (1) Red blood corpuscles (2) White blood corpuscles (3) Platelets RRB Science Planner Biology YCT 552

Q185: Which of the following metals is present in hemoglobin?

Source: RRB Group-D 05-12-2018 (Shift-II)
Correct! Hemoglobin is a type of protein found in blood cells. Hemoglobin is made up of two words - heme + globin. Human blood is red due to heme and globin is an iron-containing protein, which has tremendous ability to combine oxygen and carbon dioxide.
Incorrect. Hemoglobin is a type of protein found in blood cells. Hemoglobin is made up of two words - heme + globin. Human blood is red due to heme and globin is an iron-containing protein, which has tremendous ability to combine oxygen and carbon dioxide.

Q186: Cardiac muscle cells are:

Source: RRB Group-D 16-11-2018 (Shift-III)
Correct! Cardiac muscle cells are a type of involuntary muscle cells. These muscle cells are cylindrical, branched and uninucleated. They contract and relax rapidly, rhythmically and tirelessly throughout life. Relaxation and contraction of cardiac muscles help to pump blood and distribute blood in various part of body.
Incorrect. Cardiac muscle cells are a type of involuntary muscle cells. These muscle cells are cylindrical, branched and uninucleated. They contract and relax rapidly, rhythmically and tirelessly throughout life. Relaxation and contraction of cardiac muscles help to pump blood and distribute blood in various part of body.

Q187: Cardiac muscles are ………….

Source: RRB Group-D 05-10-2018 (Shift-II)
Correct! See the explanation of the above question.
Incorrect. See the explanation of the above question.

Q188: Which of the following is the duct that originates from the heart and transports blood to various organs in the body?

Source: RRB Group-D 05-11-2018 (Shift-I)
Correct! The ducts that originate from the heart and distribute the blood to different parts of the body, are called arteries. They usually carry pure blood, but impure blood flows from the heart to the lungs in the pulmonary artery.
Incorrect. The ducts that originate from the heart and distribute the blood to different parts of the body, are called arteries. They usually carry pure blood, but impure blood flows from the heart to the lungs in the pulmonary artery.

Q189: What is cardiac cycle?

Source: RRB Group-D 02-11-2018 (Shift-II)
Correct! The cardiac cycle is defined as a cycle which includes all the events associated with one heart beat. Cardiac cycle consist of contraction (systole) and relaxation (diastole) of both atria and ventricles. The average adult person has 65 to 75 heartbeats (cardiac cycles) per minute. One complete cardiac cycle takes about 0.8 seconds.
Incorrect. The cardiac cycle is defined as a cycle which includes all the events associated with one heart beat. Cardiac cycle consist of contraction (systole) and relaxation (diastole) of both atria and ventricles. The average adult person has 65 to 75 heartbeats (cardiac cycles) per minute. One complete cardiac cycle takes about 0.8 seconds.

Q190: The smallest blood vessel is called:

Source: RRB NTPC 03.04.2021 (Shift-II) Stage Ist
Correct! Capillaries, the smallest and most numerous of the blood vessels, form the connection between the vessels that carry blood away from the heart (arteries) and the vessels that return blood to the heart (veins). The primary function of capillaries is the exchange of materials between the blood and tissue cells.
Incorrect. Capillaries, the smallest and most numerous of the blood vessels, form the connection between the vessels that carry blood away from the heart (arteries) and the vessels that return blood to the heart (veins). The primary function of capillaries is the exchange of materials between the blood and tissue cells.

Q191: ............. is divided into four parts.

Source: RRB JE 31.05.2019 (Shift-III)
Correct! The heart is divided into four parts. Two atria and two ventricles.
Incorrect. The heart is divided into four parts. Two atria and two ventricles.

Q192: Exchange of respiratory gases occurs through. . . . . in lungs.

Source: RRB JE 28.05.2019 (Shift-III)
Correct! Gas exchange takes place in the millions of alveoli in the lungs and the capillaries that envelope them.
Incorrect. Gas exchange takes place in the millions of alveoli in the lungs and the capillaries that envelope them.

Q193: Which of the following can be compared to soldiers?

Source: RRB Group-D 02-11-2018 (Shift-I)
Correct! White blood cells are important component of the innate immune system in the human body. These are also called leukocytes. Their number is about 7,500 in one cubic mm of blood of human. It is colourless or white in colour. These are immune cells protecting the body from infectious diseases and foreign invader substances, so they are compared as soldiers fighting diseases in the body.
Incorrect. White blood cells are important component of the innate immune system in the human body. These are also called leukocytes. Their number is about 7,500 in one cubic mm of blood of human. It is colourless or white in colour. These are immune cells protecting the body from infectious diseases and foreign invader substances, so they are compared as soldiers fighting diseases in the body.

Q194: The wall of the ventricle is …… than the wall of the atrium.

Source: RRB JE 2014
Correct! The human heart is a muscular organ, which is shaped like our fist. Our heart is four chambered, consisting of two atrium and two ventricles. The ventricles are larger than the atrium and their walls are also thicker than the atria because they have to pump blood out of the heart.
Incorrect. The human heart is a muscular organ, which is shaped like our fist. Our heart is four chambered, consisting of two atrium and two ventricles. The ventricles are larger than the atrium and their walls are also thicker than the atria because they have to pump blood out of the heart.

Q195: Karl Landsteiner is known for:

Source: RRB NTPC 07.04.2021 (Shift-I) Stage Ist
Correct! Karl Landsteiner, Austrian-American immunologist and pathologist received Nobel Prize for Physiology or Medicine in the year 1930 for his discovery of the major blood groups and development of the ABO system of blood.
Incorrect. Karl Landsteiner, Austrian-American immunologist and pathologist received Nobel Prize for Physiology or Medicine in the year 1930 for his discovery of the major blood groups and development of the ABO system of blood.

Q196: Which of the following is not true about WBC?

Source: RRB Group-D 10-10-2018 (Shift-II)
Correct! White Blood Cells (WBC) size is 12-17µm. Its shape and composition is amoebic or circular. They mainly act as soldiers in the body; kill germs and protect them from infection of diseases. The nuclei is found in their nucleus whereas it has no fixed shape.
Incorrect. White Blood Cells (WBC) size is 12-17µm. Its shape and composition is amoebic or circular. They mainly act as soldiers in the body; kill germs and protect them from infection of diseases. The nuclei is found in their nucleus whereas it has no fixed shape.

Q197: Which of the following statements is INCORRECT?

Source: RRB NTPC 18.01.2021 (Shift-II) Stage Ist
Correct! Blood brings oxygen and nutrients to all the parts of the body so they can keep working. Blood carries carbon dioxide and other waste materials to the lungs, kidneys and digestive system to be removed from the body. Blood fights infections and also carries hormones around the body.
Incorrect. Blood brings oxygen and nutrients to all the parts of the body so they can keep working. Blood carries carbon dioxide and other waste materials to the lungs, kidneys and digestive system to be removed from the body. Blood fights infections and also carries hormones around the body.

Q198: Which of the following is not true about the vascular system?

Source: RRB Group-D 03-10-2018 (Shift-I)
Correct! Blood is a type of fluid connective tissue. Plasma is the basic liquid part of the blood. Red blood cells (RBC), White blood cells (WBC) and platelets are suspended in Plasma. Plasma also contains proteins, salts and hormones. Blood carries gases, digested food, hormones and excretory substances from one part of the body to another.
Incorrect. Blood is a type of fluid connective tissue. Plasma is the basic liquid part of the blood. Red blood cells (RBC), White blood cells (WBC) and platelets are suspended in Plasma. Plasma also contains proteins, salts and hormones. Blood carries gases, digested food, hormones and excretory substances from one part of the body to another.

Q199: The heart is covered by two layers of membranes. What are these membranes called?

Source: RRB Group-D 01-11-2018 (Shift-II)
Correct! The heart is covered by two layers of membranes. These membranes are called pericardial membranes. It acts like a thin sac or a cover for the heart. The heart wall composed of three layers; Epicardium, Myocardium and Endocardium. It contains pericardial fluid, which protects the heart from the effects of contraction and expansion of the diaphragm of the lungs.
Incorrect. The heart is covered by two layers of membranes. These membranes are called pericardial membranes. It acts like a thin sac or a cover for the heart. The heart wall composed of three layers; Epicardium, Myocardium and Endocardium. It contains pericardial fluid, which protects the heart from the effects of contraction and expansion of the diaphragm of the lungs.

Q200: What are the micro-tubules called through which blood flows from the arteries into the veins?

Source: RRB JE 22.05.2019 (Shift-II)
Correct! The micro tubules through which blood flows from the arteries into the veins are called capillaries.
Incorrect. The micro tubules through which blood flows from the arteries into the veins are called capillaries.

Q201: Which of the following is NOT a part of the circulatory system?

Source: RRB NTPC 28.12.2020 (Shift-II) Stage Ist
Correct! Large intestine is not a part of circulatory system. The circulatory system consists of three independent systems that work together: the heart (cardiovascular), lungs (pulmonary), and arteries, veins, coronary and portal vessels (systemic). The system is responsible for the flow of blood, nutrients, oxygen and other gases, and as well as hormones to and from cells.
Incorrect. Large intestine is not a part of circulatory system. The circulatory system consists of three independent systems that work together: the heart (cardiovascular), lungs (pulmonary), and arteries, veins, coronary and portal vessels (systemic). The system is responsible for the flow of blood, nutrients, oxygen and other gases, and as well as hormones to and from cells.

Q202: Purkinje fibres areas specialized as:

Source: RRB JE 27.05.2019 (Shift-I)
Correct! Purkinje fibers are specialized in nerve fibres in the heart.
Incorrect. Purkinje fibers are specialized in nerve fibres in the heart.

Q203: What is the normal pulse rate of humans?

Source: RRB JE 28.05.2019 (Shift-I)
Correct! The normal pulse rate of humans is 70–80 beats per minute.
Incorrect. The normal pulse rate of humans is 70–80 beats per minute.

Q204: What are the small blood vessels under our skin called?

Source: RRB JE 02.06.2019 (Shift-I)
Correct! The small blood vessels under our skin are called capillaries.
Incorrect. The small blood vessels under our skin are called capillaries.

Q205: Which among devices controls the heart rate of patients?

Source: RRB JE 27.05.2019 (Shift-IV)
Correct! The pacemaker device controls the heart rate of patients.
Incorrect. The pacemaker device controls the heart rate of patients.

Q206: Which of the following carries blood from the heart to the kidneys?

Source: RRB NTPC 22.02.2021 (Shift-II) Stage Ist
Correct! Blood vessel is a vessel in the human or animal body in which blood circulates. The vesseles that carry blood away from the heart are called arteries and their small branches are arterioles. The Renal arteries are the part of circulatory system. They carry large amounts of blood from the aorta (hearts main artery) to the kidneys.
Incorrect. Blood vessel is a vessel in the human or animal body in which blood circulates. The vesseles that carry blood away from the heart are called arteries and their small branches are arterioles. The Renal arteries are the part of circulatory system. They carry large amounts of blood from the aorta (hearts main artery) to the kidneys.

Q207: Pulse beat is measured by ……….

Source: RRB JE 02.06.2019 (Shift-IV)
Correct! Pulse beat is measured by artery. RRB Science Planner Biology YCT 554 (iii) Respiratory System
Incorrect. Pulse beat is measured by artery. RRB Science Planner Biology YCT 554 (iii) Respiratory System

Q208: The full form of ATP is –––––––.

Source: RRB Group-D 27-09-2022 (Shift-II)
Correct! The full form of ATP is Adenosine Triphosphate. ATP is the source of energy for use and storage at the cellular level. The structure of ATP is a nucleoside tri phosphate, consisting of a nitrogenous base (adenine) a ribose sugar, and three serially bonded phosphate groups. ATP is commonly referred to as the "energy currency" of the cell.
Incorrect. The full form of ATP is Adenosine Triphosphate. ATP is the source of energy for use and storage at the cellular level. The structure of ATP is a nucleoside tri phosphate, consisting of a nitrogenous base (adenine) a ribose sugar, and three serially bonded phosphate groups. ATP is commonly referred to as the "energy currency" of the cell.

Q209: Systolic pressure is a measure of ______

Source: RRB Group-D– 13/09/2022 (Shift-III)
Correct! Systolic pressure is a measure of ventricular contraction. Blood pressure is the pressure of blood pushing against the walls of the arteries. Arteries carry blood from the heart to othe parts of the body. A normal blood pressure is 120/80 mmHg.
Incorrect. Systolic pressure is a measure of ventricular contraction. Blood pressure is the pressure of blood pushing against the walls of the arteries. Arteries carry blood from the heart to othe parts of the body. A normal blood pressure is 120/80 mmHg.

Q210: Which of the following are the three-carbon molecules formed during respiration?

Source: RRB Group-D 27-09-2022 (Shift-III)
Correct! Lactic acid and pyruvate are the three-carbon molecules formed during respiration. The breakdown of glucose, a six-carbon molecule, into a three-carbon molecule called pyruvate takes place, in cytoplasm. The break up of three-carbon pyruvate molecule to give three molecules of CO2 takes place in the mitochondria.
Incorrect. Lactic acid and pyruvate are the three-carbon molecules formed during respiration. The breakdown of glucose, a six-carbon molecule, into a three-carbon molecule called pyruvate takes place, in cytoplasm. The break up of three-carbon pyruvate molecule to give three molecules of CO2 takes place in the mitochondria.

Q211: In which cell organelle, the first step of cellular respiration into a three-carbon molecule called pyruvate takes place?

Source: RRB Group-D 27-09-2022 (Shift-I)
Correct! The 1st stage of cellular respiration is glycolysis. In which a carbon molecule being broken down into two 3 carbon pyruvate molecules. ATP is produced in this process which takes place in the cytosol of the cytoplasm.
Incorrect. The 1st stage of cellular respiration is glycolysis. In which a carbon molecule being broken down into two 3 carbon pyruvate molecules. ATP is produced in this process which takes place in the cytosol of the cytoplasm.

Q212: In terrestrial animals, exchange of gases takes place by diffusion. Which among the following statements are true about respiration in these animals?

Source: RRB Group-D 14-09-2022 (Shift-II)
Correct! In terrestrial animals, respiration occurs through the process of diffusion. The diffusion process occurs through their surface because they have fine and delicate surface that enables exchange of gases and these animals may have passage for flow of air.
Incorrect. In terrestrial animals, respiration occurs through the process of diffusion. The diffusion process occurs through their surface because they have fine and delicate surface that enables exchange of gases and these animals may have passage for flow of air.

Q213: Which of the following statements is INCORRECT?

Source: RRB Group-D 14-09-2022 (Shift-II)
Correct! Carbon dioxide is more soluble in water than oxygen. When pyruvate breaks in mitochondria, it convert into lactic acid and gives three carbon molecule. The respiratory pigment is present in the Red corpuscles, hence statement-(c) is incorrect, while the rest given statements are correct.
Incorrect. Carbon dioxide is more soluble in water than oxygen. When pyruvate breaks in mitochondria, it convert into lactic acid and gives three carbon molecule. The respiratory pigment is present in the Red corpuscles, hence statement-(c) is incorrect, while the rest given statements are correct.

Q214: Which of the following statements is correct with reference to aerobic respiration?

Source: RRB Group-D 12-09-2022 (Shift-I)
Correct! Respiration involves chemical reactions that breakdown nutrient molecule in dividing cells to release energy. Respiration is basically of two types: (1) Aerobic respiration, and (2) Anaerobic respiration. Aerobic respiration takes place in the presence of oxygen. Most of the reaction in aerobic respiration happen inside Mitochondria where one molecule of pyruvate breaks down to give three molecules of carbon dioxide. The amount of released energy in aerobic respiration is more than that in anaerobic respiration.
Incorrect. Respiration involves chemical reactions that breakdown nutrient molecule in dividing cells to release energy. Respiration is basically of two types: (1) Aerobic respiration, and (2) Anaerobic respiration. Aerobic respiration takes place in the presence of oxygen. Most of the reaction in aerobic respiration happen inside Mitochondria where one molecule of pyruvate breaks down to give three molecules of carbon dioxide. The amount of released energy in aerobic respiration is more than that in anaerobic respiration.

Incorrect. Aerobic respiration is the process that leads to a complete oxidation of organic substances in the presence of oxygen, and releases CO2, water and a large amount of energy present in the substrate.

Q218: What is the reason that the lungs have alveoli?

Source: RRB Group-D 07-10-2022 (Shift-III)
Correct! The reason that the lungs have alveoli is to increase the surface area. The alveoli are where the lungs and the blood exchange oxygen and carbon dioxide during the process of breathing in and breathing out.
Incorrect. The reason that the lungs have alveoli is to increase the surface area. The alveoli are where the lungs and the blood exchange oxygen and carbon dioxide during the process of breathing in and breathing out.

Q219: What happens when we exhale during normal breathing?

Incorrect. When the lungs exhale, during normal breathing a residual amount of air remains in the lungs.

Q220: Name the process through which gaseous exchange takes place across the cell membrane.

Source: RRB Group-D 19-09-2022 (Shift-III)
Correct! Gas exchange occurs by diffusion across cell membranes. Gas exchange is the biological process through which gases are transferred across cell membranes to either enter or leave the blood.
Incorrect. Gas exchange occurs by diffusion across cell membranes. Gas exchange is the biological process through which gases are transferred across cell membranes to either enter or leave the blood.

Q222: Which of the following is the common product produced during aerobic and anaerobic respiration initially in the first step?

Source: RRB Group-D 23-08-2022 (Shift-II)
Correct! Pyruvate is the common product produced during aerobic and anaerobic respiration initially in the first step. Pyruvate is the end product of glycolysis and is derived from additional sources in cellular cytoplasm, and is ultimately destined for transport into mitochondria.
Incorrect. Pyruvate is the common product produced during aerobic and anaerobic respiration initially in the first step. Pyruvate is the end product of glycolysis and is derived from additional sources in cellular cytoplasm, and is ultimately destined for transport into mitochondria.

Q223: Anaerobic respiration of glucose in the muscles produces –––––––––––.

Source: RRB Group-D 28-09-2022 (Shift-II)
Correct! Anaerobic respiration of glucose in the muscles produces lactic acid. Anaerobic respiration does not use oxygen to produce energy. Cellular respiration
Incorrect. Anaerobic respiration of glucose in the muscles produces lactic acid. Anaerobic respiration does not use oxygen to produce energy. Cellular respiration

Q224: Which of the following is required for the breakdown of glucose in human cells to provide energy?

Source: RRB Group-D– 16/09/2022 (Shift-II)
Correct! Oxygen is required for the breakdown of glucose in human cells to provide energy. Cellular respiration is the process in which cells breakdown molecules for energy. The cell use oxygen to breakdown food in the form of glucose to produce water and release carbon dioxide.
Incorrect. Oxygen is required for the breakdown of glucose in human cells to provide energy. Cellular respiration is the process in which cells breakdown molecules for energy. The cell use oxygen to breakdown food in the form of glucose to produce water and release carbon dioxide.

Q225: Through which organ is air taken into the body of human beings?

Source: RRB Group-D– 16/09/2022 (Shift-II)
Correct! Air is taken into the body of human beings through the organ, 'Nostrils'. Nostrils are the openings to the nasal cavities that are on the face.
Incorrect. Air is taken into the body of human beings through the organ, 'Nostrils'. Nostrils are the openings to the nasal cavities that are on the face.

Q226: Where in a human body can anaerobic respiration take place?

Source: RRB Group-D– 30/09/2022 (Shift-II)
Correct! Anaerobic respiration, which takes place in the cytoplasm of cells, can occur in the absence of oxygen, as it only requires glucose. In animal cells, anaerobic respiration produces lactic acid. Aerobic respiration occur in the mitochondria of all cells.
Incorrect. Anaerobic respiration, which takes place in the cytoplasm of cells, can occur in the absence of oxygen, as it only requires glucose. In animal cells, anaerobic respiration produces lactic acid. Aerobic respiration occur in the mitochondria of all cells.

Q227: During the process of respiration, how many oxygen molecules combine with one molecule of glucose ?

Source: RRB Group-D– 08/09/2022 (Shift-II)
Correct! During the process of respiration, one molecule of glucose is oxidized with the help of six oxygen molecules to produce six molecules of carbon dioxide. C6H12O6 + 6O2 → 6 CO2 + 6H2O + 38 ATP energy.
Incorrect. During the process of respiration, one molecule of glucose is oxidized with the help of six oxygen molecules to produce six molecules of carbon dioxide. C6H12O6 + 6O2 → 6 CO2 + 6H2O + 38 ATP energy.

Q228: Which of the following statements is FALSE?

Source: RRB Group-D– 17/08/2022 (Shift-III)
Correct! The first step of cellular respiration is called glycolyis, it occurs in cytoplasm of the cell. In this process, a glucose molecule is broken down into pyruvic acid. In fermentation process sugar is broken down by enzymes of micro-organisms in the absence of oxygen. Therefore statements (1), (3) and (4) are correct but statement (2) is incorrect, as Mitochondria are the cellular organelles that synthesize ATP for our cells.
Incorrect. The first step of cellular respiration is called glycolyis, it occurs in cytoplasm of the cell. In this process, a glucose molecule is broken down into pyruvic acid. In fermentation process sugar is broken down by enzymes of micro-organisms in the absence of oxygen. Therefore statements (1), (3) and (4) are correct but statement (2) is incorrect, as Mitochondria are the cellular organelles that synthesize ATP for our cells.

Q229: What part of the respiratory system prevents the air-passage from collapsing?

Source: RRB Group-D– 17/08/2022 (Shift-I)
Correct! The part which prevents the air-passage in our respiratory system from collapsing are the ring's of cartilage. Trachea is also known as windpipe, and the cartilage rings are present in the trachea that prevent it from collapsing. This enables the lumen of the trachea to stay open during breathing.
Incorrect. The part which prevents the air-passage in our respiratory system from collapsing are the ring's of cartilage. Trachea is also known as windpipe, and the cartilage rings are present in the trachea that prevent it from collapsing. This enables the lumen of the trachea to stay open during breathing.
