Q231: All of the statements given below regarding inhalation in humans are correct except one. Which one is NOT correct? A. Ribs move inward and diaphragm is raised B. Ribs are lifted up and diaphragm becomes flat C. Chest cavity becomes larger D. Air is sucked into the lungs

Source: RRB Group-D– 26/08/2022 (Shift-III)
Correct! During inhalation the diaphragm flattens and the ribs move upwards and outwards due to contraction of the intercostals muscles. This increases the volume of the thoracic activity and the pressure decreases. As the outside pressure is higher, air gushes into the lungs. Hence statement (a) is NOT correct while rest of the statements about the 'Inhalation' holds true.
Incorrect. During inhalation the diaphragm flattens and the ribs move upwards and outwards due to contraction of the intercostals muscles. This increases the volume of the thoracic activity and the pressure decreases. As the outside pressure is higher, air gushes into the lungs. Hence statement (a) is NOT correct while rest of the statements about the 'Inhalation' holds true.

Q232: During each breathing cycle, when air is taken in and thrown out, the lungs always contain some amount of air so that there is sufficient time for oxygen to be absorbed and carbon dioxide to be released. What is this amount of air called?

Source: RRB Group-D– 05/09/2022 (Shift-II)
Correct! Residual volume (RV) is the volume of air remaining in the lungs after maximum forceful expiration. In other words, it is the volume of air that cannot be expelled from the lungs, thus causing the alveoli to remain open at all times.
Incorrect. Residual volume (RV) is the volume of air remaining in the lungs after maximum forceful expiration. In other words, it is the volume of air that cannot be expelled from the lungs, thus causing the alveoli to remain open at all times.

Q233: Breathing is harder at high altitudes compared to the sea level because .............

Source: RRB Group-D– 22/09/2022 (Shift-III)
Correct! Breathing is harder at high attitudes compared to the sea level because the atmosphere is less dense at high altitudes.
Incorrect. Breathing is harder at high attitudes compared to the sea level because the atmosphere is less dense at high altitudes.

Q234: What is the role of cilia in the respiratory tract?

Source: RRB Group-D– 22/09/2022 (Shift-III)
Correct! The role of cilia in the respiratory tract is that it sweep mucus from the lungs and airway towards the nose.
Incorrect. The role of cilia in the respiratory tract is that it sweep mucus from the lungs and airway towards the nose.

Q235: Some features of a respiratory surface in animals are mentioned below. Select the INCORRECT option.

Source: RRB Group-D– 02/09/2022 (Shift-II)
Correct! All respiratory organs have large surface area to get enough oxygen or help with the exchange of gases. They are thin – walled for easy diffusion of gases and substances. They have rich supply of blood or the conducting fluid present in the body for transporting respiratory gases to the tissues of the body. Hence, option (b) is the right answer.
Incorrect. All respiratory organs have large surface area to get enough oxygen or help with the exchange of gases. They are thin – walled for easy diffusion of gases and substances. They have rich supply of blood or the conducting fluid present in the body for transporting respiratory gases to the tissues of the body. Hence, option (b) is the right answer.

Q236: Which of the following gases is essential for all aerobic forms of life ?

Source: RRB Group-D– 08/09/2022 (Shift-III)
Correct! Oxygen (O2) is the gas present in air that is essential for aerobic respiration. Aerobic respiration is the release of energy from glucose or another organic substrate in the presence of oxygen. Respiration is essential for all aerobic forms of life.
Incorrect. Oxygen (O2) is the gas present in air that is essential for aerobic respiration. Aerobic respiration is the release of energy from glucose or another organic substrate in the presence of oxygen. Respiration is essential for all aerobic forms of life.

Q237: Which of the following has the fastest breathing rate ?

Source: RRB Group-D– 08/09/2022 (Shift-I)
Correct! The breathing rate of aquatic animal is faster than the of terrestrial animals because the amount of dissolved oxygen in the water is much less than the amount on land, so they have to breath more in order to get more oxygen. Fish has the fastest breathing rate in given options.
Incorrect. The breathing rate of aquatic animal is faster than the of terrestrial animals because the amount of dissolved oxygen in the water is much less than the amount on land, so they have to breath more in order to get more oxygen. Fish has the fastest breathing rate in given options.

Q238: The lebelling for the parts a, b and c of the human respiratory system shown below are given as options. Identify the correct option.

Source: RRB Group-D– 09/09/2022 (Shift-III)
Correct! Pharynx-Soft area at the top of throat, where the passages to the nose and mouth connect with the throat. Larynx-Voicebox or glottis is a passageway for air between pharynx and trachea Trachea- tube that carries air to the lungs
Incorrect. Pharynx-Soft area at the top of throat, where the passages to the nose and mouth connect with the throat. Larynx-Voicebox or glottis is a passageway for air between pharynx and trachea Trachea- tube that carries air to the lungs

Q239: In humans, respiratory pigments are:

Source: RRB ALP & Tec. (30-08-18 Shift-I)
Correct! The respiratory pigment found in humans is hemoglobin. It is a metal protein transporting iron- containing oxygen found in the red blood cells (RBCs) of the human body. The hemoglobin present in the blood, transports oxygen from the lungs to the rest of the body. The red colour of RBCs is due to a pigment called 'heme' of hemoglobin.
Incorrect. The respiratory pigment found in humans is hemoglobin. It is a metal protein transporting iron- containing oxygen found in the red blood cells (RBCs) of the human body. The hemoglobin present in the blood, transports oxygen from the lungs to the rest of the body. The red colour of RBCs is due to a pigment called 'heme' of hemoglobin.

Q240: The breakdown of glucose to pyruvate takes place in the …………… during energy production.

Source: RRB ALP & Tec. (30-08-18 Shift-III)
Correct! The breakdown of glucose to pyruvate takes place in the cytoplasm during energy production.The process of glycolysis takes place in the cytoplasm. Glycolysis- In this process, two molecules of pyruvic acid are formed from one molecule of glucose. This reaction does not require oxygen. Therefore, this process is similar in anaerobic respiration and aerobic respiration. This entire process takes place in cytoplasm. The discovery of glycolysis was carried out by three German biologists, Gustav Embden, Otto Meyerhof, and Jakub Karol Parnas. It is also called the EMP path.
Incorrect. The breakdown of glucose to pyruvate takes place in the cytoplasm during energy production.The process of glycolysis takes place in the cytoplasm. Glycolysis- In this process, two molecules of pyruvic acid are formed from one molecule of glucose. This reaction does not require oxygen. Therefore, this process is similar in anaerobic respiration and aerobic respiration. This entire process takes place in cytoplasm. The discovery of glycolysis was carried out by three German biologists, Gustav Embden, Otto Meyerhof, and Jakub Karol Parnas. It is also called the EMP path.

Q241: Trachea is part of which of the following human systems?

Source: RRB NTPC 31.07.2021 (Shift-I) Stage Ist
Correct! The trachea is part of the lower respiratory tract, along with the lungs, bronchi, bronchioles, and alveoli.
Incorrect. The trachea is part of the lower respiratory tract, along with the lungs, bronchi, bronchioles, and alveoli.

Q242: Trachea is a part of the ______ system of the human body.

Source: RRB NTPC 05.03.2021 (Shift-II) Stage Ist
Correct! Trachea is a part of the respiratory system of the human body. Trachea, commonly known as the windpipe, is a tube about 4 inches long and less than an inch in diameter in most people. The trachea begins just under the larynx (voice box) and runs down behind the breastbone (sternum). The trachea then divides into two smaller tubes called bronchi: one bronchus for each lung. The trachea is composed of about 20 rings of tough cartilage. The back part of each ring is made of muscle and connective tissue. Moist, smooth tissue called mucosa lines the inside of the trachea. The trachea widens and lengthens slightly with each breath in, returning to its resting size with each breath out.
Incorrect. Trachea is a part of the respiratory system of the human body. Trachea, commonly known as the windpipe, is a tube about 4 inches long and less than an inch in diameter in most people. The trachea begins just under the larynx (voice box) and runs down behind the breastbone (sternum). The trachea then divides into two smaller tubes called bronchi: one bronchus for each lung. The trachea is composed of about 20 rings of tough cartilage. The back part of each ring is made of muscle and connective tissue. Moist, smooth tissue called mucosa lines the inside of the trachea. The trachea widens and lengthens slightly with each breath in, returning to its resting size with each breath out.

Q243: The maximum amount of air that can be exhaled after maximal inspiration, is called ... ... ... .

Source: RRB JE 27.05.2019 (Shift-I)
Correct! The maximum amount of air that can be exhaled after the maximal inspiration, is called lung volume.
Incorrect. The maximum amount of air that can be exhaled after the maximal inspiration, is called lung volume.

Q244: Our lungs contain …… cells.

Source: RRB NTPC Stage Ist 29.04.2016 (Shift-II)
Correct! There are 300 million cells in our lungs. As the bronchial tubes pass through lungs, they divide into smaller air passages called bronchioles. The bronchioles end in tiny balloon-like air sacs called alveoli. Human lungs have about 600 million alveoli.Thus, about 400– 800 ft2 surface area is available for the exchange of respiratory gases in human lungs.
Incorrect. There are 300 million cells in our lungs. As the bronchial tubes pass through lungs, they divide into smaller air passages called bronchioles. The bronchioles end in tiny balloon-like air sacs called alveoli. Human lungs have about 600 million alveoli.Thus, about 400– 800 ft2 surface area is available for the exchange of respiratory gases in human lungs.

Q245: Which of the following is included in exhale?

Source: RRB NTPC 16.04.2016 (Shift-I) Stage Ist
Correct! Nitrogen gas is included in the exhale. The main function of the lungs is to perform the exchange of oxygen and carbon dioxide with air from the atmosphere.
Incorrect. Nitrogen gas is included in the exhale. The main function of the lungs is to perform the exchange of oxygen and carbon dioxide with air from the atmosphere.

Q246: Inflammation of the mucous membrane is called ………

Source: RRB NTPC 19.04.2016 (Shift-I) Stage Ist
Correct! Inflammation of the mucous membrane is called bronchitis. It is related to respiratory inflammation. It causes inflammation in the respiratory tract, which causes breathing problems. Hepatitis - Hepatitis is inflammation of the liver tissue. Iritis- Relates to inflammation of the eye. Gastritis- is associated with inflammation of the stomach.
Incorrect. Inflammation of the mucous membrane is called bronchitis. It is related to respiratory inflammation. It causes inflammation in the respiratory tract, which causes breathing problems. Hepatitis - Hepatitis is inflammation of the liver tissue. Iritis- Relates to inflammation of the eye. Gastritis- is associated with inflammation of the stomach.

Q247: When respiration takes place even in the absence of oxygen, it is called ______ respiration.

Source: RRB NTPC 23.01.2021 (Shift-I) Stage Ist
Correct! Anaerobic respiration is the type of respiration through which cells can break down sugars to generate energy in the absence of oxygen. Aerobic respiration is the process by which organisms use oxygen to turn fuel, such as fats and sugars, into chemical energy.
Incorrect. Anaerobic respiration is the type of respiration through which cells can break down sugars to generate energy in the absence of oxygen. Aerobic respiration is the process by which organisms use oxygen to turn fuel, such as fats and sugars, into chemical energy.

Q248: In the respiration process, complex organic compounds such as glucose are broken down to provide energy in the form of______ .

Source: RRB NTPC 09.01.2021 (Shift-I) Stage Ist
Correct! During the process of respiration, the complex carbon compounds usually break into the form of ATP (Adenosine - Tri Phosphate). ATP is the energy currency of cell. It is a organic compound composed of the phosphate groups, adenine and the sugar ribose.
Incorrect. During the process of respiration, the complex carbon compounds usually break into the form of ATP (Adenosine - Tri Phosphate). ATP is the energy currency of cell. It is a organic compound composed of the phosphate groups, adenine and the sugar ribose.

Q249: When does aerobic respiration take place?

Source: RRB NTPC 02.03.2021 (Shift-II) Stage Ist
Correct! Respiration releases energy stored in glucose and without it these cells would die. There are two types of respiration: Aerobic respiration occurs in the presence of oxygen and in most cells most of the time. Anaerobic respiration occurs without oxygen and much less frequently than aerobic respiration.
Incorrect. Respiration releases energy stored in glucose and without it these cells would die. There are two types of respiration: Aerobic respiration occurs in the presence of oxygen and in most cells most of the time. Anaerobic respiration occurs without oxygen and much less frequently than aerobic respiration.

Q250: Diffusion is a process by which:

Source: RRB NTPC 03.03.2021 (Shift-I) Stage Ist
Correct! Diffusion is the movement of molecules from higher concentration to lower concentration. This is due to the random movement of the molecules. This process occurs throughout the plasma membrane. Some examples of diffusion are, on opening the old drink bottles the CO2 diffuses in the air, sugar gets dissolved evenly and sweetens the water when dissolved in it etc.
Incorrect. Diffusion is the movement of molecules from higher concentration to lower concentration. This is due to the random movement of the molecules. This process occurs throughout the plasma membrane. Some examples of diffusion are, on opening the old drink bottles the CO2 diffuses in the air, sugar gets dissolved evenly and sweetens the water when dissolved in it etc.

Q251: What is exhaled in human respiration?

Source: RRB NTPC 05.04.2016 (Shift-III) Stage Ist
Correct! The gas exhaled by humans into respiration is carbon dioxide.
Incorrect. The gas exhaled by humans into respiration is carbon dioxide.

Q252: What is the function of alveoli?

Source: RRB NTPC 04.02.2021 (Shift-I) Stage Ist
Correct! Alveoli are tiny sacs within our lungs that provide a surface where exchange of gases take place, allow oxygen and carbon dioxide to move between the lungs and bloodstream. There are three overall processes involved in breathing: - moving air in and out of lungs (ventilation) - oxygen-carbon dioxide exchange (diffusion) - pumping blood through lungs (perfusion) Alveoli are the center of respiratory system’s gas exchange. The alveoli pick up the incoming energy (oxygen) breathe in and release the outgoing waste product (carbon dioxide) breathe out.
Incorrect. Alveoli are tiny sacs within our lungs that provide a surface where exchange of gases take place, allow oxygen and carbon dioxide to move between the lungs and bloodstream. There are three overall processes involved in breathing: - moving air in and out of lungs (ventilation) - oxygen-carbon dioxide exchange (diffusion) - pumping blood through lungs (perfusion) Alveoli are the center of respiratory system’s gas exchange. The alveoli pick up the incoming energy (oxygen) breathe in and release the outgoing waste product (carbon dioxide) breathe out.

Q253: Which life process converts chemical energy into heat energy?

Source: RRB Group-D 01-10-2018 (Shift-I)
Correct! Respiration takes place inside the cell of organisms, in which nutrients are used to obtain biochemical energy. There are two types of respiration: Anaerobic respiration and Aerobic respiration
Incorrect. Respiration takes place inside the cell of organisms, in which nutrients are used to obtain biochemical energy. There are two types of respiration: Anaerobic respiration and Aerobic respiration

Q254: What is aerobic respiration?

Source: RRB JE 23.05.2019 (Shift-I)
Correct! See the explanation of above question. RRB Science Planner Biology YCT 559
Incorrect. See the explanation of above question. RRB Science Planner Biology YCT 559

Q255: Where does breakdown of pyruvic acid occur, using energy?

Source: RRB Group-D 24-09-2018 (Shift-II)
Correct! Using energy, breakdown of pyruvic acid occurs in mitochondria. This process takes place in Krebs cycle. Krebs cycle is also called the tricarboxylic acid cycle. Krebs cycle was discovered by British scientist Hans Krebs in 1937 AD. Mitochondria stores energy in the form of ATP, hence it is also called ‘Power House of the Cell’.
Incorrect. Using energy, breakdown of pyruvic acid occurs in mitochondria. This process takes place in Krebs cycle. Krebs cycle is also called the tricarboxylic acid cycle. Krebs cycle was discovered by British scientist Hans Krebs in 1937 AD. Mitochondria stores energy in the form of ATP, hence it is also called ‘Power House of the Cell’.

Q256: The incomplete breakdown of the substance in the absence of oxygen is called ……….

Source: RRB Group-D 05-10-2018 (Shift-II)
Correct! Respiration in the absence of oxygen is called anaerobic respiration. There is incomplete oxidation of glucose done by anaerobic respiration and as a result, two molecules of CO2 and ethyl alcohol are produced from one molecule of glucose. C6H12O6 → 2C2H5OH + 2CO2 + 56 K.Cal energy This process occurs in the presence of bacteria or yeast cells.
Incorrect. Respiration in the absence of oxygen is called anaerobic respiration. There is incomplete oxidation of glucose done by anaerobic respiration and as a result, two molecules of CO2 and ethyl alcohol are produced from one molecule of glucose. C6H12O6 → 2C2H5OH + 2CO2 + 56 K.Cal energy This process occurs in the presence of bacteria or yeast cells.

Q257: When our muscle cells lack oxygen during energy production, the 6-carbon molecule is converted into ............. carbon molecule.

Source: RRB Group-D 18-09-2018 (Shift-III)
Correct! During energy production, when our muscle cells are deficient in oxygen, the 6-carbon molecule is converted into a 3-carbon molecule.
Incorrect. During energy production, when our muscle cells are deficient in oxygen, the 6-carbon molecule is converted into a 3-carbon molecule.

Q258: During inhalation, lungs are filled with air due to…

Source: RRB Group-D 31-10-2018 (Shift-I)
Correct! Upon inhalation, the diaphragm contracts and flattens and the chest cavity enlarges. This contraction creates vaccum, which pulls air into the lungs upon exhalation, the diaphragm relaxes and return to its original shape, and air is forced out of the lungs.
Incorrect. Upon inhalation, the diaphragm contracts and flattens and the chest cavity enlarges. This contraction creates vaccum, which pulls air into the lungs upon exhalation, the diaphragm relaxes and return to its original shape, and air is forced out of the lungs.

Q259: Exhalation occurs by ………….

Source: RRB Group-D 19-09-2018 (Shift-III)
Correct! Exhalation occurs by lung deflation (contraction). Mammals have a pair of flexible and spongy lungs, through which air is inhaled and exhaled at a fixed rate, which is called breathing. Breathing takes place in two parts viz., inhalation and exhalation.
Incorrect. Exhalation occurs by lung deflation (contraction). Mammals have a pair of flexible and spongy lungs, through which air is inhaled and exhaled at a fixed rate, which is called breathing. Breathing takes place in two parts viz., inhalation and exhalation.

Q260: The breathing process involves –––––.

Source: RRB Group-D 30-10-2018 (Shift-III)
Correct! The breathing process involves inspiration and expiration.
Incorrect. The breathing process involves inspiration and expiration.

Q261: In the human body, inspiration respiratory and expiratory pigment is. . . .

Source: RRB Group-D 27-09-2018 (Shift-III)
Correct! All the cells of RBCs in the human body are filled with hemoglobin. Hemoglobin is made up of the pigment called 'heme' and the iron-rich protein globin. The blood is red in colour due to ‘heme’ pigment, while iron-rich protein globin has the unique ability to combine oxygen and carbon dioxide, that is why blood circulates respiratory gases in the body.
Incorrect. All the cells of RBCs in the human body are filled with hemoglobin. Hemoglobin is made up of the pigment called 'heme' and the iron-rich protein globin. The blood is red in colour due to ‘heme’ pigment, while iron-rich protein globin has the unique ability to combine oxygen and carbon dioxide, that is why blood circulates respiratory gases in the body.

Q262: Which one of the following connects O2 to provide energy in our body?

Source: RRB Group-D 05-11-2018 (Shift-III)
Correct! Glucose binds O2 to provide energy in our body. Glucose is the simplest carbohydrate. It is soluble in water and its chemical formula is C6H12O6. It is sweet in taste and is the primary source of energy for living cells.
Incorrect. Glucose binds O2 to provide energy in our body. Glucose is the simplest carbohydrate. It is soluble in water and its chemical formula is C6H12O6. It is sweet in taste and is the primary source of energy for living cells.

Q263: Anaerobic respiration occurs in the absence of……….. .

Source: RRB Group-D 30-10-2018 (Shift-II)
Correct! Anaerobic respiration is the metabolic process in which oxygen is absent, and only the stage of glycolysis is completed. This occurs in micro- organisms, but is also a temporary response to oxygen- less condition in the cells of multicellular organisms, such as humans.The respiratory process of pneumatic organisms uses molecular oxygen, which is a very powerful oxidizing agent. (iv) Excretory System
Incorrect. Anaerobic respiration is the metabolic process in which oxygen is absent, and only the stage of glycolysis is completed. This occurs in micro- organisms, but is also a temporary response to oxygen- less condition in the cells of multicellular organisms, such as humans.The respiratory process of pneumatic organisms uses molecular oxygen, which is a very powerful oxidizing agent. (iv) Excretory System

Q264: How is urea removed from the blood by an artificial kidney?

Source: RRB Group-D– 30/09/2022 (Shift-I)
Correct! Urea is removed from the blood by an artificial kidney by osmosis. The process of filtering or removing the waste accumulated in the blood of patients a series of tubule made up of semi permeable membrane are placed in a dialysis solution to remove the waste and purified blood is pumped back into the body whose kidneys are functioning at low levels is called hemodialysis.
Incorrect. Urea is removed from the blood by an artificial kidney by osmosis. The process of filtering or removing the waste accumulated in the blood of patients a series of tubule made up of semi permeable membrane are placed in a dialysis solution to remove the waste and purified blood is pumped back into the body whose kidneys are functioning at low levels is called hemodialysis.

Q265: Which of the following part connects the urinary bladder and the kidney?

Source: RRB Group-D 17-09-2022 (Shift-II)
Correct! Ureter connects the urinary bladder and the kidney. It transports urine from the renal pelvis into the bladder. The muscular layers are responsible for the peristaltic activity that the ureter uses to move the urine from the kidneys to the bladder. RRB Science Planner Biology YCT 560
Incorrect. Ureter connects the urinary bladder and the kidney. It transports urine from the renal pelvis into the bladder. The muscular layers are responsible for the peristaltic activity that the ureter uses to move the urine from the kidneys to the bladder. RRB Science Planner Biology YCT 560

Q266: The method of removal of nitrogenous waste using Artificial kidney is known as ________.

Source: RRB Group-D 27-09-2022 (Shift-II)
Correct! Hemodialysis is a procedure where a dialysis machine and a special filter called an artificial kidney, or a dialyzer, are used to clean your blood. It is a treatment to filter wastes and water from your blood.
Incorrect. Hemodialysis is a procedure where a dialysis machine and a special filter called an artificial kidney, or a dialyzer, are used to clean your blood. It is a treatment to filter wastes and water from your blood.

Q267: Which letter represents the region Bowman's capsule in the diagram below?

Source: RRB Group-D 12-09-2022 (Shift-I)
Correct! Bowman's capsule is a cup like sac at the beginning of the tubular component of a nephron in the mammalian kidney that performs the first step in the filtration of blood to form urine. In the given figure all region (a) is known as Bowman's capsule.
Incorrect. Bowman's capsule is a cup like sac at the beginning of the tubular component of a nephron in the mammalian kidney that performs the first step in the filtration of blood to form urine. In the given figure all region (a) is known as Bowman's capsule.

Q268: Which of the following statements is INCORRECT?

Source: RRB Group-D 12-09-2022 (Shift-II)
Correct! The human excretory system includes a pair of kidneys, a pair of ureters, a urinary bladder and a urethra. Kidneys are located in the abdomen one on either side of backbone. The amount of the filtrate formed by the kidneys per minute is called glomerular filtration rate (GFR). GFR in a healthy individual is approximately 125 ml/minute i.e. 180 liters per day. Each kidney has large number of the filtration units called nephrons packed close together.
Incorrect. The human excretory system includes a pair of kidneys, a pair of ureters, a urinary bladder and a urethra. Kidneys are located in the abdomen one on either side of backbone. The amount of the filtrate formed by the kidneys per minute is called glomerular filtration rate (GFR). GFR in a healthy individual is approximately 125 ml/minute i.e. 180 liters per day. Each kidney has large number of the filtration units called nephrons packed close together.

Q269: Dialysis is the procedure done to remove the waste products from the blood when the normal functioning of kidneys is affected. The steps of dialysis are given below but not in proper order. Which option shows the correct sequence of these steps? a) Line to vein b) Patient’s blood passed through a tank with dialyzing fluid c) Line from artery d) Waste products from the blood pass into dialyzing fluid e) Dialyzing fluid has same osmotic pressure as blood except the wastes

Source: RRB Group-D 17-09-2022 (Shift-I)
Correct! Correct steps for dialysis of kidney are - * Line from artery * Patient's blood passed through a tank with dialyzing fluid. * Dialyzing fluid has same osmotic pressure as blood except the wastes. * Waste products from the blood pass into dialyzing fluid. * Line to vein.
Incorrect. Correct steps for dialysis of kidney are - * Line from artery * Patient's blood passed through a tank with dialyzing fluid. * Dialyzing fluid has same osmotic pressure as blood except the wastes. * Waste products from the blood pass into dialyzing fluid. * Line to vein.

Q270: Urine is composed of _____ water.

Source: RRB Group-D 30-08-2022 (Shift-III)
Correct! Human urine is composed primarily of water (95%). The rest is urea (2%), creatinine (0.1%), uric acid (0.03%), chloride, sodium, potassium, sulphate, ammonium, phosphate and other ions and molecules in lesser amounts.
Incorrect. Human urine is composed primarily of water (95%). The rest is urea (2%), creatinine (0.1%), uric acid (0.03%), chloride, sodium, potassium, sulphate, ammonium, phosphate and other ions and molecules in lesser amounts.

Q271: The following figure shows a human nephron. Which part is the collecting duct?

Source: RRB Group-D 19-09-2022 (Shift-III)
Correct! In given figure of a human nephron region a is collecting duct. Region b is glomerulus and region c is distal convoluted tubule while region d is loop of Henle.
Incorrect. In given figure of a human nephron region a is collecting duct. Region b is glomerulus and region c is distal convoluted tubule while region d is loop of Henle.

Q272: Kidney is an organ of excretion and osmoregulation in human. Regulation of which two substances is done by the kidneys?

Source: RRB Group-D 23-08-2022 (Shift-I)
Correct! Kidney is an organ of excretion and osmoregulation in humans. Regulation of water and salts is done by kidneys. Kidneys remove wastes and extra fluid from your body. Kidneys also remove acid that is produced by cells of body and maintain healthy balance of water, salts and minerals such as sodium, calcium, potassium in your blood.
Incorrect. Kidney is an organ of excretion and osmoregulation in humans. Regulation of water and salts is done by kidneys. Kidneys remove wastes and extra fluid from your body. Kidneys also remove acid that is produced by cells of body and maintain healthy balance of water, salts and minerals such as sodium, calcium, potassium in your blood.

Q273: Where can we find the glomerulus in a human being?

Source: RRB Group-D 29-09-2022 (Shift-III)
Correct! Glomerulus in a human being is found in the kidney. It is the filtering unit of the kidney. RRB Science Planner Biology YCT 561
Incorrect. Glomerulus in a human being is found in the kidney. It is the filtering unit of the kidney. RRB Science Planner Biology YCT 561

Q274: Which of the following diagrams depicts the positions of the urethras (shown as blue lines) and the urinary bladder in the human excretory system?

Source: RRB Group-D 28-09-2022 (Shift-III)
Correct! Diagram 1 depicts the position of the urethras (shown as blue lines) and the urinary bladder in the human excretory system.
Incorrect. Diagram 1 depicts the position of the urethras (shown as blue lines) and the urinary bladder in the human excretory system.

Q275: A normal adult human being produces ––––––– mL per day of urine daily.

Source: RRB Group-D 28-09-2022 (Shift-I)
Correct! A normal adult human being produces 1000 – 2000mL per day of urine daily. (with a normal fluid intake of about 2 liters per day)
Incorrect. A normal adult human being produces 1000 – 2000mL per day of urine daily. (with a normal fluid intake of about 2 liters per day)

Q276: Which of the following sequences of events occurs during the formation of urine in the human body?

Source: RRB Group-D– 17/08/2022 (Shift-II)
Correct! Filtration, reabsorption, secretion events occurs during the formation of urine in the human body. Urine is a liquid by product of metabolism in humans and in many other animals.
Incorrect. Filtration, reabsorption, secretion events occurs during the formation of urine in the human body. Urine is a liquid by product of metabolism in humans and in many other animals.

Q277: Which of the following is not an animal- produced nitrogenous waste product?

Source: RRB Group-D– 30/09/2022 (Shift-III)
Correct! Lactic acid is not an animal-produced nitrogenous waste product. Mammals, including humans, produce urea, whereas reptiles and many terrestrial invertebrates produce uric acid. Ammonia, urea, uric acid and creatinine are four nitrogenous waste products. All of these substances are produced from protein metabolism.
Incorrect. Lactic acid is not an animal-produced nitrogenous waste product. Mammals, including humans, produce urea, whereas reptiles and many terrestrial invertebrates produce uric acid. Ammonia, urea, uric acid and creatinine are four nitrogenous waste products. All of these substances are produced from protein metabolism.

Q278: Aquatic animals like fishes, excrete waste in which of the following forms?

Source: RRB Group-D– 30/09/2022 (Shift-I)
Correct! Aquatic animals like fishes, excrete waste in the form of ammonia. These animals are known as ammonotelic animals. Ammonia is eliminated from the blood upon passage through the gills. Ammonia causes stress and damages gills and other tissues, even in small amounts. Ammonia is highly water-soluble and its excretion requires large amounts of water.
Incorrect. Aquatic animals like fishes, excrete waste in the form of ammonia. These animals are known as ammonotelic animals. Ammonia is eliminated from the blood upon passage through the gills. Ammonia causes stress and damages gills and other tissues, even in small amounts. Ammonia is highly water-soluble and its excretion requires large amounts of water.

Q279: The primary excretory product of ________ is uric acid.

Source: RRB Group-D– 29/08/2022 (Shift-II)
Correct! The primary excretory product of birds is uric acid. The primary excretory product of humans is urea and cow excretes ammonia as excretory product. Ammonia is the excretory waste in fishes.
Incorrect. The primary excretory product of birds is uric acid. The primary excretory product of humans is urea and cow excretes ammonia as excretory product. Ammonia is the excretory waste in fishes.

Q280: The 'Urea Cycle' takes place in the human ___.

Source: RRB Group-D– 29/08/2022 (Shift-II)
Correct! The 'Urea cycle' takes place in the human 'liver'. Urea Cycle converts excess ammonia into urea in the mitochondria of liver cells.
Incorrect. The 'Urea cycle' takes place in the human 'liver'. Urea Cycle converts excess ammonia into urea in the mitochondria of liver cells.

Q281: Which of the following constitutes the human excretory system ?

Source: RRB Group-D– 09/09/2022 (Shift-I)
Correct! The organs that form excretory system are one pair of kidneys, one pair of ureters, single urinary bladder and a urethra.
Incorrect. The organs that form excretory system are one pair of kidneys, one pair of ureters, single urinary bladder and a urethra.

Q282: An adult human urine consists of :

Source: RRB Group-D– 06/10/2022 (Shift-III)
Correct! An adult human urine consists of 95% water, 2.5% urea and 2.5% other waste products.
Incorrect. An adult human urine consists of 95% water, 2.5% urea and 2.5% other waste products.

Q283: Bowman's capsule encloses ______.

Source: RRB Group-D– 06/10/2022 (Shift-III)
Correct! Bowman’s capsule surrounds the glomerulus capillary loops and participates in the filtration of blood from the glomerular capillaries.
Incorrect. Bowman’s capsule surrounds the glomerulus capillary loops and participates in the filtration of blood from the glomerular capillaries.

Q284: Is there any advantage of the structure of the nephron as a long tubular structure?

Source: RRB Group-D– 13/09/2022 (Shift-II)
Correct! The long tube gives time and space for re- absorption of excess water from the initial filtrate the advantage of the structure of nephron as a long tubular structure. The major function of tubules is reabsorption and process can either be through active transport or passive transport. In addition, secretions by tubules help in the urine formation without affecting the electrolyte balance of the body.
Incorrect. The long tube gives time and space for re- absorption of excess water from the initial filtrate the advantage of the structure of nephron as a long tubular structure. The major function of tubules is reabsorption and process can either be through active transport or passive transport. In addition, secretions by tubules help in the urine formation without affecting the electrolyte balance of the body.

Q285: Given below is the diagram of a nephron. Select the option with the correct labelling for a, b, c and d parts.

Source: RRB Group-D– 20/09/2022 (Shift-II)
Correct! Correct labels are- a- Branch of renal artery b- Glomerulus c- Bownan's capsule d- Branch of renal vein
Incorrect. Correct labels are- a- Branch of renal artery b- Glomerulus c- Bownan's capsule d- Branch of renal vein

Q286: Which of the following substance is/are NOT reabsorbed by the kidneys?

Source: RRB Group-D– 18/09/2022 (Shift-III)
Correct! Creatinine is a nonprotein nitrogenous substance derived from muscle creatine. An increased level of creatinine may be sign at poor kidney function.
Incorrect. Creatinine is a nonprotein nitrogenous substance derived from muscle creatine. An increased level of creatinine may be sign at poor kidney function.

Q287: In human beings, excretory products in the form of soluble nitrogen compounds are removed by the _______ in the kidneys.

Source: RRB NTPC 21.01.2021 (Shift-I) Stage Ist
Correct! In human beings, excretory products in the form of soluble nitrogen compounds are removed by the nephrons in the kidneys. Each of our kidney is made up of about a million filtering units called nephrons. Each nephron includes a filter, called the glomerulus and a renal tubule. The nephrons work through a two-step process : the glomerulus filters blood, and the tubule returns needed substances to our blood and removes wastes.
Incorrect. In human beings, excretory products in the form of soluble nitrogen compounds are removed by the nephrons in the kidneys. Each of our kidney is made up of about a million filtering units called nephrons. Each nephron includes a filter, called the glomerulus and a renal tubule. The nephrons work through a two-step process : the glomerulus filters blood, and the tubule returns needed substances to our blood and removes wastes.

Q288: The kidneys are not only the excretory organs but also complementary to …….. .

Source: RRB SSE (21.12.2014, Set-09, Yellow paper)
Correct! The kidneys are complementary to the liver along with excretory organs. The ornithine cycle is a cycle in the liver during which urea is produced from ammonia. It is a mechanism that occurs in ureotelic animals. Kidneys also act to excrete urea.
Incorrect. The kidneys are complementary to the liver along with excretory organs. The ornithine cycle is a cycle in the liver during which urea is produced from ammonia. It is a mechanism that occurs in ureotelic animals. Kidneys also act to excrete urea.

Q289: Each kidney has a large number of filtration units called:

Source: RRB NTPC 10.01.2021 (Shift-I) Stage Ist
Correct! Each kidney is made up of about a million filtering units called nephrons. Each nephron filters a small amount of blood. Nephron filters all the blood in the body from 20 to 25 times per day, and in doing so keep the blood components stable.
Incorrect. Each kidney is made up of about a million filtering units called nephrons. Each nephron filters a small amount of blood. Nephron filters all the blood in the body from 20 to 25 times per day, and in doing so keep the blood components stable.

Q290: Nephron is associated with -

Source: RRB J.E. (14.12.2014, Green paper)
Correct! Nephron is associated with excretory system. Each nephron is made up of a malpighian body, which is made up of a Bowman capsule and network of blood cells. Nephron is known as structural and functional unit of the kidney.
Incorrect. Nephron is associated with excretory system. Each nephron is made up of a malpighian body, which is made up of a Bowman capsule and network of blood cells. Nephron is known as structural and functional unit of the kidney.

Q291: ............. converts ammonia (i.e. toxic) into urea in humans?

Source: RRB NTPC Stage Ist 30.04.2016 (Shift-II)
Correct! Urea formation naturally occurs during the breakdown process of proteins. This process leads to the release of amino groups from the amino acids present in the protein. These amino groups are converted into highly toxic ammonia (NH3) and this ammonia i.e produced is eventually converted to urea by the liver. Urea is formed by the ornithine cycle, in which ammonia is converted into urea.
Incorrect. Urea formation naturally occurs during the breakdown process of proteins. This process leads to the release of amino groups from the amino acids present in the protein. These amino groups are converted into highly toxic ammonia (NH3) and this ammonia i.e produced is eventually converted to urea by the liver. Urea is formed by the ornithine cycle, in which ammonia is converted into urea.

Q292: Where is urea formed?

Source: RRB NTPC Stage Ist 28.04.2016 (Shift-III)
Correct! See the explanation of the above question.
Incorrect. See the explanation of the above question.

Q293: ............ are fleshy tubes that allow to move urine from the kidneys towards the bladder.

Source: RRB NTPC Stage Ist 30.04.2016 (Shift-I)
Correct! Each ureter is a muscular tube that drains into the bladder. Smooth muscle contractions in the walls of the ureters, over time, send the urine in small spurts into the bladder.The bladder is a hollow muscular organ shaped like a balloon. The renal pelvis functions as a funnel for urine flowing to the ureter.
Incorrect. Each ureter is a muscular tube that drains into the bladder. Smooth muscle contractions in the walls of the ureters, over time, send the urine in small spurts into the bladder.The bladder is a hollow muscular organ shaped like a balloon. The renal pelvis functions as a funnel for urine flowing to the ureter.

Q294: Whose primary function is to eliminate the waste material from the blood by urine formation? RRB Science Planner Biology YCT 563

Source: RRB Science Planner Biology
Correct! The kidney is the excretory organ of humans. There are two kidneys in the body. Their shape is like bean seeds. Its outer part is called cortex and inner part is called medulla. Each kidney is made up of about 10 lakh micro-tubes called renal tubules or Nephrons. Nephron is the functional unit of kidney. Its main function is to eliminate toxic excretory substances from the blood.
Incorrect. The kidney is the excretory organ of humans. There are two kidneys in the body. Their shape is like bean seeds. Its outer part is called cortex and inner part is called medulla. Each kidney is made up of about 10 lakh micro-tubes called renal tubules or Nephrons. Nephron is the functional unit of kidney. Its main function is to eliminate toxic excretory substances from the blood.

Q297: Which of the following is not a part of the human excretory system?

Source: RRB NTPC Stage Ist 26.04.2016 (Shift-II)
Correct! Kidney, urinary duct and urethra are organs related to the human excretory system, while the uterus is the organ related to reproduction.
Incorrect. Kidney, urinary duct and urethra are organs related to the human excretory system, while the uterus is the organ related to reproduction.

Q298: Which of the following compounds is the most common compound that forms kidney stones?

Source: RRB NTPC 02.04.2016 (Shift-II) Stage Ist
Correct! Most kidney stones are calcium stones, usually in the form of calcium oxalate ( CaC2O4). Oxalate is a naturally occurring substance found in food.
Incorrect. Most kidney stones are calcium stones, usually in the form of calcium oxalate ( CaC2O4). Oxalate is a naturally occurring substance found in food.

Q299: Which human body organ is involved in the purification of blood?

Source: RRB NTPC 18.04.2016 (Shift-II) Stage Ist
Correct! Kidney is an organ involved in the purification of blood because the process of filtration takes place in the glomeruli of Nephron, the structural unit of the kidney. Respiratory system consists of nasal cavity, trachea, pharynx, lungs etc. Through inhalation, oxygen reaches each part of the body and carbon dioxide is released. The vein carries impure blood and the arteries carry pure blood to various organs of the body.
Incorrect. Kidney is an organ involved in the purification of blood because the process of filtration takes place in the glomeruli of Nephron, the structural unit of the kidney. Respiratory system consists of nasal cavity, trachea, pharynx, lungs etc. Through inhalation, oxygen reaches each part of the body and carbon dioxide is released. The vein carries impure blood and the arteries carry pure blood to various organs of the body.

Q300: Nephrology is associated with ..............

Source: RRB NTPC 06.04.2016 (Shift-I) Stage Ist
Correct! Nephrology is related to kidney.
Incorrect. Nephrology is related to kidney.

Q301: Kidney failure is treated periodically on a kidney machine. The process is known as ______.

Source: RRB NTPC 16.01.2021 (Shift-II) Stage Ist
Correct! Hemodialysis is the process of cleaning the blood of toxins, extra salt and fluids through a dialysis machine. It helps to maintain proper chemical balance such as potassium, sodium and chloride and keeps blood pressure under control.
Incorrect. Hemodialysis is the process of cleaning the blood of toxins, extra salt and fluids through a dialysis machine. It helps to maintain proper chemical balance such as potassium, sodium and chloride and keeps blood pressure under control.

Q302: A dialyser, a machine used to clean a patient's blood, is also known as an artificial:

Source: RRB NTPC 08.04.2021 (Shift-I) Stage Ist
Correct! Hemodialysis is a treatment to filter wastes and water from blood, as kidneys did when they were healthy. Hemodialysis helps control blood pressure and balance important minerals, such as potassium, sodium, and calcium, in blood. During hemodialysis, blood goes through a filter, called a dialyzer, outside body. A dialyzer is also called as ‘artificial kidney’.
Incorrect. Hemodialysis is a treatment to filter wastes and water from blood, as kidneys did when they were healthy. Hemodialysis helps control blood pressure and balance important minerals, such as potassium, sodium, and calcium, in blood. During hemodialysis, blood goes through a filter, called a dialyzer, outside body. A dialyzer is also called as ‘artificial kidney’.

Q303: Which of the following is not a part of human excretory system?

Source: RRB NTPC 08.03.2021 (Shift-II) Stage Ist
Correct! Bronchiole is not a part of human excretory system. It is a part of lungs which carries air to the lungs. Collecting duct, Glomerulus and Bowman's Capsule are the parts of kidney.
Incorrect. Bronchiole is not a part of human excretory system. It is a part of lungs which carries air to the lungs. Collecting duct, Glomerulus and Bowman's Capsule are the parts of kidney.

Q304: In which disease treatment, dialysis is involved?

Source: RRB NTPC 31.03.2016 (Shift-I) Stage Ist
Correct! Uremia is a major symptom of renal failure.It is a dangerous condition that occurs when the kidneys no longer filter properly. Dialysis is the main treatment option for uremia. Dialysis is when the removal of wastes, extra fluids, and toxins from bloodstream is handled artificially instead of by kidneys through Hemodialysis. Hemodialysis is a procedure where a dialysis machine and a special filter called an artificial kidney, or a dialyzer, are used to clean blood. This process is boon for uremic patients in the world.
Incorrect. Uremia is a major symptom of renal failure.It is a dangerous condition that occurs when the kidneys no longer filter properly. Dialysis is the main treatment option for uremia. Dialysis is when the removal of wastes, extra fluids, and toxins from bloodstream is handled artificially instead of by kidneys through Hemodialysis. Hemodialysis is a procedure where a dialysis machine and a special filter called an artificial kidney, or a dialyzer, are used to clean blood. This process is boon for uremic patients in the world.
