Q307: Ultrafiltration is related to:

Source: RRB Group-D 26-10-2018 (Shift-II)
Correct! Ultrafiltration is related to excretion. This ultrafiltration occurs in the kidney. The human kidney purify the blood through ultrafiltration.
Incorrect. Ultrafiltration is related to excretion. This ultrafiltration occurs in the kidney. The human kidney purify the blood through ultrafiltration.

Q308: Vas deferens unites with the tube coming from ...to form a common passage called the urethra.

Source: RRB Group-D 22-10-2018 (Shift-II)
Correct! The bladder is the internal organ that collects urine produced by the kidneys before urinary excretion. Vas deferens diffusely unites with the tube coming from the bladder to form a common passage.
Incorrect. The bladder is the internal organ that collects urine produced by the kidneys before urinary excretion. Vas deferens diffusely unites with the tube coming from the bladder to form a common passage.

Q309: We can control the stimulation of urination:

Source: RRB Group-D 18-09-2018 (Shift-II)
Correct! The mechanism, by which regulation of various organs and homeostasis are maintained with environment is called nervous system. The nervous system is composed of the brain, spinal cord and the nerves arising from it. Stimulation of urination is an involuntary action that is controlled by the nervous control of the muscular bladder.
Incorrect. The mechanism, by which regulation of various organs and homeostasis are maintained with environment is called nervous system. The nervous system is composed of the brain, spinal cord and the nerves arising from it. Stimulation of urination is an involuntary action that is controlled by the nervous control of the muscular bladder.

Q310: Find odd one out:

Source: RRB Group-D 12-11-2018 (Shift-III)
Correct! Nissl's granules are found in neurons while other terms in the options are related to kidney. Nissl's granules are of rough endoplasmic reticulum (RER) with rosettes of free ribosomes, and are the site of protein synthesis.
Incorrect. Nissl's granules are found in neurons while other terms in the options are related to kidney. Nissl's granules are of rough endoplasmic reticulum (RER) with rosettes of free ribosomes, and are the site of protein synthesis.

Q311: Which of these organs is not related to the excretory system?

Source: RRB Group-D 15-11-2018 (Shift-II)
Correct! The coronary artery carries oxygenated blood to the heart. It is part of the circulatory system. The hepatic vein, renal artery and pulmonary vein are part of the excretory system. The major function of the excretory system is to eliminate nitrogenous wastes from the body. Excretion is the process of excreting toxic and waste substances produced as a result of metabolic activities.
Incorrect. The coronary artery carries oxygenated blood to the heart. It is part of the circulatory system. The hepatic vein, renal artery and pulmonary vein are part of the excretory system. The major function of the excretory system is to eliminate nitrogenous wastes from the body. Excretion is the process of excreting toxic and waste substances produced as a result of metabolic activities.

Q312: ............... is present in the lining of the renal tubule.

Source: RRB Group-D 27-11-2018 (Shift-I)
Correct! Cuboidal epithelium is present in the lining of the renal tubule. These cuboidal cells have large, spherical and central nuclei. Simple cuboidal epithelia are found on the surface of ovaries, the lining of nephrons, the walls of the renal tubules, and parts of the eye and thyroid. On these surfaces, the cells perform secretion and absorption.
Incorrect. Cuboidal epithelium is present in the lining of the renal tubule. These cuboidal cells have large, spherical and central nuclei. Simple cuboidal epithelia are found on the surface of ovaries, the lining of nephrons, the walls of the renal tubules, and parts of the eye and thyroid. On these surfaces, the cells perform secretion and absorption.

Q313: In humans, which of the following is the function of the nephrons?

Source: RRB Group-D 03-12-2018 (Shift-III)
Correct! The function of the nephrons in the human body is excretion. Excretion is the process of excreting toxic and waste substances produced as a result of metabolic activities. Other major functions of the kidney include purification of blood, balance of water in the body, balance of acid and alkali, aid in the production of blood particles, etc.
Incorrect. The function of the nephrons in the human body is excretion. Excretion is the process of excreting toxic and waste substances produced as a result of metabolic activities. Other major functions of the kidney include purification of blood, balance of water in the body, balance of acid and alkali, aid in the production of blood particles, etc.

Q314: –––––– is a 20 cm long tube, which carries urine from the bladder.

Source: RRB Group-D 16-10-2018 (Shift-I)
Correct! The urethra is a tube extending from the internal urethral orifice located in the bladder to the external urethral orifice through which urine passes out. In men, the urethra is about 20 cm. There is a long tube (8 inches) which acts as an aperture for both urine and semen. Urethra in women is about 4 cm. (1.5 inches) long, which serves only the urinary system. (v) Nervous System
Incorrect. The urethra is a tube extending from the internal urethral orifice located in the bladder to the external urethral orifice through which urine passes out. In men, the urethra is about 20 cm. There is a long tube (8 inches) which acts as an aperture for both urine and semen. Urethra in women is about 4 cm. (1.5 inches) long, which serves only the urinary system. (v) Nervous System

Q315: Olfactory receptors aid in ______ perception.

Source: RRB Group-D 30-08-2022 (Shift-II)
Correct! Olfactory receptors aid in smell perception olfactory receptors are above to detect airborne odour molecules that enter the nasal cavity and bind with olfactory receptors.
Incorrect. Olfactory receptors aid in smell perception olfactory receptors are above to detect airborne odour molecules that enter the nasal cavity and bind with olfactory receptors.

Q316: Which of the following parts is responsible to give a specific colour to the eyes?

Source: RRB Group-D 19-09-2022 (Shift-I)
Correct! Iris part is responsible to give a specific colour to the eyes. A person's eye colour results from pigmentation of a structure called the iris, which surrounds the small black hole in the centre of the eye (the pupil) and helps to control how much light can enter the eye.
Incorrect. Iris part is responsible to give a specific colour to the eyes. A person's eye colour results from pigmentation of a structure called the iris, which surrounds the small black hole in the centre of the eye (the pupil) and helps to control how much light can enter the eye.

Q317: Identify the following cell.

Source: RRB Group-D 28-09-2022 (Shift-II)
Correct! The given cell is a nerve cell. A type of cell that receives and sends message from the body to the brain and back to the body. The messages are sent by weak electrical current also called neuron.
Incorrect. The given cell is a nerve cell. A type of cell that receives and sends message from the body to the brain and back to the body. The messages are sent by weak electrical current also called neuron.

Q318: Which of the following numbers indicates the spinal cord's location in the human brain?

Source: RRB Group-D 18-08-2022 (Shift-I)
Correct! Spinal cord is a cylindrical structure that begins at the bottom of the brain stem as shown in the given figure at the number 4. Spinal cord is a long, thin, tubular structure made up of nervous tissue, which extends from the medulla oblangata in the brainstem.
Incorrect. Spinal cord is a cylindrical structure that begins at the bottom of the brain stem as shown in the given figure at the number 4. Spinal cord is a long, thin, tubular structure made up of nervous tissue, which extends from the medulla oblangata in the brainstem.

Q319: Which part of the brain regulates breathing?

Source: RRB ALP & Tec. (31-08-18 Shift-I)
Correct! The medulla is the lowest part of the brain column. It is situated between the pons on the top and the spinal cord on the bottom. The medulla has coordination centres of heart pulsation rate and intensity, diameter of blood vessels, breathing rate, food ingestion, coughing, sneezing, hiccups, tongue movements, etc. that regulate these responses of human.
Incorrect. The medulla is the lowest part of the brain column. It is situated between the pons on the top and the spinal cord on the bottom. The medulla has coordination centres of heart pulsation rate and intensity, diameter of blood vessels, breathing rate, food ingestion, coughing, sneezing, hiccups, tongue movements, etc. that regulate these responses of human.

Q320: Name the structure of the eye that acts to refract light rays and focus on the retina?

Source: RRB JE 27.05.2019 (Shift-III)
Correct! The structure of the eye, which acts to refract light rays and focus on the retina, is called a lens.
Incorrect. The structure of the eye, which acts to refract light rays and focus on the retina, is called a lens.

Q321: Nodes of Ranvier are microscopic gaps found within ………. .

Source: RRB ALP & Tec. (09-08-18 Shift-I)
Correct! Nodes of Ranvier are microscopic gaps found within myelinated axons. The Nodes of Ranvier are the gaps between the myelin insulation of Schwann cells which insulate the axon of neuron. These refract the neuron's axis. Schwann cells are also called glial cells.
Incorrect. Nodes of Ranvier are microscopic gaps found within myelinated axons. The Nodes of Ranvier are the gaps between the myelin insulation of Schwann cells which insulate the axon of neuron. These refract the neuron's axis. Schwann cells are also called glial cells.

Q322: Which of the following is the main thinking part of the human brain?

Source: RRB ALP & Tec. (10-08-18 Shift-II)
Correct! Forebrain is highly developed in humans and is the centre of all intelligence, consciousness, willpower, knowledge, memory, speech, thinking and thought collection. Therefore, it provides the ability to read, write, speak, think, future planning, etc. The human brain has three parts: (A) Fore-brain, (B) Mid-brain (C) Hind-brain. The forebrain also controls reflex actions like laughing, crying, excretion. It also serves as the center of transmission of sensory responses, which contains information about hearing, sight, taste, touch, temperature, pressure, etc.
Incorrect. Forebrain is highly developed in humans and is the centre of all intelligence, consciousness, willpower, knowledge, memory, speech, thinking and thought collection. Therefore, it provides the ability to read, write, speak, think, future planning, etc. The human brain has three parts: (A) Fore-brain, (B) Mid-brain (C) Hind-brain. The forebrain also controls reflex actions like laughing, crying, excretion. It also serves as the center of transmission of sensory responses, which contains information about hearing, sight, taste, touch, temperature, pressure, etc.

Q323: In which of these organs is the thermostat of the human body contained?

Source: RRB SSE (21.12.2014, Set-07, Yellow paper)
Correct! The hypothalamus is a part of the brain which has many small nuclei with different functions. One of the important functions of the hypothalamus is to connect the nervous system to the endocrine system through the pituitary gland (hypophysis). All vertebrate brains have hypothalamus. In humans, it is shaped like a pea shape. Pineal gland - The pineal gland (also called the pineal body) is called epiphysis or third eye. It is tiny endocrine gland present in veretebrate brain. It produces serotonin derived melatonin which helps maintain circadian rhythm and regulate reproductive hormones.
Incorrect. The hypothalamus is a part of the brain which has many small nuclei with different functions. One of the important functions of the hypothalamus is to connect the nervous system to the endocrine system through the pituitary gland (hypophysis). All vertebrate brains have hypothalamus. In humans, it is shaped like a pea shape. Pineal gland - The pineal gland (also called the pineal body) is called epiphysis or third eye. It is tiny endocrine gland present in veretebrate brain. It produces serotonin derived melatonin which helps maintain circadian rhythm and regulate reproductive hormones.

Q324: What is Cyton called?

Source: RRB Group-D 15-10-2018 (Shift-I)
Correct! Cyton is also known as perikaryon cell. Cyton is the central spherical part or cell body of a neuron containing the nucleus and excluding its processes. It mainly contains nucleus connecting the dendrites. Its cytoplasm shows characteristic Nissl's granules. Cyton receives electrical impulses from other neurons through dendrites. It also brings information on the neuron, the axon that would send the information to other neurons. Main function of cell body is to control all functions of cell in the body to work properly.
Incorrect. Cyton is also known as perikaryon cell. Cyton is the central spherical part or cell body of a neuron containing the nucleus and excluding its processes. It mainly contains nucleus connecting the dendrites. Its cytoplasm shows characteristic Nissl's granules. Cyton receives electrical impulses from other neurons through dendrites. It also brings information on the neuron, the axon that would send the information to other neurons. Main function of cell body is to control all functions of cell in the body to work properly.

Q325: Which of the following is a basic structural and functional unit of the nervous system?

Source: RRB NTPC 02.03.2021 (Shift-I) Stage Ist
Correct! A neuron or nerve cell is an electrically excitable cell that communicates with other cells via specialized connections called synapses. It is the main component of nervous tissue in all animals except sponges and placozoa. It is a basic structural and functional unit of the nervous system. Neurons are the longest tissue of a human body.
Incorrect. A neuron or nerve cell is an electrically excitable cell that communicates with other cells via specialized connections called synapses. It is the main component of nervous tissue in all animals except sponges and placozoa. It is a basic structural and functional unit of the nervous system. Neurons are the longest tissue of a human body.

Q326: Dendrites and synapses are associated with:

Source: RRB J.E. (14.12.2014, Green paper)
Correct! Nerve cells are structural and functional units of the nervous system. Their number in the human body is about 100 billion (1010). Most of nerve cells are present in the brain. It is made up of neuro blast cells of the embryo. They are responsible for the electrical excitability of muscle cells, and they mediate most forms of electrical signaling in the nervous system. They are specialized for signal transmission. RRB Science Planner Biology YCT 566
Incorrect. Nerve cells are structural and functional units of the nervous system. Their number in the human body is about 100 billion (1010). Most of nerve cells are present in the brain. It is made up of neuro blast cells of the embryo. They are responsible for the electrical excitability of muscle cells, and they mediate most forms of electrical signaling in the nervous system. They are specialized for signal transmission. RRB Science Planner Biology YCT 566

Q327: Which of the following is not a voluntary action?

Source: RRB ALP & Tec. (13-08-18 Shift-III)
Correct! When an action is produced with the involvement of thoughts, they are called the voluntary action. It involves actions like walking, eating, jumping, moving a chair, closing a fist, taking an object and running etc. These actions are produced consciously. Both spinal cord and brain are involved and these coordinate with PNS to generate necessary movements. Actions which take place without consciousness or willingness of an individual are called the involuntary action. Digestion, heart beating, sneezing, etc are few examples of involuntary actions.
Incorrect. When an action is produced with the involvement of thoughts, they are called the voluntary action. It involves actions like walking, eating, jumping, moving a chair, closing a fist, taking an object and running etc. These actions are produced consciously. Both spinal cord and brain are involved and these coordinate with PNS to generate necessary movements. Actions which take place without consciousness or willingness of an individual are called the involuntary action. Digestion, heart beating, sneezing, etc are few examples of involuntary actions.

Q328: The ECG senses the electric forces generated by ………. .

Source: RRB JE 27.05.2019 (Shift-III)
Correct! The ECG senses the electrical forces generated by the heart.
Incorrect. The ECG senses the electrical forces generated by the heart.

Q329: Which of the following helps to diagnose heart problems?

Source: RRB JE 24.05.2019 (Shift-III)
Correct! ECG helps diagnose heart problems.
Incorrect. ECG helps diagnose heart problems.

Q330: Which body part is tested by ECG?

Source: RRB JE 29.05.2019 (Shift-III)
Correct! ECG tests heart mechanism.
Incorrect. ECG tests heart mechanism.

Q331: Involuntary actions in humans such as blood pressure, salivation and vomiting are controlled by the:

Source: RRB ALP & Tec. (20-08-18 Shift-I)
Correct! Involuntary actions takes place without the conscious choice of an organism. Involuntary action is the set of muscle movement which does not require thinking but it is controlled by brain for example beating of heart. These actions are controlled by the medulla. Medulla directly controls certain ANS responses, such as heart rate, breathing, blood vessel dilation, digestion, sneezing, swallowing and vomiting.
Incorrect. Involuntary actions takes place without the conscious choice of an organism. Involuntary action is the set of muscle movement which does not require thinking but it is controlled by brain for example beating of heart. These actions are controlled by the medulla. Medulla directly controls certain ANS responses, such as heart rate, breathing, blood vessel dilation, digestion, sneezing, swallowing and vomiting.

Q332: The ……….. is responsible for precision of voluntary actions and maintaining the posture and balance of the body.

Source: RRB ALP & Tec. (29-08-18 Shift-II)
Correct! The cerebellum is responsible for precision of voluntary actions and maintaining the posture and balance of the body.
Incorrect. The cerebellum is responsible for precision of voluntary actions and maintaining the posture and balance of the body.

Q333: Thermoregulation in humans is controlled by …………. .

Source: RRB NTPC Stage Ist 29.04.2016 (Shift-I)
Correct! The hypothalamus gland is a part of the brain. The secretion of the pituitary gland is regulated by this gland that controls many bodily functions of hunger, thirst, heat, anger, happiness, sexual intercourse.
Incorrect. The hypothalamus gland is a part of the brain. The secretion of the pituitary gland is regulated by this gland that controls many bodily functions of hunger, thirst, heat, anger, happiness, sexual intercourse.

Q334: Which part of the human brain is the center of intelligence, memory and emotions?

Source: RRB NTPC Stage Ist 27.04.2016 (Shift-III)
Correct! The Cerebrum is the part of the brain which is the center of intelligence, memory and emotions. Embryologically, the cerebrum is derived from the prosencephalon. It controls posture coordination, balance, movements of voluntary muscles, etc. Its main function is to maintain the balance of the body. It controls the contraction of the voluntary muscles of the body.
Incorrect. The Cerebrum is the part of the brain which is the center of intelligence, memory and emotions. Embryologically, the cerebrum is derived from the prosencephalon. It controls posture coordination, balance, movements of voluntary muscles, etc. Its main function is to maintain the balance of the body. It controls the contraction of the voluntary muscles of the body.

Q335: The function of the lens in our eyes is to -

Source: RRB NTPC 28.03.2016 (Shift-I) Stage Ist
Correct! The function of the lens in our eyes is to change the focal distance of the eye. When the rays of light moving from an object reach the cornea, it is refracted and enters the eye.This makes an inverse image of the object on the retina, then the object gives us straight apperance.
Incorrect. The function of the lens in our eyes is to change the focal distance of the eye. When the rays of light moving from an object reach the cornea, it is refracted and enters the eye.This makes an inverse image of the object on the retina, then the object gives us straight apperance.

Q336: The area of the retina where the vision is highest is

Source: RRB JE 29.05.2019 (Shift-II)
Correct! The area of the retina, where the vision is highest, is called fovea.
Incorrect. The area of the retina, where the vision is highest, is called fovea.

Q337: Which of the following parts allows light to enter into the human eye?

Source: RRB NTPC 02.03.2021 (Shift-II) Stage Ist
Correct! Light rays enter the eye through the cornea, the clear front “window” of the eye. The cornea's refractive power bends the light rays in such a way that they pass freely through the pupil, the opening in the centre of the iris through which light enters the eye.
Incorrect. Light rays enter the eye through the cornea, the clear front “window” of the eye. The cornea's refractive power bends the light rays in such a way that they pass freely through the pupil, the opening in the centre of the iris through which light enters the eye.

Q338: In which part of body is cornea and retina found?

Source: RRB JE 24.05.2019 (Shift-III)
Correct! The cornea and retina are found in the eye of the human body.
Incorrect. The cornea and retina are found in the eye of the human body.

Q339: On which of the following principle does the human eye work?

Source: RRB JE 01.06.2019 (Shift-I)
Correct! The human eye works on principle ‘ refraction of light’. RRB Science Planner Biology YCT 567
Incorrect. The human eye works on principle ‘ refraction of light’. RRB Science Planner Biology YCT 567

Q340: What is called feature of adaptation of human eyes to see near and distant objects?

Source: RRB NTPC 30.03.2016 (Shift-II) Stage Ist
Correct! Accomodation is feature of adaptation of human eyes to see near and distant objects. Myopia is the term used to define being shortsighted. A myopic person has clear vision when looking at objects close to them, but distant objects will appear blurred. Hypermetropia, sometimes called hyperopia, is the term used to define being longsighted. If a person is hypermetropic, the image of a nearby object is formed behind the retina. This means that light is focused too far back in the eye, causing things which are close up to appear blurred. Hypermetropia and Myopia, both are refractive defects in vision.
Incorrect. Accomodation is feature of adaptation of human eyes to see near and distant objects. Myopia is the term used to define being shortsighted. A myopic person has clear vision when looking at objects close to them, but distant objects will appear blurred. Hypermetropia, sometimes called hyperopia, is the term used to define being longsighted. If a person is hypermetropic, the image of a nearby object is formed behind the retina. This means that light is focused too far back in the eye, causing things which are close up to appear blurred. Hypermetropia and Myopia, both are refractive defects in vision.

Q341: Which of the following is NOT a part of the human eye?

Source: RRB NTPC 21.01.2021 (Shift-I) Stage Ist
Correct! Cornea, Retina, Iris, Pupil, Aqueous humour, Crystalline lens, Ciliary muscles, Optic nerve, Vitreous humour are the parts of the human eye; whereas Cochlea (the coiled portion of the labyrinth), Pinna, Temporal bone, Malleus, Incus, Stapes in oval window, Cochlear nerve, Eustachian tube, Tympanic membrane are the parts of the human ear.
Incorrect. Cornea, Retina, Iris, Pupil, Aqueous humour, Crystalline lens, Ciliary muscles, Optic nerve, Vitreous humour are the parts of the human eye; whereas Cochlea (the coiled portion of the labyrinth), Pinna, Temporal bone, Malleus, Incus, Stapes in oval window, Cochlear nerve, Eustachian tube, Tympanic membrane are the parts of the human ear.

Q342: Least distance of distinct vision for normal eye is …… .

Source: RRB NTPC 30.03.2016 (Shift-I) Stage Ist
Correct! Least distance of distinct vision for the normal eye is 25 cm. The ability of the eye lens to adjust its focal length is called power of accommodation. This is done by the ciliary muscles by changing the focal length of eye lens.
Incorrect. Least distance of distinct vision for the normal eye is 25 cm. The ability of the eye lens to adjust its focal length is called power of accommodation. This is done by the ciliary muscles by changing the focal length of eye lens.

Q343: When a person can see only nearby objects, the condition is called?

Source: RRB NTPC 31.03.2016 (Shift-II) Stage Ist
Correct! When a person can see only nearby objects, this condition is called myopia. This is because light is focused in front of the retina and, being too far forward in the eye, things at the distance look blurred. Shortsightedness is corrected using a concave (curved inwards) lens which is placed in front of a myopic eye, moving the image back to the retina and making it clearer.
Incorrect. When a person can see only nearby objects, this condition is called myopia. This is because light is focused in front of the retina and, being too far forward in the eye, things at the distance look blurred. Shortsightedness is corrected using a concave (curved inwards) lens which is placed in front of a myopic eye, moving the image back to the retina and making it clearer.

Q344: Which of the following is an eye disorder?

Source: RRB JE 22.05.2019 (Shift-II)
Correct! See the explanation of the above question.
Incorrect. See the explanation of the above question.

Q345: How many muscles are used to control the eyeball?

Source: RRB NTPC 04.04.2016 (Shift-III) Stage Ist
Correct! There are six muscles involved in the control of the eyeball. They can be divided into two groups; the four recti muscles (Superior Rectus, Inferior Rectus, Medial Rectus and Lateral Rectus) and the two oblique muscles(Superior Oblique, Inferior Oblique).
Incorrect. There are six muscles involved in the control of the eyeball. They can be divided into two groups; the four recti muscles (Superior Rectus, Inferior Rectus, Medial Rectus and Lateral Rectus) and the two oblique muscles(Superior Oblique, Inferior Oblique).

Q346: How much does the human brain weigh?

Source: RRB NTPC 04.04.2016 (Shift-III) Stage Ist
Correct! The human brain is a group of nerve cells, which are closed in a bone called the cranium of the head. The number of cells in brain remains almost same throughout life. The human brain weighs about 2% (about 1400 grams) of its total body weight.
Incorrect. The human brain is a group of nerve cells, which are closed in a bone called the cranium of the head. The number of cells in brain remains almost same throughout life. The human brain weighs about 2% (about 1400 grams) of its total body weight.

Q347: Pons is a part of human:

Source: RRB NTPC 13.03.2021 (Shift-II) Stage Ist
Correct! Pons is a portion of the brain stem. It is located above the medulla oblongata and below the midbrain. It is approximately 2.5 cm long, it serves several important functions. It is a bridge between various parts of the nervous system, including the cerebellum and cerebrum.
Incorrect. Pons is a portion of the brain stem. It is located above the medulla oblongata and below the midbrain. It is approximately 2.5 cm long, it serves several important functions. It is a bridge between various parts of the nervous system, including the cerebellum and cerebrum.

Q348: Which of the following is true?

Source: RRB NTPC 02.04.2016 (Shift-I) Stage Ist
Correct! The image formed on the retina is inverted and real. The real and inverted image formed on the retina is carried to the brain by the optic nerve in the form of electrical signals. The brain interprets these signals and processes the information such that we see the objects erect.
Incorrect. The image formed on the retina is inverted and real. The real and inverted image formed on the retina is carried to the brain by the optic nerve in the form of electrical signals. The brain interprets these signals and processes the information such that we see the objects erect.

Q349: Which of the following is not true about cerebellum?

Source: RRB Group-D 12-10-2018 (Shift-I)
Correct! The cerebellum is the upper part of the hindbrain. It is about 11% of the brain which is made of pons and medulla oblongata . The cerebellum is responsible for maintaining equilibrium, transfer of information, fine adjustments to motor actions, coordinating eye movements etc. Coordination and body balance, posture during walking, riding, standing, swimming, running, are all maintained by the cerebellum. RRB Science Planner Biology YCT 568
Incorrect. The cerebellum is the upper part of the hindbrain. It is about 11% of the brain which is made of pons and medulla oblongata . The cerebellum is responsible for maintaining equilibrium, transfer of information, fine adjustments to motor actions, coordinating eye movements etc. Coordination and body balance, posture during walking, riding, standing, swimming, running, are all maintained by the cerebellum. RRB Science Planner Biology YCT 568

Q350: For how long does the sensation of sound persist in the human brain?

Source: RRB Group-D 12-11-2018 (Shift-II)
Correct! The sensation of sound remains in our brain for about 0.1 second. Due to the refraction of the sound, it is heard far away in the night than in the day.
Incorrect. The sensation of sound remains in our brain for about 0.1 second. Due to the refraction of the sound, it is heard far away in the night than in the day.

Q351: 'I pulled my hand back from the flame reflexly'. Which organ is responsible for such an action?

Source: RRB Group-D 23-10-2018 (Shift-II)
Correct! The spinal cord of our body is responsible for pulling the hand back from the flame. Sensory reflexes transmitted into motor neurons through synapses in grey matter of spinal cord i.e they become motor inductions. These receive sensory information from the body, including fine touch, proprioception, and vibration. The signals originate in nerves found in the skin, bones, or joints and travel through interneurons for immediate responses and through the dorsal column-medial lemniscus tract for more involved movement. Grey column is responsible for regulating the autonomic nervous system through its role in activating the sympathetic nervous system.
Incorrect. The spinal cord of our body is responsible for pulling the hand back from the flame. Sensory reflexes transmitted into motor neurons through synapses in grey matter of spinal cord i.e they become motor inductions. These receive sensory information from the body, including fine touch, proprioception, and vibration. The signals originate in nerves found in the skin, bones, or joints and travel through interneurons for immediate responses and through the dorsal column-medial lemniscus tract for more involved movement. Grey column is responsible for regulating the autonomic nervous system through its role in activating the sympathetic nervous system.

Q352: The brain is also the coordinating center of the body:

Source: RRB Group-D 15-10-2018 (Shift-III)
Correct! The brain is an essential part of the body of most animals. Human brain is well- developed. The weight of an adult human brain is about 1350–1400 grams. It is protected within the skull and coordinates muscle movements, maintain posture, and balance of the body etc. There are three parts of human brain - 1. Fore-brain, 2. Mid-brain, 3. Hind-brain
Incorrect. The brain is an essential part of the body of most animals. Human brain is well- developed. The weight of an adult human brain is about 1350–1400 grams. It is protected within the skull and coordinates muscle movements, maintain posture, and balance of the body etc. There are three parts of human brain - 1. Fore-brain, 2. Mid-brain, 3. Hind-brain

Q353: Which of the following is composed of nerve fibres that mediate reflex actions and that transmit impulses to and from the brain?

Source: RRB NTPC 30.12.2020 (Shift-I) Stage Ist
Correct! Spinal cord, major nerve tract of vertebrates, extending from the base of the brain through the canal of nerve fibres that mediate reflex actions and that transmit impulses to and from the brain.
Incorrect. Spinal cord, major nerve tract of vertebrates, extending from the base of the brain through the canal of nerve fibres that mediate reflex actions and that transmit impulses to and from the brain.

Q354: Which of these is associated with colour vision?

Source: RRB JE 26.05.2019 (Shift-III)
Correct! Cone cells are related to colour vision.
Incorrect. Cone cells are related to colour vision.

Q355: How much does the human brain weigh in grams?

Source: RRB Group-D 22-10-2018 (Shift-II)
Correct! The weight of human brain in grams is 1200 - 1400 grams. The brain is the central information and transmission organ of the human body. It performs the functions of movement, balance, heat control, hunger and thirst, transportation, activities of many endocrine glands and control of human behavior. It is also the site of seeing, hearing, speaking, recollection, sharpness, feelings and thoughts.
Incorrect. The weight of human brain in grams is 1200 - 1400 grams. The brain is the central information and transmission organ of the human body. It performs the functions of movement, balance, heat control, hunger and thirst, transportation, activities of many endocrine glands and control of human behavior. It is also the site of seeing, hearing, speaking, recollection, sharpness, feelings and thoughts.

Q356: The cerebellum is related to-

Source: RRB Group-D 26-09-2018 (Shift-II)
Correct! The cerebellum, part of the posterior brain, is also called mesencephalon. It controls coordination, balance, movements of voluntary muscles, etc. Its main function is to maintain the balance of the body and control the contraction of the voluntary muscles.
Incorrect. The cerebellum, part of the posterior brain, is also called mesencephalon. It controls coordination, balance, movements of voluntary muscles, etc. Its main function is to maintain the balance of the body and control the contraction of the voluntary muscles.

Q357: .......... helps the eye to adjust the focal length of the lens.

Source: RRB Group-D 27-09-2018 (Shift-I)
Correct! The ciliary body helps eye to adjust the focal length of the lens. The ciliary body is the part of the eye that includes the ciliary muscle, which controls the shape of the lens, and the ciliary epithelium, which produces the aqueous humor. The aqueous humor is the thin, clear, watery fluid between cornea and lens in eyeball of eye.
Incorrect. The ciliary body helps eye to adjust the focal length of the lens. The ciliary body is the part of the eye that includes the ciliary muscle, which controls the shape of the lens, and the ciliary epithelium, which produces the aqueous humor. The aqueous humor is the thin, clear, watery fluid between cornea and lens in eyeball of eye.

Q358: ……….. tissue is made up of neurons, which receive and transmit impulses.

Source: RRB Group-D 15-11-2018 (Shift-I)
Correct! The control and coordination of motion in animals is done by the nervous and muscular tissues. Nervous tissue is made up of an organized network of neurons and is capable of transmiting information from one part of the body to another by electrical impulses. RRB Science Planner Biology YCT 569
Incorrect. The control and coordination of motion in animals is done by the nervous and muscular tissues. Nervous tissue is made up of an organized network of neurons and is capable of transmiting information from one part of the body to another by electrical impulses. RRB Science Planner Biology YCT 569

Q359: Which of these is a nerve cell?

Source: RRB JE 27.05.2019 (Shift-IV)
Correct! See the explanation of the above question.
Incorrect. See the explanation of the above question.

Q360: The nature of nerve impulse is:

Source: RRB Group-D 15-11-2018 (Shift-I)
Correct! The nervous system is made up of sensory organs, nerves, brain, spinal cord and nerve cells. The unit of the nervous system is a neuron. A nerve impulse can be defined as an electrical signal which generates along the length of the axon due to differential distribution and permeability to the sodium and potassium ions. It is caused due to the activities of pumps and channel proteins. At the axon terminal, the electrical impulse is changed into the chemical form via the release of the neurotransmitters like acetylcholine into the synapse or the end plate. So, the nature of nerve impulse is electrochemical.
Incorrect. The nervous system is made up of sensory organs, nerves, brain, spinal cord and nerve cells. The unit of the nervous system is a neuron. A nerve impulse can be defined as an electrical signal which generates along the length of the axon due to differential distribution and permeability to the sodium and potassium ions. It is caused due to the activities of pumps and channel proteins. At the axon terminal, the electrical impulse is changed into the chemical form via the release of the neurotransmitters like acetylcholine into the synapse or the end plate. So, the nature of nerve impulse is electrochemical.

Q361: The amount of light entering the eye is controlled by:

Source: RRB Group-D 24-09-2018 (Shift-I)
Correct! The amount of light entering the eye is controlled by pupil. The iris opens and closes to control the amount of light entering the eye through the pupil. The pupil is the opening in the center of the iris where light enters the eye.
Incorrect. The amount of light entering the eye is controlled by pupil. The iris opens and closes to control the amount of light entering the eye through the pupil. The pupil is the opening in the center of the iris where light enters the eye.

Q362: The pupil is a part of …………. .

Source: RRB JE 25.05.2019 (Shift-III)
Correct! See the explanation of the above question.
Incorrect. See the explanation of the above question.

Q363: ............ controls involuntary actions such as coughing and sneezing?

Source: RRB Group-D 06-12-2018 (Shift-II)
Correct! The medulla oblongata is responsible for regulating several basic functions of the autonomic nervous system, including respiration, cardiac function, vasodilation, and reflexes like vomiting, coughing, sneezing, and swallowing.
Incorrect. The medulla oblongata is responsible for regulating several basic functions of the autonomic nervous system, including respiration, cardiac function, vasodilation, and reflexes like vomiting, coughing, sneezing, and swallowing.

Q364: ............is the space between two neurons.

Source: RRB Group-D 30-10-2018 (Shift-I)
Correct! Synapse is the space between two neurons.The transmission of nerve impulses from one neuron to another neuron is completed by synapse. Neuron is the structural and functional unit of nervous system. It consists of dendrites, axon and soma. Dendrites are the small extension of nerve cells that receives signals from sensory receptors or other neurons.The long extension of cell body of nerve cell is called as axon that serves to conduct the nerve impulse away from the cell body.
Incorrect. Synapse is the space between two neurons.The transmission of nerve impulses from one neuron to another neuron is completed by synapse. Neuron is the structural and functional unit of nervous system. It consists of dendrites, axon and soma. Dendrites are the small extension of nerve cells that receives signals from sensory receptors or other neurons.The long extension of cell body of nerve cell is called as axon that serves to conduct the nerve impulse away from the cell body.

Source: RRB NTPC 15.02.2021 (Shift-I) Stage Ist
Correct! See the explanation of the above question.
Incorrect. See the explanation of the above question.

Q366: The junction between two neurons is called:

Source: RRB JE 31.05.2019 (Shift-I)
Correct! The junction between two neurons is called synapse.
Incorrect. The junction between two neurons is called synapse.

Q367: The main thinking part of the brain is

Source: RRB Group-D 29-10-2018 (Shift-III)
Correct! Cerebrum(a major part of forebrain) is the main thinking part of brain. It has sensory, motor and association areas. The forebrain is main thinking part of the brain. It is considered to be the largest of the brain and the major part of the central nervous system.
Incorrect. Cerebrum(a major part of forebrain) is the main thinking part of brain. It has sensory, motor and association areas. The forebrain is main thinking part of the brain. It is considered to be the largest of the brain and the major part of the central nervous system.

Q368: The branch like structure of neurons is called ……….. .

Source: RRB NTPC 03.04.2021 (Shift-II) Stage Ist
Correct! Dendrites are projections of a neuron (nerve cell) that receive signals (information) from other neurons. The transfer of information from one neuron to another is achieved through chemical signals and electric impulses, i.e. electrochemical signals.
Incorrect. Dendrites are projections of a neuron (nerve cell) that receive signals (information) from other neurons. The transfer of information from one neuron to another is achieved through chemical signals and electric impulses, i.e. electrochemical signals.

Q369: Each neuron is formed of a cytone (cell body), from which arises a number of small branched processes called-

Source: RRB Group-D 16-10-2018 (Shift-I)
Correct! Each neuron is formed of a cytone (cell body), from which arises a number of small branched processes called dendrites.These are branch-like structures that receive messages from other neurons and allow the transmission of messages to the cell body. Neurons are the building blocks of the nervous system. They receive and transmit signals to different parts of the body. This is carried out in both physical and electrical forms. There are several different types of neurons that facilitate the transmission of information. Axon is a tube-like structure that carries electrical impulse from the cell body to the axon terminals that passes the impulse to another neuron. Synapse is the chemical junction between the terminal of one neuron and dendrites of another neuron.
Incorrect. Each neuron is formed of a cytone (cell body), from which arises a number of small branched processes called dendrites.These are branch-like structures that receive messages from other neurons and allow the transmission of messages to the cell body. Neurons are the building blocks of the nervous system. They receive and transmit signals to different parts of the body. This is carried out in both physical and electrical forms. There are several different types of neurons that facilitate the transmission of information. Axon is a tube-like structure that carries electrical impulse from the cell body to the axon terminals that passes the impulse to another neuron. Synapse is the chemical junction between the terminal of one neuron and dendrites of another neuron.

Q370: In which part of a neuron is information acquired?

Source: RRB NTPC 05.01.2021 (Shift-I) Stage Ist
Correct! The part of neuron that acquires information is dendrite and the part of neuron through which information travels as an electrical impulse is axon. The transfer of information from neuron to neuron takes place through the release of chemical substance into the space between the axon and the dendrites.
Incorrect. The part of neuron that acquires information is dendrite and the part of neuron through which information travels as an electrical impulse is axon. The transfer of information from neuron to neuron takes place through the release of chemical substance into the space between the axon and the dendrites.

Q371: Involuntary actions such as breathing, salivation and peristalsis are controlled by:

Source: RRB NTPC 15.02.2021 (Shift-I) Stage Ist
Correct! Involuntary actions such as breathing, salivation and peristalsis are controlled by Medulla oblongata. Medulla oblangata is a part of the brain which regulates functions like respiration, sneezing and blood circulation.
Incorrect. Involuntary actions such as breathing, salivation and peristalsis are controlled by Medulla oblongata. Medulla oblangata is a part of the brain which regulates functions like respiration, sneezing and blood circulation.

Q372: Which of the following is not true for cerebellum?

Source: RRB Group-D 12-10-2018 (Shift-III)
Correct! The cerebellum is a part of hind-brain. It maintains equilibrium of body and controls contraction of voluntary muscles. It does not control activities like speaking, seeing, smelling, tasting, hearing and intelligence etc. They are controlled by the cerebrum.
Incorrect. The cerebellum is a part of hind-brain. It maintains equilibrium of body and controls contraction of voluntary muscles. It does not control activities like speaking, seeing, smelling, tasting, hearing and intelligence etc. They are controlled by the cerebrum.

Q373: The image , formed on the retina of the human eye is:

Source: RRB Group-D 11-10-2018 (Shift-II)
Correct! Human eye forms a real but inverted image on the retina. The human eye is part of the body that reacts to light to detect the objects.
Incorrect. Human eye forms a real but inverted image on the retina. The human eye is part of the body that reacts to light to detect the objects.

Q374: The aperture controlling the light entering in the eye is called:

Source: RRB JE 02.06.2019 (Shift-III)
Correct! The pupil is the aperture controlling the light entering in the eye.
Incorrect. The pupil is the aperture controlling the light entering in the eye.

Q375: Which one of the following is not correct about cerebrum?

Source: RRB Group-D 11-10-2018 (Shift-II)
Correct! The brain is the central information and transmission organ of the human body. The brain is mainly divided into three parts, such as the forebrain, mid-brain and hind- brain. The cerebrum is the part of the anterior brain which is about 80% of the brain and it forms the frontal, superior and lateral part of the brain. Thinking, understanding, remembrance, love, hatred, fear etc. are controlled and coordinated by the fore brain while the movements of muscles are controlled by hind- brain.
Incorrect. The brain is the central information and transmission organ of the human body. The brain is mainly divided into three parts, such as the forebrain, mid-brain and hind- brain. The cerebrum is the part of the anterior brain which is about 80% of the brain and it forms the frontal, superior and lateral part of the brain. Thinking, understanding, remembrance, love, hatred, fear etc. are controlled and coordinated by the fore brain while the movements of muscles are controlled by hind- brain.

Q376: Which among the following activities voluntary muscles are involved? A. Jumping of frog B. Movement of food in the stomach C. Pumping of heart D. Writing in hand

Source: RRB Group-D 11-10-2018 (Shift-II)
Correct! Voluntary muscles are made of striated muscle tissues and contract under conscious control. It comprises skeletal muscles, head and thoracic muscles. Jumping of frog and writing in hand are examples of voluntary muscle action.An involuntary action is one which occurs without the conscious choice of an organism. Movement of food in the stomach, contraction - expansion of blood vessels and pumping of heart are examples of involuntary muscle action. Involuntary actions are opposite of voluntary actions that occur because of choice.
Incorrect. Voluntary muscles are made of striated muscle tissues and contract under conscious control. It comprises skeletal muscles, head and thoracic muscles. Jumping of frog and writing in hand are examples of voluntary muscle action.An involuntary action is one which occurs without the conscious choice of an organism. Movement of food in the stomach, contraction - expansion of blood vessels and pumping of heart are examples of involuntary muscle action. Involuntary actions are opposite of voluntary actions that occur because of choice.

Q377: How many spinal nerves are there in human body?

Source: RRB NTPC 03.04.2021 (Shift-II) Stage Ist
Correct! The part of the body which helps in consideration, understanding, memorizing and controlling voluntary and involuntary actions of human body is termed as nervous system. It is of two types: 1– Peripheral Nervous System (PNS) 2– Central Nervous System (CNS) CNS is constituted by spinal and cranial nerves. The human body has 12 pairs of cranial nerves and 31 pairs of spinal nerves.
Incorrect. The part of the body which helps in consideration, understanding, memorizing and controlling voluntary and involuntary actions of human body is termed as nervous system. It is of two types: 1– Peripheral Nervous System (PNS) 2– Central Nervous System (CNS) CNS is constituted by spinal and cranial nerves. The human body has 12 pairs of cranial nerves and 31 pairs of spinal nerves.

Q378: Pinna is the outer part of ……… .

Source: RRB Group-D 08-10-2018 (Shift-II)
Correct! Pinna is the outer part of the ear. The ear is the main part of the auditory system in humans and other mammals. Pinna collects sound waves and sends them to external auditory meatus. It is found in the external ear.
Incorrect. Pinna is the outer part of the ear. The ear is the main part of the auditory system in humans and other mammals. Pinna collects sound waves and sends them to external auditory meatus. It is found in the external ear.

Q382: Which of the following is not correct about cerebellum?

Source: RRB Group-D 11-10-2018 (Shift-III)
Correct! The cerebellum has three parts. There are two lateral lobes and one vermis. Both lateral lobes grow to form a circular shape, called the Cerebellar hemisphere. The upper part of the brain is located in the cerebral cranium, the two small hemispheres of the cerebellum appear to be connected at the bottom of their posterior part. The cerebrum and cerebellum are covered with membranes, which are called meninges.
Incorrect. The cerebellum has three parts. There are two lateral lobes and one vermis. Both lateral lobes grow to form a circular shape, called the Cerebellar hemisphere. The upper part of the brain is located in the cerebral cranium, the two small hemispheres of the cerebellum appear to be connected at the bottom of their posterior part. The cerebrum and cerebellum are covered with membranes, which are called meninges.

Q390: Bone cells are embedded in a hard matrix that is composed of :

Source: RRB Group-D 19-09-2022 (Shift-III)
Correct! Bone cells are embedded in a hard matrix that is composed of calcium and phosphorus. Over 99% calcium and 85% phosphorus present in the mineral forms in bones.

Q391: What is the cause of muscle cramps?

Source: RRB Group-D 17-09-2022 (Shift-II)
Correct! Muscle cramps happen when anaerobic respiration takes place in our muscle cells i.e. when we are doing heavy physical work/exercised then there is lack of oxygen as demand by muscles cause muscle cramps.
Incorrect. Muscle cramps happen when anaerobic respiration takes place in our muscle cells i.e. when we are doing heavy physical work/exercised then there is lack of oxygen as demand by muscles cause muscle cramps.

Q392: What is the difference between striated and smooth muscle cells?

Source: RRB Group-D 12-09-2022 (Shift-II)
Correct! The difference between striated and smooth muscle cells is smooth muscles cannot contract at will, while voluntary muscles contract at will. RRB Science Planner Biology YCT 572
Incorrect. The difference between striated and smooth muscle cells is smooth muscles cannot contract at will, while voluntary muscles contract at will. RRB Science Planner Biology YCT 572

Q394: Which of the following statements is correct about striated muscles?

Source: RRB Group-D 28-09-2022 (Shift-I)
Correct! Striated muscles are highly organized tissues that convert chemical energy to physical work. The primary function of striated muscles is to generate force and contract in order to support respiration, locomotion and posture (skeletal muscle) and to pump blood throughout the body.
Incorrect. Striated muscles are highly organized tissues that convert chemical energy to physical work. The primary function of striated muscles is to generate force and contract in order to support respiration, locomotion and posture (skeletal muscle) and to pump blood throughout the body.

Q395: You get cramps after participating in a 400 m race. Which option best explains the reason for the same?

Source: RRB Group-D– 29/08/2022 (Shift-III)
Correct! Cramps, after participating in a 400 m race is due to lack of oxygen and pyruvate converted to lactic acid. Overuse of muscle, dehydration, muscle strain can cause a muscle cramp.
Incorrect. Cramps, after participating in a 400 m race is due to lack of oxygen and pyruvate converted to lactic acid. Overuse of muscle, dehydration, muscle strain can cause a muscle cramp.

Q396: The movement of food in the alimentary canal is brought about by the smooth muscles in the body. Which of the following options has all the organs having smooth muscles?

Source: RRB Group-D– 02/09/2022 (Shift-I)
Correct! Smooth muscle is found throughout the body where it serves a variety of functions. It is in the stomach and intestines where it helps with digestion and nutrient collection. It is found throughout the urinary system where it functions to help rid of the body from toxins and works in electrolyte balance. Hence, option (a) is right answer.
Incorrect. Smooth muscle is found throughout the body where it serves a variety of functions. It is in the stomach and intestines where it helps with digestion and nutrient collection. It is found throughout the urinary system where it functions to help rid of the body from toxins and works in electrolyte balance. Hence, option (a) is right answer.

Q397: Which one of the following statement is NOT correct?

Source: RRB NTPC 15.03.2021 (Shift-II) Stage Ist
Correct! In the given statements, option (d) is incorrect because our vertebral column is formed by 26 serially arranged units called vertebrae and is dorsally placed. It extends from the base of the skull and constitutes the main framework of the trunk. The vertebral column is differentiated into cervical (7), thoracic (12), lumbar (5), sacral (1-fused) and coccygeal (1-fused) regions starting from the skull. Point to be noted is that there are 33 small vertebrae in the vertebral column of the child.
Incorrect. In the given statements, option (d) is incorrect because our vertebral column is formed by 26 serially arranged units called vertebrae and is dorsally placed. It extends from the base of the skull and constitutes the main framework of the trunk. The vertebral column is differentiated into cervical (7), thoracic (12), lumbar (5), sacral (1-fused) and coccygeal (1-fused) regions starting from the skull. Point to be noted is that there are 33 small vertebrae in the vertebral column of the child.

Q398: In humans, the tissue that connects the muscles to bones is called:

Source: RRB J.E. (14.12.2014, Green paper)
Correct! A tendon is a fibrous connective tissue which attaches muscle to bone. Both tendons & ligaments are made of collagen. The tendon is equivalent to the ligaments. A ligament is a fibrous connective tissue which attaches bone to bone, and usually serves to hold structures together and keep them stable.
Incorrect. A tendon is a fibrous connective tissue which attaches muscle to bone. Both tendons & ligaments are made of collagen. The tendon is equivalent to the ligaments. A ligament is a fibrous connective tissue which attaches bone to bone, and usually serves to hold structures together and keep them stable.

Q399: A tendon made of:

Source: RRB ALP & Tec. (31-08-18 Shift-II)
Correct! The end of muscles is called tendon. It connects muscles to bones or cartilage. A tendon is a tough band of fibrous connective tissue that usually connects muscle to bone and is capable of withstanding tension. These are made up of long bands of collagen. The collagen portion is made up of 97–98% type I collagen, with small amounts of other types of collagen.
Incorrect. The end of muscles is called tendon. It connects muscles to bones or cartilage. A tendon is a tough band of fibrous connective tissue that usually connects muscle to bone and is capable of withstanding tension. These are made up of long bands of collagen. The collagen portion is made up of 97–98% type I collagen, with small amounts of other types of collagen.

Source: RRB J.E. 2014 (14.12.2014 Set-2, Red Paper)
Correct! Lactic acid causes pain in our muscles. Due to accumulation of lactic acid in the muscles, body feels fatigue more and persists pain.
Incorrect. Lactic acid causes pain in our muscles. Due to accumulation of lactic acid in the muscles, body feels fatigue more and persists pain.

Q402: What is the total number of bones in the skeleton of an average adult human?

Source: RRB J.E. 2014 (14.12.2014 Red Paper)
Correct! The structure of the human body is made up of bones. All bones are connected to each other. There are muscles above the bones, which helps joints of bones in movement. Bones and muscles protect the internal organs of the body. There are 206 bones are found in human body. The organ forming the structure of the human body is called the skeletal system.
Incorrect. The structure of the human body is made up of bones. All bones are connected to each other. There are muscles above the bones, which helps joints of bones in movement. Bones and muscles protect the internal organs of the body. There are 206 bones are found in human body. The organ forming the structure of the human body is called the skeletal system.

Q403: The ……… has abundant white fibres.

Source: RRB ALP & Tec. (20-08-18 Shift-I)
Correct! Abundant white fibres are found in tendons. The end of muscles is called tendon. These connect muscles to bones or cartilages. These are strong band- like structures of connective tissues made of dense collagen fibers.
Incorrect. Abundant white fibres are found in tendons. The end of muscles is called tendon. These connect muscles to bones or cartilages. These are strong band- like structures of connective tissues made of dense collagen fibers.

Incorrect. There are total 206 bones in human body, in which the longest bone is the femur which is found in the thigh. Whereas the smallest bone is the stapes, found in the ear. The hardest part of the body is the enamel of the tooth.

Q408: Approximately, how many bones are there in a child's body at the time of birth?

Source: RRB NTPC 30.01.2021 (Shift-II) Stage Ist
Correct! A boy's body has about 300 bones at birth. They eventually fuse to form the 206 bones that adults have. Some of a baby's bones are made entirely of a special material called cartilage. Other bones in a baby are partly made of cartilage.
Incorrect. A boy's body has about 300 bones at birth. They eventually fuse to form the 206 bones that adults have. Some of a baby's bones are made entirely of a special material called cartilage. Other bones in a baby are partly made of cartilage.

Q409: How many bones does a new born human baby have?

Source: RRB NTPC 16.04.2016 (Shift-I) Stage Ist
Correct! The human baby has 270 bones (about 350) in its body, while 206 bones are found in adult. 29 bones are found in human skull. The largest bone in the body is the femur (in the thigh) and the smallest bone in the human body is the stapes (in the ear). The total number of muscles in the body is 639.
Incorrect. The human baby has 270 bones (about 350) in its body, while 206 bones are found in adult. 29 bones are found in human skull. The largest bone in the body is the femur (in the thigh) and the smallest bone in the human body is the stapes (in the ear). The total number of muscles in the body is 639.

Incorrect. Ligament is a connective tissue which joints one bone to another bone. Tendon is also a connective tissue which joints muscles to bones.

Q415: Which is the smallest bone of the human body?

Correct! Our body comprises of 206 bones. * The smallest bone in the human body is called stapes, located in the middle ear. There are three bones in the middle ear- malleus, stapes and incus. * Femur or thigh bone is the largest and heaviest bone in the human body. RRB Science Planner Biology YCT 574
Incorrect. Our body comprises of 206 bones. * The smallest bone in the human body is called stapes, located in the middle ear. There are three bones in the middle ear- malleus, stapes and incus. * Femur or thigh bone is the largest and heaviest bone in the human body. RRB Science Planner Biology YCT 574

Q421: Which is the hardest substance in the human body?

Source: RRB JE 23.05.2019 (Shift-I)
Correct! Tooth enamel is the hardest substance in the human body. Tooth enamel protects teeth from decay and cavities. When it is damaged or destroyed, teeth and gums are more susceptible to oral health issues more serious disease.
Incorrect. Tooth enamel is the hardest substance in the human body. Tooth enamel protects teeth from decay and cavities. When it is damaged or destroyed, teeth and gums are more susceptible to oral health issues more serious disease.

Q422: There are 29 bones in the human head. Which of the following classifications is correct?

Source: RRB NTPC 03.04.2021 (Shift-I) Stage Ist
Correct! The 29 head bones consist of 8 cranial bones,14 facial bones, 1 hyoid bones and 6 auditory bones(Ear). The 8 cranial bones are the frontal, 2 parietal, occipital, 2 temporal, sphenoid and ethmoid bones.
Incorrect. The 29 head bones consist of 8 cranial bones,14 facial bones, 1 hyoid bones and 6 auditory bones(Ear). The 8 cranial bones are the frontal, 2 parietal, occipital, 2 temporal, sphenoid and ethmoid bones.

Q423: Which part of the human body is formed by the fusing of the ilium, ischium and the pubis?

Source: RRB NTPC 22.01.2021 (Shift-I) Stage Ist
Correct! The hip bone of the human body is formed by fusing of the illium, ischium and pubis. It lies in the hip of the human body. At the end of the teenage the illium, ischium and pubis converge and form hip bone.
Incorrect. The hip bone of the human body is formed by fusing of the illium, ischium and pubis. It lies in the hip of the human body. At the end of the teenage the illium, ischium and pubis converge and form hip bone.

Q424: Which is the strongest bone of the human body?

Source: RRB JE 27.05.2019 (Shift-I)
Correct! The strongest bone in the human body is the thigh bone(femur).
Incorrect. The strongest bone in the human body is the thigh bone(femur).

Q425: What are the bones around the chest called?

Source: RRB NTPC 05.04.2016 (Shift-II) Stage Ist
Correct! Ribs are the long curved bones which form the rib cage, part of the axial skeleton.The ribs are the bony framework of the thoracic cavity that help in protection of it.
Incorrect. Ribs are the long curved bones which form the rib cage, part of the axial skeleton.The ribs are the bony framework of the thoracic cavity that help in protection of it.

Q426: Which one of the following is not an axial bone?

Source: RRB NTPC 03.04.2016 (Shift-III) Stage Ist
Correct! The axial skeleton is the part of the skeleton that consists of the bones of the head,skull,spinal cord and trunk of a vertebrate.The axial skeleton supports the head, neck, back, and chest and thus forms the vertical axis of the body, while scapula is not the axial bone.
Incorrect. The axial skeleton is the part of the skeleton that consists of the bones of the head,skull,spinal cord and trunk of a vertebrate.The axial skeleton supports the head, neck, back, and chest and thus forms the vertical axis of the body, while scapula is not the axial bone.

Q427: Spine is also called ……. .

Source: RRB JE 29.05.2019 (Shift-I)
Correct! The spine is also called the spinal cord.
Incorrect. The spine is also called the spinal cord.

Q428: What is the lubricating fluid found between the two bones at a movable joint called?

Source: RRB NTPC 22.02.2021 (Shift-I) Stage Ist
Correct! Synovial fluid also known as joint fluid is a thick liquid located between two joints. The fluid cushions the ends of bones and reduces friction when we move our joints. It is on all of two joints, including in our knee, shoulders, hips, hands and feet.
Incorrect. Synovial fluid also known as joint fluid is a thick liquid located between two joints. The fluid cushions the ends of bones and reduces friction when we move our joints. It is on all of two joints, including in our knee, shoulders, hips, hands and feet.

Q429: Where are involuntary muscles located in a human body?

Source: RRB NTPC 31.03.2016 (Shift-III) Stage Ist
Correct! The involuntary muscles are located in heart of a human body. On the basis of structure and function, there are three types of muscle tissue recognized in vertebrates: (1) Voluntary muscles: They anchored to bone by tendons,that is why they are also called Skeletal muscles. They are used to effect skeletal movement in activities such as locomotion and maintaining posture. These muscles are responsible to react to conscious control of human, so they are known as voluntary muscles. RRB Science Planner Biology YCT 575 (2) Involuntary muscles: Involuntary muscles include all muscles whose activity is independent and not affected by voluntary nerve activity. (3) Cardiac muscles: Cardiac muscles are striated muscles that is present only in the walls of heart under involuntary action.
Incorrect. The involuntary muscles are located in heart of a human body. On the basis of structure and function, there are three types of muscle tissue recognized in vertebrates: (1) Voluntary muscles: They anchored to bone by tendons,that is why they are also called Skeletal muscles. They are used to effect skeletal movement in activities such as locomotion and maintaining posture. These muscles are responsible to react to conscious control of human, so they are known as voluntary muscles. RRB Science Planner Biology YCT 575 (2) Involuntary muscles: Involuntary muscles include all muscles whose activity is independent and not affected by voluntary nerve activity. (3) Cardiac muscles: Cardiac muscles are striated muscles that is present only in the walls of heart under involuntary action.

Q430: ..........connects muscles to bones.

Source: RRB Group-D 24-10-2018 (Shift-III)
Correct! The tendon serves to connect the muscles to the bones. The ends of muscles are known as tendon. Tendon connects the muscles to the bones or cartilage. These are strong band-like structures of connective tissue composed of dense collagen fibers, which are extensions of the Epimysium surrounding the muscle. There is also no contraction due to lack of flexibility in tendon.
Incorrect. The tendon serves to connect the muscles to the bones. The ends of muscles are known as tendon. Tendon connects the muscles to the bones or cartilage. These are strong band-like structures of connective tissue composed of dense collagen fibers, which are extensions of the Epimysium surrounding the muscle. There is also no contraction due to lack of flexibility in tendon.

Q431: Bone cells are embedded in a hard matrix that is composed of-

Source: RRB Group-D 26-09-2018 (Shift-II)
Correct! Bone cells are embedded in a hard matrix that is composed of Calcium (Ca) and Phosphorus (P). The body of all organisms is made up of cell. The living cells found in bones, are called bone cells.
Incorrect. Bone cells are embedded in a hard matrix that is composed of Calcium (Ca) and Phosphorus (P). The body of all organisms is made up of cell. The living cells found in bones, are called bone cells.

Q432: The force generated by the action of muscles, is called....

Source: RRB Group-D 30-10-2018 (Shift-II)
Correct! The force generated by the action of muscles is called muscular force. When we lift an object with our hands or kick an object with our feet, we apply muscular force because this force is exerted pressure in our muscle.
Incorrect. The force generated by the action of muscles is called muscular force. When we lift an object with our hands or kick an object with our feet, we apply muscular force because this force is exerted pressure in our muscle.

Q433: Voluntary muscles are contained in the …….. .

Source: RRB Group-D 28-09-2018 (Shift-I)
Correct! Voluntary or linear muscles are formed by multinucleated fibers. This type of muscles found in the hands, feet, neck etc., while involuntary muscles or non-linear muscles are found in the iris, testis, alimentary canal , bladder and heart etc.
Incorrect. Voluntary or linear muscles are formed by multinucleated fibers. This type of muscles found in the hands, feet, neck etc., while involuntary muscles or non-linear muscles are found in the iris, testis, alimentary canal , bladder and heart etc.

Q434: The………….. make soft the surface of the bone at the joint.

Source: RRB Group-D 26-09-2018 (Shift-III)
Correct! The cartilage softens the surface of the bone at the joint. Cartilage is a flexible connective tissue found in the human body and other animals. It is made up of chondrocytes cells, located in our bone marrow. Ear bone, nose bone, joints of bones etc. are made of cartilages.
Incorrect. The cartilage softens the surface of the bone at the joint. Cartilage is a flexible connective tissue found in the human body and other animals. It is made up of chondrocytes cells, located in our bone marrow. Ear bone, nose bone, joints of bones etc. are made of cartilages.

Q435: Bone cells are embedded in a hard matrix, which is made of …………. .

Source: RRB Group-D 07-12-2018 (Shift-I)
Correct! Phosphorus is essential for the formation of bones and teeth in the human body. It combines with calcium to form calcium phosphate. Calcium phosphate is an insoluble salt, which is important for the formation of bones and teeth. Calcium phosphate is stored in bones and teeth, which gives them firmness, strength and stability.
Incorrect. Phosphorus is essential for the formation of bones and teeth in the human body. It combines with calcium to form calcium phosphate. Calcium phosphate is an insoluble salt, which is important for the formation of bones and teeth. Calcium phosphate is stored in bones and teeth, which gives them firmness, strength and stability.

Q436: Which mineral is essential for bones?

Source: RRB JE 25.05.2019 (Shift-I)
Correct! Calcium is essential mineral for bones.
Incorrect. Calcium is essential mineral for bones.

Q437: ...........muscles are also called skeletal muscles.

Source: RRB Group-D 07-12-2018 (Shift-I)
Correct! Voluntary muscles are attached to bones, so they are also called skeletal muscles. These muscles are under the control of human conscious, hence they are also called voluntary muscles. Each muscle cell is multinucleated. Excessive exercise or work causes lactic acid to build up, causing fatigue. These muscles are mainly found in hands, feet, neck, eyes etc. Voluntary muscles work in the control of the brain or spinal cord.
Incorrect. Voluntary muscles are attached to bones, so they are also called skeletal muscles. These muscles are under the control of human conscious, hence they are also called voluntary muscles. Each muscle cell is multinucleated. Excessive exercise or work causes lactic acid to build up, causing fatigue. These muscles are mainly found in hands, feet, neck, eyes etc. Voluntary muscles work in the control of the brain or spinal cord.

Q438: What is the smallest muscle of human body?

Source: RRB JE 02.06.2019 (Shift-I)
Correct! Stapedius is the smallest muscle in the human body.
Incorrect. Stapedius is the smallest muscle in the human body.

Q439: –––––– connects muscles to bones.

Source: RRB Group-D 06-12-2018 (Shift-III)
Correct! The tendon connects muscles to bones. Ligament connects bones to bones.
Incorrect. The tendon connects muscles to bones. Ligament connects bones to bones.

Q440: The muscles help the heart to pump blood to all parts of the body, which requires rhythmic contraction and relaxation.

Source: RRB Group-D 27-11-2018 (Shift-III)
Correct! Cardiac muscles help the heart to pump blood to all parts of the body, requiring rhythmic contraction and relaxation. Heart muscle is the involuntary muscles found in the heart walls. This muscle fibers are branching and monocular. The heart muscle continuous to contraction and relax with a non-stop, weary rhythm throughout life, resulting in continuous blood circulation in the body.
Incorrect. Cardiac muscles help the heart to pump blood to all parts of the body, requiring rhythmic contraction and relaxation. Heart muscle is the involuntary muscles found in the heart walls. This muscle fibers are branching and monocular. The heart muscle continuous to contraction and relax with a non-stop, weary rhythm throughout life, resulting in continuous blood circulation in the body.

Q441: ...............is a connective tissue with a minimal matrix.

Source: RRB Group-D 07-12-2018 (Shift-III)
Correct! The cells of the connective tissue are less interconnected and are embedded in the intercellular adipose. The connective tissue connecting two bones is called a ligament. This tissue is very flexible and strong. It has a minimal matrix. RRB Science Planner Biology YCT 576
Incorrect. The cells of the connective tissue are less interconnected and are embedded in the intercellular adipose. The connective tissue connecting two bones is called a ligament. This tissue is very flexible and strong. It has a minimal matrix. RRB Science Planner Biology YCT 576

Q442: Striped muscles fibres are . ... . . . . . :

Source: RRB Group-D 05-12-2018 (Shift-III)
Correct! Striped muscles are also called skeletal muscles because they are attached to vertebral skeletons. Striated muscle are skeletal muscle cells like muscle fibers. These are elongated or tubular and they have multiple nuclei which are located on the periphery of the cell. Striated muscles bring voluntary contractions that is why hand, feet and other organ move smoothly.
Incorrect. Striped muscles are also called skeletal muscles because they are attached to vertebral skeletons. Striated muscle are skeletal muscle cells like muscle fibers. These are elongated or tubular and they have multiple nuclei which are located on the periphery of the cell. Striated muscles bring voluntary contractions that is why hand, feet and other organ move smoothly.

Q443: Which of the following hormones makes the heart beat faster in order to supply more oxygen to our muscles?

Source: RRB Group-D 02-11-2018 (Shift-III)
Correct! Adrenaline is a hormone secreted from the adrenal gland that secretes when the body is stimulated. That is why it is also called 'fight and flight' hormone. It increases the blood flow in our muscles at the time of crisis and makes the heart beat faster in order to supply more oxygen to our muscles (due to stimulation).
Incorrect. Adrenaline is a hormone secreted from the adrenal gland that secretes when the body is stimulated. That is why it is also called 'fight and flight' hormone. It increases the blood flow in our muscles at the time of crisis and makes the heart beat faster in order to supply more oxygen to our muscles (due to stimulation).

Q444: The two bones can be connected to each other by another connective tissue , is called ………. .

Source: RRB Group-D 22-09-2018 (Shift-I)
Correct! The ligament is a fibrous connective tissue, which attaches bone to bone and usually serves to hold structures together and keep them stable. This tissue is very elastic. It has considerable strength. It provides a structural framework to the body.
Incorrect. The ligament is a fibrous connective tissue, which attaches bone to bone and usually serves to hold structures together and keep them stable. This tissue is very elastic. It has considerable strength. It provides a structural framework to the body.

Q445: Vibrations inside the ear is amplified by three bones, namly the ………… in the middle ear.

Source: RRB Group-D 22-09-2018 (Shift-I)
Correct! The vibration inside the ear is amplified by three bones: (i) Hammer: Its outer end is connected to the ear screen and the inner wide end is attached to the incus. It is similar to a hammer. Its length is 8- 9mm. (ii) Anvil: Its outer end is attached to the malleus and the inner end is connected to the stirrup. Due to its shape like an anvil, it is called an anvil. Its length is 7 mm. (iii) Stirrup: This bone is like the stirrup of riding saddle of horse. A hole is found in its middle.
Incorrect. The vibration inside the ear is amplified by three bones: (i) Hammer: Its outer end is connected to the ear screen and the inner wide end is attached to the incus. It is similar to a hammer. Its length is 8- 9mm. (ii) Anvil: Its outer end is attached to the malleus and the inner end is connected to the stirrup. Due to its shape like an anvil, it is called an anvil. Its length is 7 mm. (iii) Stirrup: This bone is like the stirrup of riding saddle of horse. A hole is found in its middle.

Q446: Due to the presence of ........ in our ear, which is a type of connective tissue, the ears can be folded -

Source: RRB Group-D 20-09-2018 (Shift-II)
Correct! Cartilage is the flexible connective tissue found in the human body and other animals. It is made up of chondrocytes cells present in our marrow. Ear bone, nose bone, joints of bones around the spine are made of cartilage. The ears can be folded due to its elasticity.
Incorrect. Cartilage is the flexible connective tissue found in the human body and other animals. It is made up of chondrocytes cells present in our marrow. Ear bone, nose bone, joints of bones around the spine are made of cartilage. The ears can be folded due to its elasticity.

Incorrect. The names of the three bones present in the middle ear are hammer, anvil, stirrup.

Q455: Which hormone helps the body to adjust in stress when one is very angry, embarrassed worried?

Source: RRB Group-D 28-09-2022 (Shift-II)
Correct! The Hormone Adrenaline helps the body to adjust the stress when one is very angry, embarrassed or worried. Adrenaline rapidly secretion is the name for quick release of adrenaline into your bloodstream. This gets your body ready for a fight or flight response.
Incorrect. The Hormone Adrenaline helps the body to adjust the stress when one is very angry, embarrassed or worried. Adrenaline rapidly secretion is the name for quick release of adrenaline into your bloodstream. This gets your body ready for a fight or flight response.

Q456: Which of the following is termed as a hunger hormone as it stimulates appetite, increases food intake and promotes fat storage?

Source: RRB NTPC (Stage-II) –12/06/2022 (Shift-II)
Correct! Ghrelin is hormone produced by enteroendocrine cell of the gastrointestinal tract, especially the stomach, and is often called a "hunger hormone" because it increases food intake.
Incorrect. Ghrelin is hormone produced by enteroendocrine cell of the gastrointestinal tract, especially the stomach, and is often called a "hunger hormone" because it increases food intake.

Q457: Which of the following glands produces insulin hormone?

Source: RRB NTPC 31.07.2021 (Shift-I) Stage Ist
