Incorrect. Insulin is a hormone which is made by beta cells in our pancreas, which allows glucose to enter the body’s cells to provide energy.

Q458: What is the function of insulin in the human body?

Source: RRB NTPC 22.02.2021 (Shift-II) Stage Ist
Correct! Insulin is an essential hormone produced by the pancreas. Its main role is to control glucose levels in our bodies.
Incorrect. Insulin is an essential hormone produced by the pancreas. Its main role is to control glucose levels in our bodies.

Q459: Which element is essential for the synthesis of thyroxine?

Source: RRB ALP & Tec. (09-08-18 Shift-II)
Correct! Thyroxine is neutral chemical compound. Kidney and liver alongwith their mutual action, converts it into an active compound known as Tri- iodothyronine. Micro nutrients like Iodine and Selenium are responsible for the synthesis of Thyroxine.
Incorrect. Thyroxine is neutral chemical compound. Kidney and liver alongwith their mutual action, converts it into an active compound known as Tri- iodothyronine. Micro nutrients like Iodine and Selenium are responsible for the synthesis of Thyroxine.

Q465: Which of the following pigments is mainly responsible for the colour of our hair, skin and eyes?

Source: RRB NTPC 24.07.2021 (Shift-II) Stage Ist
Correct! Melanin is a natural skin pigment. Hair, Skin, and Eye color in people and animals mostly depends on the type and amount of melanin they have.
Incorrect. Melanin is a natural skin pigment. Hair, Skin, and Eye color in people and animals mostly depends on the type and amount of melanin they have.

Q466: ............. is not an endocrine glands in humans.

Source: RRB ALP & Tec. (10-08-18 Shift-III)
Correct! Thomas Addison is known as the 'Father of Endocrine System'. The study of endocrine system is called endocrinology. Pineal, adrenal, pituitary glands are endocrine glands. The liver is a digestive gland. It is the largest gland of the body that acts as endocrine and exocrine gland.
Incorrect. Thomas Addison is known as the 'Father of Endocrine System'. The study of endocrine system is called endocrinology. Pineal, adrenal, pituitary glands are endocrine glands. The liver is a digestive gland. It is the largest gland of the body that acts as endocrine and exocrine gland.

Q467: What does the Adrenal gland secretes?

Correct! The key hormones produced by the adrenal gland includes– Cortisol, Aldosterone, DHEA, Adrenaline, etc.
Incorrect. The key hormones produced by the adrenal gland includes– Cortisol, Aldosterone, DHEA, Adrenaline, etc.

Q468: Secretion of insulin hormone is caused by ………….

Source: RRB J.E. 2014 (14.12.2014 Red Paper)
Correct! Insulin is an endocrine hormone secreted by the pancreas.. Beta cells produce insulin which is responsible for reducing blood glucose levels and increasing protein formation. Alpha cells that produce glucagon help to increase glucose levels in the blood. Delta cells produces somatostatin, which maintains a balance between the release of insulin and glucagon. Thyroid gland - The thyroid is an endocrine gland in the throat. The thyroid gland releases thyroid hormones, which mainly affect metabolic rate and protein synthesis. Adrenal gland - The adrenal gland is an endocrine gland found in vertebrates. It is situated above the kidney. Pituitary gland - Pituitary gland is an endocrine gland, that is pea - shaped and weighs 0.5 gm. (0.02 oz). It is a protrusion off the bottom of the hypothalamus at the base of the brain.
Incorrect. Insulin is an endocrine hormone secreted by the pancreas.. Beta cells produce insulin which is responsible for reducing blood glucose levels and increasing protein formation. Alpha cells that produce glucagon help to increase glucose levels in the blood. Delta cells produces somatostatin, which maintains a balance between the release of insulin and glucagon. Thyroid gland - The thyroid is an endocrine gland in the throat. The thyroid gland releases thyroid hormones, which mainly affect metabolic rate and protein synthesis. Adrenal gland - The adrenal gland is an endocrine gland found in vertebrates. It is situated above the kidney. Pituitary gland - Pituitary gland is an endocrine gland, that is pea - shaped and weighs 0.5 gm. (0.02 oz). It is a protrusion off the bottom of the hypothalamus at the base of the brain.

Q469: Which part of the human body consists sweat glands?

Source: RRB NTPC 12.04.2016 (Shift-I) Stage Ist
Correct! Sweat glands are present in the skin of human body. Sweat is released from the sweat glands found in the skin. These are called eccrine sweat gland. Sweat contains 99% water and a small amount of salt, protein and urea.
Incorrect. Sweat glands are present in the skin of human body. Sweat is released from the sweat glands found in the skin. These are called eccrine sweat gland. Sweat contains 99% water and a small amount of salt, protein and urea.

Q470: The endocrine glands are also called ––––––.

Source: RRB Group-D 23-10-2018 (Shift-I)
Correct! The endocrine glands do not have ducts, so they are called ductless glands. Endocrine glands and hormone-secreting cells located in different parts of the human body, form the endocrine system. The pituitary gland, pineal gland, thyroid, adrenal, pancreatic, parathyroid, thymus and reproductive glands are the well-organized endocrine organs of our body.
Incorrect. The endocrine glands do not have ducts, so they are called ductless glands. Endocrine glands and hormone-secreting cells located in different parts of the human body, form the endocrine system. The pituitary gland, pineal gland, thyroid, adrenal, pancreatic, parathyroid, thymus and reproductive glands are the well-organized endocrine organs of our body.

Incorrect. The thyroid gland is located to the front of the neck just below the larynx.

Incorrect. The pancreatic islet cell include alpha cells, which produce glucagon ; beta cells, which produce insulin; delta cells, which produce somatostatin; and PP cells, which produce pancreatic polypeptide.

Q475: Match the following in the correct order: Hormone Secretory gland (P) Hormones of Colip a. Adrenal gland (Q) Aldosterone b. Pineal gland (R) Prolactin c. Parathyroid gland (S) Melatonin d. Pituitary gland

Q476: Graves (Exophthalmic Goitre) disease is caused by over-secretion of .............. due to increase in thyroid.

Source: RRB NTPC Stage Ist 30.04.2016 (Shift-I)
Correct! Oversecretion of thyroid hormones (hyperthyroidism) causes Graves disease which is characterized by formation of exophthalmic goitre. Weight loss, eyes bulging from eye sockets,growth in thyroid gland and basic metabolic rate etc are characterstics of exophthalmic goitre. It is known as Graves disease .
Incorrect. Oversecretion of thyroid hormones (hyperthyroidism) causes Graves disease which is characterized by formation of exophthalmic goitre. Weight loss, eyes bulging from eye sockets,growth in thyroid gland and basic metabolic rate etc are characterstics of exophthalmic goitre. It is known as Graves disease .

Q477: Which of the following hormones is not secreted by the pituitary gland?

Source: RRB NTPC Stage Ist 27.04.2016 (Shift-I)
Correct! A part in the pancreas is called the ‘Islets of Langerhans’. A hormone called ‘somatostatin’ is released from the delta cell of the Islets of Langerhans. Insulin acts to determine blood sugar levels. Low secretion of insulin results Diabetes . This hormone is not secreted by the pituitary gland.
Incorrect. A part in the pancreas is called the ‘Islets of Langerhans’. A hormone called ‘somatostatin’ is released from the delta cell of the Islets of Langerhans. Insulin acts to determine blood sugar levels. Low secretion of insulin results Diabetes . This hormone is not secreted by the pituitary gland.

Source: RRB JE 24.05.2019 (Shift-I)
Correct! See the explanation of the above question.
Incorrect. See the explanation of the above question.

Q479: Which among the following is not digestive enzyme?

Source: RRB NTPC Stage Ist 26.04.2016 (Shift-III)
Correct! Proteases, amylases and lipases are digestive enzymes, while superoxide dismutase is an enzyme that helps break down potentially harmful oxygen molecules in cells.
Incorrect. Proteases, amylases and lipases are digestive enzymes, while superoxide dismutase is an enzyme that helps break down potentially harmful oxygen molecules in cells.

Q480: Which acid is secreted by certain glandular cells of the stomach lining?

Source: RRB NTPC Stage Ist 26.04.2016 (Shift-II)
Correct! Certain glandular cells in the stomach lining secrete hydrochloric acid. The digestive glands that are present in the wall of the alimentary canal are called internal digestive glands. It consists all mucous glands, intestinal glands and Brunner's glands, predominantly located in the duodenal submucosa. Formic acid is found in ants. Nitric acid is corrosive acid.
Incorrect. Certain glandular cells in the stomach lining secrete hydrochloric acid. The digestive glands that are present in the wall of the alimentary canal are called internal digestive glands. It consists all mucous glands, intestinal glands and Brunner's glands, predominantly located in the duodenal submucosa. Formic acid is found in ants. Nitric acid is corrosive acid.

Q481: Which organ is not a gland?

Source: RRB NTPC 06.04.2016 (Shift-I) Stage Ist
Correct! Adrenal, liver and pituitary gland are three endocrine glands whereas the gall bladder is a bile collecting organ.
Incorrect. Adrenal, liver and pituitary gland are three endocrine glands whereas the gall bladder is a bile collecting organ.

Q482: Our skin becomes dark as soon as it is exposed to sunlight, this occurs due to presence of :

Source: RRB NTPC 12.04.2016 (Shift-I) Stage Ist
Correct! Our skin becomes dark as soon as it is exposed to sunlight, this occurs due to presence of melanin. In animals, melanin is made from an amino acid called tyrosine. The most commonly found form of melanin in organisms is called eumelanin and is dark brown colour. In humans, this pigment gives colour to skin and eye. 99.9% of the ultraviolet radiation that falls on our body is prevented by melanin.
Incorrect. Our skin becomes dark as soon as it is exposed to sunlight, this occurs due to presence of melanin. In animals, melanin is made from an amino acid called tyrosine. The most commonly found form of melanin in organisms is called eumelanin and is dark brown colour. In humans, this pigment gives colour to skin and eye. 99.9% of the ultraviolet radiation that falls on our body is prevented by melanin.

Q483: Human hypothalamus gland is ……………….

Source: RRB NTPC 18.01.2017 (Shift-I) Stage IInd
Correct! The hypothalamus is the gland present in the brain, which connects the nervous system with the endocrine system through the pituitary gland. It regulates body temperature, food, water balance etc. associated with visceral and other physical activities.
Incorrect. The hypothalamus is the gland present in the brain, which connects the nervous system with the endocrine system through the pituitary gland. It regulates body temperature, food, water balance etc. associated with visceral and other physical activities.

Q484: The gland of human body that secretes both enzymes and hormones:

Source: RRB NTPC Stage Ist 22.04.2016 (Shift-II)
Correct! Pancreatic gland of human body that secretes both enzymes and hormones. Pancreatic juice is secreted by pancreatic cells. It contains 98% water and the remaining 2% contains salts and enzymes. It is an alkaline fluid. Pancreatic juice contains three types of digestive juices, also called absolute digestive juices, the main five enzymes being trypsin, amylase, carboxypeptidase, lipase and maltase.
Incorrect. Pancreatic gland of human body that secretes both enzymes and hormones. Pancreatic juice is secreted by pancreatic cells. It contains 98% water and the remaining 2% contains salts and enzymes. It is an alkaline fluid. Pancreatic juice contains three types of digestive juices, also called absolute digestive juices, the main five enzymes being trypsin, amylase, carboxypeptidase, lipase and maltase.

Q485: Where are the Islets of Langerhans found in the human body?

Source: RRB NTPC 29.03.2016 (Shift-I) Stage Ist
Correct! Islets of Langerhans are found in the pancreas in the human body. Langerhans was discovered by a medical practitioner named Langerhans. Its alpha-cell emits glucagon, beta-cell form insulin and gamma-cell release somatostatin. Increase in blood sugar levels is called Diabetes.
Incorrect. Islets of Langerhans are found in the pancreas in the human body. Langerhans was discovered by a medical practitioner named Langerhans. Its alpha-cell emits glucagon, beta-cell form insulin and gamma-cell release somatostatin. Increase in blood sugar levels is called Diabetes.

Q486: In the human body, the pancreas is a part of……..:

Source: RRB NTPC 31.03.2016 (Shift-I) Stage Ist
Correct! The pancreas is a part of the digestive system in the human body. It is the second largest gland of the human body. Its main feature is that it acts as endocrine and exocrine gland. It is located in the 'U' shaped part of the small intestine.
Incorrect. The pancreas is a part of the digestive system in the human body. It is the second largest gland of the human body. Its main feature is that it acts as endocrine and exocrine gland. It is located in the 'U' shaped part of the small intestine.

Q487: Which of the following is responsible for dwarfism in humans?

Source: RRB NTPC 18.01.2021 (Shift-II) Stage Ist
Correct! Dwarfism is caused by problems arising from the pituitary gland or Growth Hormone Dificiency (GHD). The pea-sized pituitary gland is located at the base of brain. It makes hormones that control many functions in body.
Incorrect. Dwarfism is caused by problems arising from the pituitary gland or Growth Hormone Dificiency (GHD). The pea-sized pituitary gland is located at the base of brain. It makes hormones that control many functions in body.

Q488: Which among the following hormones is not secreted by the thyroid gland?

Source: RRB NTPC 12.04.2016 (Shift-I) Stage Ist
Correct! The thymus gland plays significant role in the development of the immune system. This gland secretes a peptide hormone called thymosin. Synthesis of thyroxine or T4, triiodothyronine or T3 and Thyrocalcitonin hormones is accomplished by the thyroid gland. RRB Science Planner Biology YCT 580
Incorrect. The thymus gland plays significant role in the development of the immune system. This gland secretes a peptide hormone called thymosin. Synthesis of thyroxine or T4, triiodothyronine or T3 and Thyrocalcitonin hormones is accomplished by the thyroid gland. RRB Science Planner Biology YCT 580

Q489: Which gland is active only till puberty?

Source: RRB JE 23.05.2019 (Shift-III)
Correct! The thymus gland, located behind sternum and between lungs, is only active till puberty. After puberty, the thymus starts to slowly shrink and become replaced by fat. Thymosin is the hormone of the thymus, and it stimulates the development of disease-fighting T cells..
Incorrect. The thymus gland, located behind sternum and between lungs, is only active till puberty. After puberty, the thymus starts to slowly shrink and become replaced by fat. Thymosin is the hormone of the thymus, and it stimulates the development of disease-fighting T cells..

Q490: What is full name of A.D.H.?

Source: RRB NTPC 10.04.2016 (Shift-III) Stage Ist
Correct! The full form of ADH is antidiuretic hormone. It is released by the posterior part of the pituitary gland and also known as vasopressin. It mainly increases the permeability of distal convoluted tubule (DCT) and collecting duct (CD) due to which reabsorption of water increases and maintains osmoregulation in human kidney.
Incorrect. The full form of ADH is antidiuretic hormone. It is released by the posterior part of the pituitary gland and also known as vasopressin. It mainly increases the permeability of distal convoluted tubule (DCT) and collecting duct (CD) due to which reabsorption of water increases and maintains osmoregulation in human kidney.

Q491: Hydrochloric acid secreted by gastric glands, eases the action of enzyme............

Source: RRB Group-D 22-09-2018 (Shift-I)
Correct! Digestive functions are accomplished by gastric glands present in the wall of the stomach. They secrete hydrochloric acid, a protein digestive enzyme, pepsin and mucus. Hydrochloric acid forms an acidic medium which is helpful in the action of the pepsin enzyme. The stomach food is acidic and is made alkaline for the action of pancreatic enzymes. The pancreas secrete pancreatic juice which contains the trypsin enzyme for digestion of proteins.
Incorrect. Digestive functions are accomplished by gastric glands present in the wall of the stomach. They secrete hydrochloric acid, a protein digestive enzyme, pepsin and mucus. Hydrochloric acid forms an acidic medium which is helpful in the action of the pepsin enzyme. The stomach food is acidic and is made alkaline for the action of pancreatic enzymes. The pancreas secrete pancreatic juice which contains the trypsin enzyme for digestion of proteins.

Q494: …….. brings about the changes in appearance seen in boys at the time of puberty.

Source: RRB Group-D 31-10-2018 (Shift-II)
Correct! Testosterone is a male sex hormone that is important for sexual and reproductive development. The production of testosterone in men is mainly in the testes. The hypothalamus and pituitary gland of the brain regulate testosterone production. Due to testosterone secretion, changes are seen in appearence of boys only during puberty, such as voice becomes heavy, enlargement of the testicles and sprouting of pubic hair etc.
Incorrect. Testosterone is a male sex hormone that is important for sexual and reproductive development. The production of testosterone in men is mainly in the testes. The hypothalamus and pituitary gland of the brain regulate testosterone production. Due to testosterone secretion, changes are seen in appearence of boys only during puberty, such as voice becomes heavy, enlargement of the testicles and sprouting of pubic hair etc.

Q495: During puberty, secretion of sweat glands and sebaceous glands increases. Which element get secreted during this time through these glands?

Source: RRB Group-D 23-10-2018 (Shift-II)
Correct! During puberty, the secretion increases in the sweat glands and adipose glands, then sweat and oil secrete at that time. Sweat glands are a type of exocrine gland, which are glands that produce and secrete substances onto an epithelial surface by way of a duct. Its coiled part releases sweat. Sebaceous glands are usually attached to hair follicles and release a fatty substance, sebum, into the follicular duct and thence to the surface of the skin.
Incorrect. During puberty, the secretion increases in the sweat glands and adipose glands, then sweat and oil secrete at that time. Sweat glands are a type of exocrine gland, which are glands that produce and secrete substances onto an epithelial surface by way of a duct. Its coiled part releases sweat. Sebaceous glands are usually attached to hair follicles and release a fatty substance, sebum, into the follicular duct and thence to the surface of the skin.

Q496: Oestrogen, the female hormone, is secreted by the …….in females.

Source: RRB Group-D 12-12-2018 (Shift-I)
Correct! Estrogen is important for reproductive and sexual development in women, hence it is also called the female sex hormone.Estrogen plays significant role in the physiological changes of women and that is why, it is also called female growth hormone. Following changes are observed in women due to estrogen - • Development of breast in girls • Starting of menstrual cycle or period • Pubic hair growth in the genitals. The production of estrogen hormone in the body of women is mainly in the ovaries as well as by the adrenal gland and to some extent by the fetus and placenta.
Incorrect. Estrogen is important for reproductive and sexual development in women, hence it is also called the female sex hormone.Estrogen plays significant role in the physiological changes of women and that is why, it is also called female growth hormone. Following changes are observed in women due to estrogen - • Development of breast in girls • Starting of menstrual cycle or period • Pubic hair growth in the genitals. The production of estrogen hormone in the body of women is mainly in the ovaries as well as by the adrenal gland and to some extent by the fetus and placenta.

Q497: ...........is not an enzyme.

Source: RRB Group-D 31-10-2018 (Shift-III)
Correct! Insulin is the hormone, form in the beta cells of the pancreatic gland that stimulates the accumulation of glucose in the liver as glycogen and controls the proper usage of glucose by tissue cells.
Incorrect. Insulin is the hormone, form in the beta cells of the pancreatic gland that stimulates the accumulation of glucose in the liver as glycogen and controls the proper usage of glucose by tissue cells.

Q498: Which among the following micronutrients is essential for the normal functioning of the thyroid gland?

Source: RRB NTPC 07.03.2021 (Shift-I) Stage Ist
Correct! Iodine is an essential micronutrient used by the thyroid gland to make thyroid hormones that control many functions in the body including growth and development. Because our body does not produce iodine, it needs to be supplied in the diet. When iodine intake is poor, the body cannot produce enough thyroid hormones. Deficiency of iodine can cause endemic goitre, hypothyroidism, cretinism, decreased fertility rate, increased infant mortality, and mental retardation.
Incorrect. Iodine is an essential micronutrient used by the thyroid gland to make thyroid hormones that control many functions in the body including growth and development. Because our body does not produce iodine, it needs to be supplied in the diet. When iodine intake is poor, the body cannot produce enough thyroid hormones. Deficiency of iodine can cause endemic goitre, hypothyroidism, cretinism, decreased fertility rate, increased infant mortality, and mental retardation.

Q499: Rise in sugar level in blood is detected by the cells of:

Source: RRB Group-D 17-09-2018 (Shift-II)
Correct! The pancreas is a mixed gland. The pancreas has specific type of cells, called the Islets of Langerhans. They were discovered by Langerhans in 1869 AD. These cells are of three types: (a) Alpha (b) Beta and (c) Gamma cells, in which beta cells are of large size, secrete insulin hormone that regulates blood sugar levels.
Incorrect. The pancreas is a mixed gland. The pancreas has specific type of cells, called the Islets of Langerhans. They were discovered by Langerhans in 1869 AD. These cells are of three types: (a) Alpha (b) Beta and (c) Gamma cells, in which beta cells are of large size, secrete insulin hormone that regulates blood sugar levels.

Q500: Which hormone regulates the blood sugar level in the body?

Source: RRB NTPC 01.04.2021 (Shift-I) Stage Ist
Correct! Pancreas is a composite gland which acts as both exocrine and endocrine gland. The endocrine pancreas consists of 'Islets of Langerhans'. The two main types of cells in the Islet of Langerhans are called α-cells and β-cells. The α-cells secrete a hormone called glucagon, while the β-cells secrete insulin. Both hormones work in balance to play a vital role in regulating blood sugar levels. If the level of one hormone is higher or lower than the ideal range, blood sugar levels may spike or drop.
Incorrect. Pancreas is a composite gland which acts as both exocrine and endocrine gland. The endocrine pancreas consists of 'Islets of Langerhans'. The two main types of cells in the Islet of Langerhans are called α-cells and β-cells. The α-cells secrete a hormone called glucagon, while the β-cells secrete insulin. Both hormones work in balance to play a vital role in regulating blood sugar levels. If the level of one hormone is higher or lower than the ideal range, blood sugar levels may spike or drop.

Incorrect. See the explanation of the above question.

Q502: Which of following is NOT an endocrine gland?

Source: RRB NTPC 27.02.2021 (Shift-I) Stage Ist
Correct! Endocrine glands are the glands which not have a duct and secrete the contents directly in the blood stream. Pancreas, Adrenal and Thyroid gland are the examples of the endocrine glands. Salivary gland is an exocrine gland. The gland contains many lobules which pour the saliva in the common salivary duct.The salivary duct empties saliva in the mouth.
Incorrect. Endocrine glands are the glands which not have a duct and secrete the contents directly in the blood stream. Pancreas, Adrenal and Thyroid gland are the examples of the endocrine glands. Salivary gland is an exocrine gland. The gland contains many lobules which pour the saliva in the common salivary duct.The salivary duct empties saliva in the mouth.

Q503: Secretion from Prostate gland enters into ……

Source: RRB Group-D 03-10-2018 (Shift-I)
Correct! Prostate is a small gland found only in men that located between the penis and the bladder. Secretion from the prostate gland enters into urethra.
Incorrect. Prostate is a small gland found only in men that located between the penis and the bladder. Secretion from the prostate gland enters into urethra.

Q504: The release of which hormone causes simultaneous increase in heartbeat and breathing rate?

Source: RRB NTPC 31.01.2021 (Shift-II) Stage Ist
Correct! The release of Adrenaline hormone causes simultaneous increase in heartbeat and breathing rate. Adrenaline is normally produced both by the adrenal glands and by a small number of neurons in the medulla oblongata.
Incorrect. The release of Adrenaline hormone causes simultaneous increase in heartbeat and breathing rate. Adrenaline is normally produced both by the adrenal glands and by a small number of neurons in the medulla oblongata.

Incorrect. Testosterone is the hormone secreted by the testes. Testosterone is the steroid hormone of the androgen group that secretes from testicles of men. It helps in the development of sexual characterstics in men.

Q507: .............. gland is also known as master gland.

Source: RRB Group-D 22-09-2018 (Shift-I)
Correct! The pituitary gland is an endocrine gland located in the sphenoid bone of the cranium. It is called sella turcica. Its weight is about 0.6 grams. It is also known as the master gland. Hypothalamus is known as the'master of master gland'.
Incorrect. The pituitary gland is an endocrine gland located in the sphenoid bone of the cranium. It is called sella turcica. Its weight is about 0.6 grams. It is also known as the master gland. Hypothalamus is known as the'master of master gland'.

Q510: Which of these hormones stimulates uterine contractions and dilation of the cervix?

Source: RRB NTPC 27.02.2021 (Shift-I) Stage Ist
Correct! Oxytocin plays a key role in uterine contraction. Often called the 'love hormone', oxytocin is associated with feelings of bonding and motherhood. The another hormone released during labour called 'prolactin'. It helps us feel good, and it triggers nurturing feelings and behaviors. Receptor cells allow body to respond to oxytocin increase gradually in pregnancy and then increase a lot during labour. Oxytocin stimulates powerful contractions that help to thin and open (dilate) the cervix, moves the body down and out of the birth canal, pushes out the placenta, and limits bleeding at the site of the placenta. RRB Science Planner Biology YCT 582
Incorrect. Oxytocin plays a key role in uterine contraction. Often called the 'love hormone', oxytocin is associated with feelings of bonding and motherhood. The another hormone released during labour called 'prolactin'. It helps us feel good, and it triggers nurturing feelings and behaviors. Receptor cells allow body to respond to oxytocin increase gradually in pregnancy and then increase a lot during labour. Oxytocin stimulates powerful contractions that help to thin and open (dilate) the cervix, moves the body down and out of the birth canal, pushes out the placenta, and limits bleeding at the site of the placenta. RRB Science Planner Biology YCT 582

Q511: Which of the following glands is an endocrine gland in the human body?

Source: RRB NTPC 26.07.2021 (Shift-I) Stage Ist
Correct! Pituitary gland is an endocrine gland. It is also called master gland. In endocrine glands ducts are not found so they are also called ductless glands. They release hormones directly into the blood, such as thyroid, parathyroid, adrenal, testicular gland etc.
Incorrect. Pituitary gland is an endocrine gland. It is also called master gland. In endocrine glands ducts are not found so they are also called ductless glands. They release hormones directly into the blood, such as thyroid, parathyroid, adrenal, testicular gland etc.

Q512: Which of the following hormones stimulates milk production after childbirth?

Source: RRB JE 28.05.2019 (Shift-I)
Correct! Prolactin hormone stimulates the process of milk production after childbirth.
Incorrect. Prolactin hormone stimulates the process of milk production after childbirth.

Q513: Which hormone is released during emergency situtation?

Source: RRB JE 28.05.2019 (Shift-I)
Correct! Adrenaline hormone is released during emergency situation.
Incorrect. Adrenaline hormone is released during emergency situation.

Q514: What is the basic function of estrogen?

Source: RRB NTPC 24.07.2021 (Shift-I) Stage Ist
Correct! The primary function of estrogens is development of female secondary sexual characteristics. These include breasts, endometrium, regulation of the menstrual cycle etc. Estrogens are present in significant amounts in both men and women. They are present in significantly higher amounts in women. In males estrogen helps in maturation of the sperm and maintenance of a healthy libido.
Incorrect. The primary function of estrogens is development of female secondary sexual characteristics. These include breasts, endometrium, regulation of the menstrual cycle etc. Estrogens are present in significant amounts in both men and women. They are present in significantly higher amounts in women. In males estrogen helps in maturation of the sperm and maintenance of a healthy libido.

Q515: Which hormone promotes RBC production in bone marrow?

Source: RRB JE 01.06.2019 (Shift-I)
Correct! Erythropoietin hormone promotes RBC production in bone marrow.
Incorrect. Erythropoietin hormone promotes RBC production in bone marrow.

Correct! Hormones are normally absent in bacteria.
Incorrect. Hormones are normally absent in bacteria.

Incorrect. Bile is secreted by the liver which helps in digestion.

Q518: The _____ gland, which hangs by a thin stalk from the hypothalamus, is called the master gland of the human body.

Source: RRB NTPC 16.01.2021 (Shift-II) Stage Ist
Correct! The pituitary gland, also known as the hypophysis, is a pea-sized endocrine gland situated at the base of our brain. It is often referred to as the 'Master Gland' because it controls the functions of many other endocrine glands. The pituitary gland is divided into three parts, also called lobes: • Anterior pituitary • Intermediate pituitary • Posterior pituitary
Incorrect. The pituitary gland, also known as the hypophysis, is a pea-sized endocrine gland situated at the base of our brain. It is often referred to as the 'Master Gland' because it controls the functions of many other endocrine glands. The pituitary gland is divided into three parts, also called lobes: • Anterior pituitary • Intermediate pituitary • Posterior pituitary

Q519: Pheromone, released by an animal:

Source: RRB J.E. (14.12.2014, Green paper)
Correct! Pheromone is an excretory chemical factor that triggers a social response in members of the same species. Pheromones are chemicals capable of acting like hormones outside the body of the secreting individual, to impact the behavior of the receiving individuals. (viii) Reproductive System
Incorrect. Pheromone is an excretory chemical factor that triggers a social response in members of the same species. Pheromones are chemicals capable of acting like hormones outside the body of the secreting individual, to impact the behavior of the receiving individuals. (viii) Reproductive System

Q520: During puberty, a woman's first menstrual flow is known as __________.

Source: RRB Group-D– 29/08/2022 (Shift-II)
Correct! During puberty, a woman's first menstrual flow is known as menarche. It typically occurs between the ages of 10 and 14, with the average age of onset being 12.4 years.
Incorrect. During puberty, a woman's first menstrual flow is known as menarche. It typically occurs between the ages of 10 and 14, with the average age of onset being 12.4 years.

Q522: What is the best diet for a pregnant woman?

Source: RRB Group-D 29-09-2022 (Shift-I)
Correct! The best diet for a pregnant woman is a special diet prescribed by a dietician. Variety of vegetables, fruits, whole grains, fat-free foods are usually recommended for a pregnant woman. RRB Science Planner Biology YCT 583
Incorrect. The best diet for a pregnant woman is a special diet prescribed by a dietician. Variety of vegetables, fruits, whole grains, fat-free foods are usually recommended for a pregnant woman. RRB Science Planner Biology YCT 583

Q523: Which of the following is NOT a part of the female reproductive system?

Source: RRB Group-D 30-08-2022 (Shift-I)
Correct! Urethra is the tube through which urine leaves the body. It discharges urine from the bladder. It is not the part of female reproductive system. The female reproductive organs include several key structures, such as the ovaries, uterus, fallopian tubes vagina, and vulva. These organs are involved in fertility, conception, pregnancy, and childbirth.
Incorrect. Urethra is the tube through which urine leaves the body. It discharges urine from the bladder. It is not the part of female reproductive system. The female reproductive organs include several key structures, such as the ovaries, uterus, fallopian tubes vagina, and vulva. These organs are involved in fertility, conception, pregnancy, and childbirth.

Q524: Oral contraceptive pills work by stopping ……… .

Source: RRB Group-D 18-08-2022 (Shift-II)
Correct! The oral contraceptive pills-prevents the ovaries from releasing an egg each month, i.e. they work by stopping ovulation.
Incorrect. The oral contraceptive pills-prevents the ovaries from releasing an egg each month, i.e. they work by stopping ovulation.

Q525: Is there a visible difference between sperms which contain X chromosomes and sperms which contain Y chromosomes?

Source: RRB Group-D 27-09-2022 (Shift-I)
Correct! A sperm is a male gametophyte cell capable to fertilize an oocyte and carries genetic information for determining the sex of offspring. Recent studies shows there is negligible differences between X & Y spermatozoa with respect to ratio shape & size, motility and swimming pattern, strength, electric charge, pH, stress response, aneuploidy. The only difference between X & Y spermatozoa lies in their DNA content. Hence, there is difference in size or motility.
Incorrect. A sperm is a male gametophyte cell capable to fertilize an oocyte and carries genetic information for determining the sex of offspring. Recent studies shows there is negligible differences between X & Y spermatozoa with respect to ratio shape & size, motility and swimming pattern, strength, electric charge, pH, stress response, aneuploidy. The only difference between X & Y spermatozoa lies in their DNA content. Hence, there is difference in size or motility.

Q526: Which of the following is an example of the barrier method of contraception?

Source: RRB Group-D 27-09-2022 (Shift-II)
Correct! Barrier methods of Birth control are: Spermicidal, condom, Sponge, Diaphragm and Cervical CAP. Condoms are also known as "barrier methods of birth control"
Incorrect. Barrier methods of Birth control are: Spermicidal, condom, Sponge, Diaphragm and Cervical CAP. Condoms are also known as "barrier methods of birth control"

Q527: The first menstrual flow begins at puberty and is termed as:

Source: RRB Group-D 17-09-2022 (Shift-II)
Correct! The first menstrual flow begins at puberty and is termed as menarche. Most of the girls get their first periods between 11 to 14 years. The sign of menarche include light bleeding, cramps and mood swings.
Incorrect. The first menstrual flow begins at puberty and is termed as menarche. Most of the girls get their first periods between 11 to 14 years. The sign of menarche include light bleeding, cramps and mood swings.

Q528: Which method of contraception changes the hormonal balance of the body?

Source: RRB Group-D 11-10-2022 (Shift-I)
Correct! Pill contain a mixture of estrogen and progesterone hormones which can alter the hormonal balance of the body.
Incorrect. Pill contain a mixture of estrogen and progesterone hormones which can alter the hormonal balance of the body.

Q529: Which of the following statements is incorrect about AIDS?

Source: RRB Group-D 19-09-2022 (Shift-I)
Correct! Acquired Immunodeficiency syndrome (AIDS) is a chronic, potentially life-threatening condition caused by the human immunodeficiency virus (HIV). HIV is a sexually transmitted infection. It can also be spread by contact with infected blood and from illicit injection drug users or sharing needles. It can also be spread from mother to child during pregnancy, child birth or breastfeeding. Hence, option (d) the virus can be transmitted by shaking hands with person infected with HIV statement is incorrect about AIDS.
Incorrect. Acquired Immunodeficiency syndrome (AIDS) is a chronic, potentially life-threatening condition caused by the human immunodeficiency virus (HIV). HIV is a sexually transmitted infection. It can also be spread by contact with infected blood and from illicit injection drug users or sharing needles. It can also be spread from mother to child during pregnancy, child birth or breastfeeding. Hence, option (d) the virus can be transmitted by shaking hands with person infected with HIV statement is incorrect about AIDS.

Q530: What happens during menstruation?

Source: RRB Group-D 19-09-2022 (Shift-I)
Correct! Menstruation is one part of a woman's reproductive cycle when the lining of the uterus (endometrium) is shed. This occurs throughout a woman's reproductive life. With monthly cycle, the endometrium prepares itself to nourish a fetus.
Incorrect. Menstruation is one part of a woman's reproductive cycle when the lining of the uterus (endometrium) is shed. This occurs throughout a woman's reproductive life. With monthly cycle, the endometrium prepares itself to nourish a fetus.

Q531: What is the basic event in reproduction?

Source: RRB Group-D 24-08-2022 (Shift-III)
Correct! The basic event in the reproduction process is DNA replication which helps in doubling of parental DNA and with the help of meiotic cell division restores accurate chromosome number in the offspring.
Incorrect. The basic event in the reproduction process is DNA replication which helps in doubling of parental DNA and with the help of meiotic cell division restores accurate chromosome number in the offspring.

Q532: Which of the following is the INCORRECT feature related to animal reproduction?

Source: RRB Group-D 24-08-2022 (Shift-III)
Correct! In animals fertilization of an egg by sperm normally occurs in the follopian tubes. The fertilized egg then moves to the uterus, where it implants into uterus lining.
Incorrect. In animals fertilization of an egg by sperm normally occurs in the follopian tubes. The fertilized egg then moves to the uterus, where it implants into uterus lining.

Q533: Oral pills used for birth control change the hormonal balance of the body. How do these prevent pregnancy? Select the correct option.

Source: RRB Group-D 23-08-2022 (Shift-I)
Correct! Oral contraceptive pills have been widely considered as method of birth control. Usually these pills come in different variants-some containing estrogen while some containing progesterone hormones. Usually these pills stop the process of ovulation in female's body. The ovulation involves releasing of eggs from ovaries to oviduct (falopian tube). Some pills also harden the cervix muscle so that female egg may not enter the vagina and fertilization may never occur.
Incorrect. Oral contraceptive pills have been widely considered as method of birth control. Usually these pills come in different variants-some containing estrogen while some containing progesterone hormones. Usually these pills stop the process of ovulation in female's body. The ovulation involves releasing of eggs from ovaries to oviduct (falopian tube). Some pills also harden the cervix muscle so that female egg may not enter the vagina and fertilization may never occur.

Q534: In human males, why are testes present outside the abdominal cavity in a pouch called scrotum?

Source: RRB Group-D 22-08-2022 (Shift-III)
Correct! In human males, testes present outside the abdominal cavity in pouch called scrotum which helps in maintaining temperature 2 to 3 degrees celsius lower than the body for sperm formation.
Incorrect. In human males, testes present outside the abdominal cavity in pouch called scrotum which helps in maintaining temperature 2 to 3 degrees celsius lower than the body for sperm formation.

Q535: Which of the following is not a change that marks the onset of puberty

Source: RRB Group-D 25-08-2022 (Shift-I)
Correct! Puberty is the process of biological and physical changes through which a child's body matures into an adult body capable of sexual reproduction. The changes that marks the onset of puberty is change in voice, sudden increase in height and the change in body shape while growth of nails is NOT a change that marks the assets of puberty.
Incorrect. Puberty is the process of biological and physical changes through which a child's body matures into an adult body capable of sexual reproduction. The changes that marks the onset of puberty is change in voice, sudden increase in height and the change in body shape while growth of nails is NOT a change that marks the assets of puberty.

Q536: Which of the following DOES NOT constitute a part of pubertal development:

Source: RRB Group-D 24-08-2022 (Shift-I)
Correct! Puberty is the process of physical changes through which a child's body matures into an adult body capable of sexual reproduction. Getting pimples, menstruation and voice change constitute a part of pubertal development while obesity is not its part.
Incorrect. Puberty is the process of physical changes through which a child's body matures into an adult body capable of sexual reproduction. Getting pimples, menstruation and voice change constitute a part of pubertal development while obesity is not its part.

Q537: The uterine wall in females prepares itself to receive the developing fertilized egg. In case there is no fertilization, the thickened lining of the uterine wall breaks down and goes out of the body along with blood. This is called:

Source: RRB Group-D 29-09-2022 (Shift-III)
Correct! The uterine wall in females prepare itself to receive the fertilized egg. In case there is no fertilization, the thickened lining of the uterine wall breaks down and goes out of the body along with blood. This is called Menstruation.
Incorrect. The uterine wall in females prepare itself to receive the fertilized egg. In case there is no fertilization, the thickened lining of the uterine wall breaks down and goes out of the body along with blood. This is called Menstruation.

Q538: Sexual reproduction in human beings involves the introduction of sperm in the vagina of the female. Where does fertilization occur?

Source: RRB Group-D 28-09-2022 (Shift-III)
Correct! Sexual reproduction in human beings involves the introduction of sperm in the vagina of the female. The fertilization occur in the fallopian tube.
Incorrect. Sexual reproduction in human beings involves the introduction of sperm in the vagina of the female. The fertilization occur in the fallopian tube.

Q539: Which among the following is not a change noticed among children who entered teenage (boys and girls)?

Source: RRB Group-D 28-09-2022 (Shift-I)
Correct! Hair growth is seen in all parts of the body is not a special change noticed among children who entered teenage. While, Hair growth is some part of the body, 'Some develop pimples' and skin in many becomes oily are the features of 'Puberty'.
Incorrect. Hair growth is seen in all parts of the body is not a special change noticed among children who entered teenage. While, Hair growth is some part of the body, 'Some develop pimples' and skin in many becomes oily are the features of 'Puberty'.

Q540: During adolescence, several changes occur in the human body. Which of the following changes is associated with sexual maturation only in girls?

Source: RRB Group-D– 17/08/2022 (Shift-II)
Correct! Adolescence is a period in human life when several changes occur in the human body, these changes comes in different ways in both boys and girls. Among girls, during puberty the mammary gland develops to perform its function during pregnancy and lactation.
Incorrect. Adolescence is a period in human life when several changes occur in the human body, these changes comes in different ways in both boys and girls. Among girls, during puberty the mammary gland develops to perform its function during pregnancy and lactation.

Q541: Which part of the human sperm is responsible for determination of sex of the zygote?

Source: RRB Group-D– 30/09/2022 (Shift-III)
Correct! The male reproductive system produce sperm. The head of the sperm contains the DNA, which when combined with the egg's DNA, will create a new individual. The tip of the sperm head is the portion called the acrosome, which enables the sperm to penetrate the egg. The midpiece contains the mitochondria which supplies the energy the tail needs to move. So, part A (head) of sperm is responsible for determination of sex of the zygote.
Incorrect. The male reproductive system produce sperm. The head of the sperm contains the DNA, which when combined with the egg's DNA, will create a new individual. The tip of the sperm head is the portion called the acrosome, which enables the sperm to penetrate the egg. The midpiece contains the mitochondria which supplies the energy the tail needs to move. So, part A (head) of sperm is responsible for determination of sex of the zygote.

Q542: Girls should take special care with respect to health and hygiene during the time menstrual flow to avoid infections and ill health. Which of the following statements in this regard is false?

Source: RRB Group-D– 26/08/2022 (Shift-III)
Correct! During the time of menstrual flow, girls should keep trace of their menstrual cycle and be prepared for the onset of menstruation. Girls should use sanitary napkins or clean homemade pads. Girls should change pads after every 4-5 hours or as per the requirement. Girls should not consume chips and packed or tinned snacks.
Incorrect. During the time of menstrual flow, girls should keep trace of their menstrual cycle and be prepared for the onset of menstruation. Girls should use sanitary napkins or clean homemade pads. Girls should change pads after every 4-5 hours or as per the requirement. Girls should not consume chips and packed or tinned snacks.

Incorrect. Implantation and development of embryo into →uterus Fertilization of egg → Fallopian tube ∴ Since Part A denotes uterus and B denotes Fallopian tube, hence option (2) is correct.

Q545: _______refers to the cessation of menstruation.

Source: RRB Group-D– 05/09/2022 (Shift-I)
Correct! Menopause refers to the cessation of menstruation. It is a natural decline in reproductive hormones when a woman reaches the age of 45 to 55. The sign of the menopause is 12 months since last menstruation.
Incorrect. Menopause refers to the cessation of menstruation. It is a natural decline in reproductive hormones when a woman reaches the age of 45 to 55. The sign of the menopause is 12 months since last menstruation.

Q546: The nutrients are supplied to the foetus from the mother through:

Source: RRB Group-D– 22/09/2022 (Shift-III)
Correct! The nutrients are supplied to the foetus from the mother through placenta. The placenta is a temporary organ that formed in the uterus during pregnancy. It attaches to the uterine wall and provides nutrients and oxygen to the baby through the umbilical cord.
Incorrect. The nutrients are supplied to the foetus from the mother through placenta. The placenta is a temporary organ that formed in the uterus during pregnancy. It attaches to the uterine wall and provides nutrients and oxygen to the baby through the umbilical cord.

Source: RRB Group-D– 20/09/2022 (Shift-III)

Incorrect. Vas deferens is not a part of the female reproductive system. Fallopian tube, oviduct, ovaries are the part of female reproductive system. Vas deference is the part of male reproductive system.

Q554: Which of the following is main women sex hormone?

Source: RRB NTPC 25.01.2021 (Shift-II) Stage Ist
Correct! Estrogen is the main women sex hormones. It helps develop and maintain both the reproductive system and female characteristics such as breasts and pubic hair. The woman's ovaries make most estrogen hormones, Men have estrogen, too, but in smaller amounts.
Incorrect. Estrogen is the main women sex hormones. It helps develop and maintain both the reproductive system and female characteristics such as breasts and pubic hair. The woman's ovaries make most estrogen hormones, Men have estrogen, too, but in smaller amounts.

Q555: ………. forms a common passage for both urine and sperms in human males.

Source: RRB ALP & Tec. (09-08-18 Shift-III)
Correct! Urethra forms a common passage for both urine and sperms in human males. Male urethra is long about 20 cm which starts from the urinary meatus or external urethral orifice and opens out through the urogenital cavity at end of penis. In females, the urethra helps in the discharge of urine from the urinary bladder. The urinary tract connects to the urinary muscle above the vulva, while the urethra of the female empties into the urogenital sinus.
Incorrect. Urethra forms a common passage for both urine and sperms in human males. Male urethra is long about 20 cm which starts from the urinary meatus or external urethral orifice and opens out through the urogenital cavity at end of penis. In females, the urethra helps in the discharge of urine from the urinary bladder. The urinary tract connects to the urinary muscle above the vulva, while the urethra of the female empties into the urogenital sinus.

Q559: What of the following is primary sex organ in man?

Source: RRB ALP & Tec. (10-08-18 Shift-II)
Correct! The pair of testis (testicles) is the primary sex organ in man. The male reproductive system includes the penis, scrotum, epididymis, vas deferens, prostate, cowper's gland and seminal vesicles.
Incorrect. The pair of testis (testicles) is the primary sex organ in man. The male reproductive system includes the penis, scrotum, epididymis, vas deferens, prostate, cowper's gland and seminal vesicles.

Q560: How many testicles does a male have?

Source: RRB Group-D 15-10-2018 (Shift-I)
Correct! The testes are oval organs about the size of very large olives that lie in the scrotum, secured at either end by a structure called the spermatic cord. Most men have two testes. The testes are responsible for making testosterone, the primary male sex hormone, and for producing sperm. Within the testes are coiled masses of tubes called seminiferous tubules. These tubules are responsible for producing the sperm cells through a process called spermatogenesis.
Incorrect. The testes are oval organs about the size of very large olives that lie in the scrotum, secured at either end by a structure called the spermatic cord. Most men have two testes. The testes are responsible for making testosterone, the primary male sex hormone, and for producing sperm. Within the testes are coiled masses of tubes called seminiferous tubules. These tubules are responsible for producing the sperm cells through a process called spermatogenesis.

Q561: Asexual reproduction differs from sexual reproduction in that in asexual reproduction,

Source: RRB ALP & Tec. (09-08-18 Shift-I)
Correct! Differences in asexual and sexual reproduction: Asexual reproduction Sexual reproduction
Incorrect. Differences in asexual and sexual reproduction: Asexual reproduction Sexual reproduction

Q562: Syngamy is defined as:

Source: RRB ALP & Tec. (13-08-18 Shift-II)
Correct! The process of fusion between the haploid male nucleus and egg nucleus is known as amphimixis. It is also known as syngamy or fertilization which leads to the formation of a diploid zygote. It leads to the recombination of character which causes variation. It is a mode of sexual reproduction.
Incorrect. The process of fusion between the haploid male nucleus and egg nucleus is known as amphimixis. It is also known as syngamy or fertilization which leads to the formation of a diploid zygote. It leads to the recombination of character which causes variation. It is a mode of sexual reproduction.

Q563: A baby receives its nutrition in the mother's womb through the .......... .

Source: RRB NTPC 25.01.2021 (Shift-I) Stage Ist
Correct! Placenta is a temporary organ that connects a growing baby to mother's uterus in womb. It attaches to the wall of mother's uterus, usually on the top or side and acts as a lifeline that gives nutrients and oxygen to baby through the umbilical cord.
Incorrect. Placenta is a temporary organ that connects a growing baby to mother's uterus in womb. It attaches to the wall of mother's uterus, usually on the top or side and acts as a lifeline that gives nutrients and oxygen to baby through the umbilical cord.

Q564: Which part of the female reproductive system prepares itself every month to receive and nurture the growing child?

Source: RRB ALP & Tec. (14-08-18 Shift-III)
Correct! The uterus is the female reproductive part that prepares itself every month to receive the male germ cell and nurture a growing child by menstruation. Uterus, an inverted pear-shaped muscular organ of the female reproductive system, located between the bladder and the rectum.Its lowest section, the cervix, opens into the vagina.The inner linings of the uterus thicken, and a plentiful supply of blood is flown to nourish the embryo.
Incorrect. The uterus is the female reproductive part that prepares itself every month to receive the male germ cell and nurture a growing child by menstruation. Uterus, an inverted pear-shaped muscular organ of the female reproductive system, located between the bladder and the rectum.Its lowest section, the cervix, opens into the vagina.The inner linings of the uterus thicken, and a plentiful supply of blood is flown to nourish the embryo.

Q565: Implantation is the process of:

Source: RRB ALP & Tec. (14-08-18 Shift-II)
Correct! Implantation is defined as the process by which the embryo attaches to the endometrial surface of the uterus and invades the epithelium and then the maternal circulation to form the placenta.
Incorrect. Implantation is defined as the process by which the embryo attaches to the endometrial surface of the uterus and invades the epithelium and then the maternal circulation to form the placenta.

Q566: Prostate gland is present below:

Source: RRB ALP & Tec. (14-08-18 Shift-I)
Correct! The prostate is a walnut-sized gland located between the bladder and the penis. It is important for reproduction, because it supplies the seminal fluid, which mixes with sperm from the testes. It is rich in fructose (source of energy), citrate, prostaglandins, calcium and certain enzymes. Seminal fluid along with the sperms is called semen or seminal fluid. It also maintains the viability and motility of sperms as it provides proper pH (approximately pH 7.5) and ionic strength.
Incorrect. The prostate is a walnut-sized gland located between the bladder and the penis. It is important for reproduction, because it supplies the seminal fluid, which mixes with sperm from the testes. It is rich in fructose (source of energy), citrate, prostaglandins, calcium and certain enzymes. Seminal fluid along with the sperms is called semen or seminal fluid. It also maintains the viability and motility of sperms as it provides proper pH (approximately pH 7.5) and ionic strength.

Incorrect. See the explanation of the above question.

Q568: The embryo gets nutrition from the mother's blood with the help of a special tissue called:

Source: RRB ALP & Tec. (14-08-18 Shift-I)
Correct! The embryo gets nutrition from the mother’s blood with the help of a special tissue called placenta. During pregnancy, the placenta develops in the uterus that has main function to provide oxygen and nutrition to the unborn child. This nutrition is obtained from the mother's blood. (a) The placenta itself stimulates the development of the baby. (b) The placenta helps in the formation of lactogen in the body. (c) The placenta connects the mother and child.
Incorrect. The embryo gets nutrition from the mother’s blood with the help of a special tissue called placenta. During pregnancy, the placenta develops in the uterus that has main function to provide oxygen and nutrition to the unborn child. This nutrition is obtained from the mother's blood. (a) The placenta itself stimulates the development of the baby. (b) The placenta helps in the formation of lactogen in the body. (c) The placenta connects the mother and child.
